writepity: 1) In senior year we had our Honors Convocation for students who obtained a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher. Most of my friends obtained the gold or purple cord; which signified a GPA of 3.75 or above. When my best friend went on stage; he received the white cord; which is for a GPA of 3-3.25. All of us were astonished; not because we thought any lower of him; but for the entire 4 years my friend told us that his grades were right up there with ours and because we took very similar classes. Nobody really questioned anything because we assumed he was telling the truth. The next day I went to his house because I wanted answers. He was hard to talk to at first because he figured out that something was wrong but he did not want to tell me. It was a struggle for him to even look me in the eye because he knew he'd been lying to everybody; including me; for the better part of 4 years. After some not-so-friendly talking; he spilled. He broke into tears and revealed to me that he has a learning disability; and didn't want to disclose anything to his close friends because he thought we would look down upon him.  /  / 2) I just felt terrible and wanted him to get better. I pitied him because he didn't know what to say to us.  /  / 3) I wanted him to tell the rest of our friends and come clean. That's the only way to get over a situation like this.
writecomp: 1) When my father went out of the country for a business trip; my mom was home alone for about 2 weeks. We have a lot of family nearby but she was home taking care of my grandmother who fell ill just a week before. It was difficult to see both of them stuck at home; and my mom running around to do everything she could to help my grandmother. I could see the pain and struggle in her eyes as it was difficult for her to manage the house with an ill grandmother and two teenage kids running around; wanting to have their freedom.  /  / 2) I wanted to help her by spending more quality time with her. It's so easy to disregard spending time with parents when we get busy with our own lives. But a little deeper look at the situation shows that our parents tend to be more busy than us; just in different ways.  /  / 3) I told her I'd take her out to dinner once so she can get her mind off how stressful everything was and I got her a massage pass at the nearest spa so she can get some actual relaxation. It made everything feel so much better that I was closer to her than ever before.
writesymp: 1) During this school  year a friend I met earlier decided to transfer to a different school. He was an out of state student and just couldn't adjust to this university. I talked to him soon after he decided to transfer and he told me that it just wouldn't work. For one; he's an out of state student who didn't know anybody upon coming to this school. As that kind of student; you really hope for a good room mate who you can be with for the early parts of the year. His roommate was terrible. An arrogant student who didn't care at all for anybody else.  /  / 2) I wanted to help him and do something that would make him feel more at home. Even though I've never been through a situation exactly like that; I've heard stories and could only imagine what that would be like.  /  / 3) I spent more time with him; hoping that he would change his mind. I also invited more of my friends to hangout with him so he feels a sense of comfort. Unfortunately; he still decided to transfer as the large classes and the overall community wasn't something that liked too much.
writeempat: 1) A close friend of mine didn't get into her dream Ivy League school this past year. Personally; I never thought too deeply of going to a school like that until right around the college application process. I fell in love with some of the schools there and worked endlessly to complete applications and recommendation letters. I too got rejected from my dream school and allowed me to empathize.  /  / 2) When she told me; I felt like I knew exactly what she was feeling as I was there just a year ago. It's a horrible feeling; a feeling that all of your hard work in the past 12 years gets reduced to a few sheets of papers; that either gets an "Accept" or "Rejection". It's demoralizing; really. And I knew she felt the same.  /  / 3) So I called her and told her to keep her head up and realize that the school doesn't make the person; but the person and that school can make a difference. And that just because one school doesn't necessarily want her; it doesn't mean she's not good enough to get things done. Obviously these are just words that will only have a meaning later on; but just having somebody to talk to really does make a difference in a time like that.  /
plove: I believe that would be a false notion of love. Love is an emotion that should be expressed through times of hardship and happiness; and every single emotion that exists. Love is a complementary emotion that is felt between two people; or things; and is one that is omnipresent. Saying that pity is a kind love may be one way to portray what love is; but love cannot be the only emotion shown during times of pity. Pity means you feel poorly for somebody and wish the best for them. If love was present in this; then that feeling would change to a feeling of making yourself to anything possible to make whom you love feel better.
pcontempt: I believe this is relatively true. Contempt may be a more harsh way to phrase things; but there must be some pity present for one to feel contempt.
clove: Compassion and love do come hand in hand. I believe that one can only feel true compassion with somebody else if there is love between the two. Compassion is having the ability to pick out what's wrong without somebody having to say it; and doing something that makes it easier for that person to have a normal sense back. It's difficult to judge where the line is; but I believe that compassion can only exist where love is present; not necessarily a kind of love. They coexist.
slove: I believe that sympathy is definitely something that exists during love but is not necessarily an indicator of love. I did not "love" my friend as I would see others but I still sympathized with him because of his situation.
elove: Empathy isn't necessarily a kind of love; but it's something that will truly exist if the time comes when two people care about each other a lot. I by no means loved that person; but I did care very deeply for them as a close friend would. I say this because I would go out of my way to help; but I wouldn't feel the need to do so as I would for others that I do believe I love. Therefore; I believe that empathy is an emotion that is present in love; but love is not needed to empathize.

writepity: When I was in 8th grade; my younger brother was at the same school as me and was in the 6th grade.  My brother had always been the opposite of me in that he never wanted to do is homework and most times; never did his homework.  One time he had lied to our parents about homework so much that he had 20 missing assignments.  This number was unheard of.  Growing up in the same environment as him; I felt very little sympathy for him because I had taken the same classes and done just fine.  In addition; he was showing no effort to succeed.  However; one day at my brother's flag football game; some kid told his parent that someone had 20 missing assignments and then the surrounding parents started ridiculing the kid and the parent; even though my mom was sitting right there.  Then the parent asked who the kid was and when he said the name; all the parents got super quiet because they knew that they had been ridiculing my mom and her son right in front of her face.  When my mom came home and told me the story; I felt pity for my brother.  Not in the way that I felt bad for him having the missing assignments; but because I felt bad that people were talking about him behind his back.  They had not known the circumstances and they were not justified to talk about him like that.  However; since I felt my brother should have never been in the situation; I did not feel stronger emotions; such as sympathy or compassion.
writetende: This last summer; my girlfriend's two best friends' moms both got diagnosed with cancer at roughly the same time.  It was a terrible situation; although both were told that the cancers should not be terminal.  However; when she told me this; I felt tenderness toward her.  She had grown up with these best friends and therefore; knew each of the moms on a relatively personal level.  However; it was nothing like having one of her own parents diagnosed with cancer so it was a difficult spot to feel sympathy for.  It was noticeable that she was upset; but then again she wasn't completely shaken up.  Therefore; I felt some caring attitude toward her; but it was not overwhelming.
writesymp: This year at the NCRB; I was playing basketball but was waiting on the sideline to play in the next game.  In the game; there was one player who was not good at all.  He was also cherry picking; or not playing much defense and just running to the other end of the court when his team got the ball.  One play; he was all the way down on the offense side of the court when his team got the ball and they threw it down the court to him.  Therefore; he had a wide open layup.  He missed the layup 3 times and then that is when someone on the other team ran down the court to get a rebound (since everyone assumed he would make it).  He then missed a layup for the 4th time in a row and the other team got the ball.  When they came back down the court; all the older; better basketball players were making fun of him very badly.  All of a sudden; he stormed off the court with what looked like tears in his eyes.  He was saying "Fuck Off" to them; but looked more sad than mad at the situation.  He grabbed his things and left.  He obviously should have made the layups and I would consider myself way better at basketball than him; but I did not say anything and felt that no one else should have; unless maybe you were friends with him.
writeempat: Earlier this year; one of my friends was arguing with his girlfriend and was not in a good mood.  He was in his room and had to ask his roommate to leave so he could talk.  They were talking about him; not in a negative way; but also not in a positive way.  I felt that they shouldn't really tell everyone about it because it was his personal business.  I felt empathy toward him because I have had fights with my girlfriend and I know that I usually would rather have no one know because it makes the situation simpler and easier to resolve.  Therefore; I felt as if I had been in that situation before and knew exactly how he was feeling; despite not knowing what the fight was about.
plove: Pity is a love in which the relationship is not in the greatest portion but there is love nonetheless.
pcontempt: I think this is true because it is not as strong of an emotion such as sympathy; but it does convey a sense of feeling a portion of the emotion.
tlove: It would be a love that is possibly at the beginning and just beginning to form into something bigger.
slove: I would call it a deeper love because there are more emotions connected with it.
elove: It would be a love in which someone from the outside can relate to exactly what the couple is doing or how they are feeling because of similar past relationships.

writepity: When my friend got into an advanced school for science and math; I pitied her because I knew the amount of time and work that would have be put into it. She stayed up late almost every night either studying or finishing homework. It was helpful and challenging; but in the end we both ended up going to the same college. I think she would have had a better high school experience if she had not gone to that program.
writetende: When I was visiting my grandpa in the hospital; I knew it would be the last time I would see him. He was attached to many different machines and on various medicines. By the time I had gotten to the hospital in New Jersey; he was unconscious the entire time. I knew he did not know I was there with him; but I was glad to be there with my entire family. The waiting room for the ICU patients was entirely taken up by our family and friends. That is when I truly realized the great impact my grandpa had on so many people's lives. When I went by his side; I held his hand as the machines were unplugged; honored to have called such a great man my grandfather. Just his touch was so tender and comforting.
writecomp: When I travel to places like India; there are people there living on the streets with no money; home; and minimal clothes. I feel compassion for them. If I were in their shoes; I imagine what it would be like. I realize how fortunate I am to have as much as I do and also realize how much I take for granted. I try to help by giving them some money; even though it is not enough to greatly impact their lives; hopefully it can improve their lives even a little. It is hard to imagine so many lives in poverty when we are blessed with so much; but it is present in places all around the world. I feel compassion for all these brave and strong people who experience it every day.
writesymp: When my sister had to get stitches in her head; I stayed at home with my uncle while my parents took her to the doctor. I felt bad that this had happened to her and wanted to help. Although I did not know how she felt and could not know how she felt; I felt sympathy for her. I wanted to help and make her feel better in any way possible. I would watch TV and play games with her. I knew the things she was missing out on. We went on vacation shortly after; and she could not go in the ocean because of her injury so I stayed and made sandcastles with her so she would not feel left out.
plove: Pity is wanting the best for someone who you love. It is felling bad they are going through someone; and it could have been avoided.
pcontempt: Yes because people often cause their own situations that make people feel pity for them.
tlove: Tenderness is a warm kind of love; where a person understands the other person's position and emotions. It is a true feeling of love and understanding.
clove: Compassion is understanding the other person's feelings; it is loving everything about them. When you put yourself in another person's shoes/situation you truly learn their life.
slove: Sympathy is love where you are there for someone else when they need it most. Without judging them; you give them a shoulder to lean on.

writepity: A time that i felt pity toward someone was in my high school diving state meet.  I had trained hard all season and then got into a bad car accident that didn't allow me to practice.  So i got back on the boards just in time to be able to qualify and compete for states.  My dream the last 4 years of high school was to win the state meet my senior year.  My two big competitors we really talented diver but nothing too hard for me to handle.  So during the whole competition i felt pity toward them because i kept telling myself that i messed up because of my time away.  It wasn't fair for me to do that but i did.  I ended up getting 3rd in the state whicjh i was happy with but I know that if i hadnt been injured i could have won.  So after the competition and even now i feel pity towadr those girls.
writecomp: When i feel compassionate toward someone I know I love them.  I am compassionate toward my boyfriend as he is toward me.  A moment when I feel this way is when he took me out to dinner on valentines day.  It was the perfect moment and I know I couldn't be happier with anyone else.  He cares about me and he loves me and that makes me feel compassion for him.
writeempat: One time I experienced the feeling of empathy was when I was younger.  My aunt was going through breast cancer and that made me feel very empathetic toward her situation.  It also made me feel that way about the rest of our family and for her kids and her husband.  What they had to go through was hard on the family and i felt very empathetic for them.  It was hard for my dad too because it was his sister and it was scary having to watch him go through that with her.  I would hear stories from my dad and from my cousins about the surgeries and medicine she has to take.  When she went through therapy and started to lose her hair i again felt empathetic.  I could have never imagined having to go through something like that in my life and feeling sorry for my family that they had to deal with me.  As a kind an observer i felt empathetic for her and having breast cancer.
plove: I think pity can be connected with jealousy not love.
pcontempt: I agree
clove: Compassion is a caring kind of love.  It's how you show them you care for them.
elove: It's kind of a sad love.  Like you feel bad for someone you love and by feeling that way you show empathy toward them.  It's not a bad thing it is a sign of love toward that person

writepity: There was one time where I had felt pity for a friend. She had sprained her ankle during her soccer season of her senior year in high school. I felt bad for her because she had worked so hard throughout high school and now she was not able to play in her last season of high school because she was injured. I felt pity because I thought she deserved better. I wanted to help her but there was only so much I could do. I tried to make her happy by distracting her attention off of soccer and spend time with her doing different activities.
writecomp: I once felt compassion toward my best friend. I remember a moment where I was going through a difficult time in my life and she was there to support me and make me feel better. I really appreciated her efforts in trying to make me feel better. It made me want to be able to do the same for her. If she was ever in a difficult time in her life I would hope that I could also be the person she can rely on talking to and trusting. I felt like our relationship grew after I had shared things that I would not have been able to with others and this built my compassion towards them.
writeempat: The last time I felt empathy toward someone was when my dad got promoted in his job. He was not doing to well financially and it caused our whole family to feel worried and stressed . But once he found out this great news all of the stress was put away. My dad was excited and happy and our family was proud of him. I felt happy with him because he is someone that I care about. I congratulated him and wanted to support him throughout his future.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: Yes because it is something we all experience whether we know the person or not. We will always feel slight pity for the homeless stranger on the sidewalk.
clove: It is almost the same as saying you are passionate about something; such as a sport. You love your sport; and invest all of your time and effort into it to be the best you can be. With compassion it is similar but with someone else; you love them and want the best for them.
efeltother: In context to the story: /  / 1. Happy / 2. Excited / 3. Grateful
elove: It would be the kind of love where I am able to put myself in their shoes and experience the emotions that they have or are going through.

writepity: The last time that I felt pity towards someone was when I was home over spring break. Walking down the blocks in New York City I saw so many homeless men and women; but instead of feeling badly for them and trying to help them out; I felt puty towards them. There signs read things about just using the money for alcohol; or they are sitting in the cold; smoking cigarettes while the dog they have kept with them looks as though it has not eaten in the longest time. This was pity; because I felt bad for their poor judgement in the truly awful situations that they were in.
writecomp: One time in which I have felt compassion towards someone was when I did Dance Marathon at the University of Michigan just a couple of weeks ago. For Dance Marathon we are supposed to stand for 30 hours; dancing for most of it; in order to show our support and understanding for the children who go through a similar pain but a completely different struggle each day with their illness. Each team is given a family that they get to interact with and hear their stories and see their struggles. However; I did not feel immediately emphatic towards our girl; Emma; who did not speak until the age of 5 because of down syndrome. I did not immediately feel pity towards her family for dealing with a child with a disability. Instead I felt compassion for our sporty and spunky Emma; who never complained once or even spoke about what was "wrong" with her. Instead she came into the room; smiling; ready to play basketball; her second favorite sport. She introduced herself to all of us; organized a photo to her liking; and never stopped playing basketball with all of us. Her family just looked happy to see their daughter interacting and having fun. This was the last time I truly felt compassionate towards a girl and her family.
writesymp: One time in which I felt sympathy towards someone was when my roommate was going through a hard time with her boyfriend; and I was able to relate and feel the struggle and emotions she was going through. With sympathy; I was able to draw on my past experiences and bring forth those emotions in order to relate to the situation while also giving advice and helping to make this sad experience at least more positive in the outcome.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love; because it stems more so from a negative and vulnerable side that I don't think would be healthy for a loving reltionship.
pcontempt: I would say that this is true because when reflecting on this situation; I felt contempt in that I didn't have to make any actions as a result of my pity; therefore making these two emotions akin to one another.
clove: I would say that compassion is when you love someone or something because of either background information; a specific emotion you saw; or some other characteristic that draws your love in. Compassion has to involve passion.
slove: I believe that in order to feel sympathetic one needs to love the person in which they are caring for.

writepity: There's not necessarily a specific incident that covers this one; but my most significant experiences of pity are around some of the boys who used to bully me when I was younger. I invested a great deal of time and energy in hating them and feeling negatively about them; but after a long time (and my mom telling me for years and years that it wasn't my problem) there was one boy in particular who I came to pity over hating. His name was Jared and he'd treated me like crap from 3rd or 4th grade all the way through 8th grade and even into high school. He teased me; called me names in front of other kids; pushed me around on the playground; and started rumors about me. But somewhere near the end of my 8th grade year and into the first year of high school; I came to understand that his family situation was somewhat unpleasant and that his mother was a very aggressive; unforgiving; unkind person who probably took out a lot of that on him. I came to pity him because he was obviously not in a very good place and did not have the kind of support systems I did; meaning that he already had a great deal of unpleasant stuff to deal with just like me but without the benefit of having someone there to pick up the pieces. Additionally; he would probably struggle with having meaningful relationships for a long time if not the rest of his life because it was clear that the only way he knew how to deal with his negative emotions was by taking that out on other people in hurtful ways. My pity for him was not pleasant or kind.
writecomp: Recently; my friend Gretta was telling me about how her parents tend to treat her concerns about social issues with a great deal of dismissal in favor of their own agenda. When she tried to bring up the topic of violence against women in conversation over dinner; they changed the topic and belittled her concerns; comparing an unwillingness to recycle with violent crimes that had affected people that Gretta and I both know. I felt compassion for her because I understand what it's like to have family trivialize your concerns and I find it unfair that these people she is meant to trust most won't give her the same trust in return. Her situation made me feel like I needed to reach out to her and show her that; even if her parents weren't listening; I was and I understood both her concern and her frustration and disappointment. I told her that I knew the feeling of dismissal and that it was unfair of her parents to treat her and her concerns in such a way; but that it's important not to lose hope and continue to try and make others understand.
writesymp: My friend Holly's parents were divorced a few years ago and the breakup was really hard on her. I am also a child of divorced parents; but my mom and dad split when I was still a baby and I have lived significantly far from my dad from the age of four onwards. I could reach out and try to understand Holly's feelings using the knowledge I already had of how hard it was to feel like you had to pick sides; but I couldn't put myself entirely in her shoes because I did not know what a breakup felt like firsthand. I tried to make sure that she understood I was there for her as much as she needed me to be and that I could talk to her as much as she wanted.
writeempat: One of my closer friends; Sarah; went to a Catholic school for a number of years; like me. Neither of us are still Catholic; but we retain strong ties to some members of our former churches and both have fond memories of the schools we attended; grateful even for the religious education they gave us. Recently; she told me that some changes made by the diocese that oversees her old school would cost some of her favorite teachers their jobs on the grounds of ideology. The regulation stipulated that the school would no longer employ anyone who vocally supported or engaged in "lifestyles" contradictory to the teachings/beliefs of the Church; including support for being homosexual. Both she and I are non-heterosexual; so this struck a chord with both of us and I felt empathy for her; understanding her feelings of betrayal and fear that an environment which could have been so enriching and positive for us even in the face of doctrine could make such exclusionary and harmful decisions. At the time it reminded me of when my own former school made some similar changes; laying off some of our best teachers on the grounds of their religion (prior to this; it had been common to have Protestant teachers; but the new Bishop didn't agree). I told Sarah that I understood how unfair and frightening something like that could be and that I would be there to listen and talk about it as much as she needed.
plove: I would not call pity love.
pcontempt: Yes. Pity is a kind of sympathy that involves the pitier putting themselves above the person they pity. It is a self-congratulatory form of compassion that is often accompanied by feelings of disgust or distaste.
clove: Compassion would be a love that focuses on striving to understand and reach out.
slove: Sympathy is a kind of love based in consideration and on listening.
elove: I would call it a giving or caring love.

writepity: One time; a friend and I were going to the movies together. I do not have a car; so he was driving us. On the way there; we hit an enormous pothole that literally destroyed both of the tires on the right side of his car. We pulled into a nearby parking lot and we could hear and see all of the air pouring out of the tires. He was swearing a lot. He tried to call AAA; which; ironically; his father works for; but they said that his card was inactive. We eventually found someone who used their information to call them for us and have a tow truck sent to get us. We had to wait for the tow truck for several hours; since so many other people had hit the pothole at the same time and also had to call AAA. As he was finally getting into the truck to be taken to the tire store; his pants ripped. Not to mention he was very worried about getting his car fixed on time; because he had to drive to court the next day because he got caught drinking underage. I didn't know what to say except that I was sorry. I didn't know how to help; but I felt a lot of pity for my friend because that was so many lousy things to have happen at once. I also felt kind of sorry for myself; though; because I really wanted to see the movie. And I felt very angry at AAA because they knew we were stranded but refused to help us out without a valid card; I know it is business; but it was still frustrating.
writetende: I have a friend who has consistently struggled with emotional instability issues. We met recently; but had no trouble becoming close with each other because I have also struggled with similar issues throughout my life. There was one evening when I was over at his apartment and he and his roommates had some guests over who were drinking and being very loud. I could tell from the moment I came over that he was in a lousy mood; but when the guests started drinking I could see that he was struggling with handling his emotions and keeping his composure in the situation. Although my attempts felt worthless; I tried my best to convey tenderness; patience; and understanding to him so that he; if nothing else; would not feel any worse that evening. I did not feel as though I could truly help him feel better; but again; the tenderness I attempted to communicate to him was in an effort to not let his mood get any worse.
writecomp: When I first met my boyfriend; we obviously took a lot of time to get to know each other. I came from a very broken and disruptive family. His experiences were by no means identical to mine; but I feel very compassionate toward him when he told me about his older brother being out of the house and feeling like he had no one to turn to when his parents were fighting. I also have a significantly older brother; and although his parents worked through the issues they were going through and mine did not; I definitely felt compassionate because I know first hand that witnessing people that you care about fight is something that can be really emotionally painful. I really just told him; then; about my personal experiences and told him specifically about my own experiences that were kind of similar.
writesymp: My mother has been going through a very difficult time lately. She is battling numerous health issues and is trying her hardest; but is unfortunately mostly unsuccessful; to find medical care professionals to help her through at least some of these issues; some of which have been plaguing her for years; some of which are more recent. She has been travelling a lot; in great pain; trying to find doctors to help with disappointing results. Unfortunately; on top of all of this happening; last month her mother died. She and her little sister are the only surviving members of their six-person immediate family; so my mother had to fly out to her hometown and clean out her mother's apartment and decide what to keep; store; and get rid of. I saw her for a few days over my spring break; and I felt an extreme; but also kind of hopeless and helpless sympathy for her. I felt so; so sad for everything that she was going through and wanted so badly to be there for her and help her through things. I believe that she realized that I was available to be her support system; but I think that the issues are that her problems are so much more than anything I could truly help her with. I think she appreciated my sympathy; but did not know what to do with it.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I think pity is a much "rougher" form of sympathy; but I don't think it is as "negative" as contempt. The way I see pity; it still has an element of care and understanding to it.
tfeltother: 1. Self-consciousness (that his bad mood was due to my actions) / 2. Worry / 3. Frustration
tlove: I think that love must have tenderness as an aspect for it to be a successful and healthy relationship; but I do not think that tenderness on its own is a kind of love.
clove: I would not call compassion a type of love.
slove: I would not call sympathy a type of love; but I do think that it is the most intimate of all of these nouns presented in this study.

writetende: I felt tenderness for my best friend; when she lost her father to cancer. She was very close to her father; and I knew this was a sad time for her. I felt like I had to be careful about what i said; or did. I didn't want to set her off into a frenzy of cries. I had to make sure to keep in mind of her emotions; and feelings; and be there for her any way she needed. I wanted to be a good friend; and look out for her.
writecomp: I felt compassion for my ex-boyfriend when his mom moved backed to Michigan. During this time my ex and I were really close ; and He told me multiple times how much he missed his mom; and wanted her to move back to Michigan. They had a really close relationship; so when she moved back; i felt happy and compassionate for him.
writesymp: A time when I felt sympathy for someone; was my cousin; when you she was going through a hard time. My cousin did not grow up in the most stable environment. When I say she didn't grow up in a stable environment; I mean she watched as her mom got beat by her boyfriend; and watched as he put his whole other family in the same; small two bedroom apartment. She watched her mom be mistreated and used; and as an effect of that; her and her mom did not have a close relationship. Well recently my cousin got into an abusive relationship; and she doesn't know how to deal with it; because she is just doing what she saw; and I feel sympathy for her not knowing any better.
writeempat: I felt empathy when a friend of mine broke her ankle. I felt empathy for her; because I watched it happen. I told her not to jump off the bench but she did it anyway and broke her ankle.  i felt empathy for her because; I know it had to hurt; but I couldn't see myself in the same situation.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of sad love. A love where you feel the need to look out after someone.
clove: If compassion was a type of love it would be a happy type of love.
slove: Sympathy is not a kind of love.
elove: Empathy is not a kind of love.

writepity: Best example of when I felt pity for someone was when my brother was hospitalized for a long period of time when he was 13 or so years old. Had to visit him all the time and watch him go through it. He has a lot of serious allergies and his body rejects a lot of things that we would take for granted and see as harmless. I felt kind of helpless in the situation; and still have a lack of trust for healthcare professionals due to some misdiagnosises that were involved. I thought about the truths behind the statements that modern healthcare is a business; and institutionalized to extremes that only focus on the finances and quantity of care. Procedures are completed as quickly as possible and in large volumes to maximize profit.  /  / Thats all I was thinking about; while wishing I could take his place.
writetende: I've never felt tenderness toward anyone; besides my parents. Mostly my mother. I only felt this way when there was something else tragic going on in our lives that brought us closer together (father being in hospital; death of relative; etc.). /  / The emotions that we are being testing about in this study; while I said they are all different; are emotions that come about largely together in groups. I think that in the situations I'm recalling; tenderness was just a feeling of sensitivity. I was aware that my mother and I were both emotionally sensitive during these times; and we wanted to protect eachothers emotions from being disrupted too badly.
writecomp: Compassion in my mind is just an idea; it is a much less concrete word than the others we have encountered so far in this study. I don't think that I have ever necessarily felt compassion for someone. I have felt pity; sympathy; and empathy; but never consciously realized that I was feeling compassion. I think that compassion is just a filler word that people use as a substitute for the other words we are considering. That's not to say that they should be grouped together; because again; I don't think the word has any merit or direct translation to a concrete feeling. Then again; people tell me I am pretty stoic and lack basic human emotions.
writesymp: I have an older sister that dated an asshole for a solid 5 years or so. When they split; my sister was devistated; and had a hard time with it. Being the only sibling around her age; she came to me for a lot of the support she needed; and talked to me about it often. I haven't dated much through school or my lifetime; I prefer to mess around until my life as a professional adult and actual contributor to society settles down. I didn't feel empathy for her because I've never met a girl that I had a significant emotional attachment to. I more felt sympathy toward her only because of the way she described the rough process of letting go. The only thing I did for her was listened; and reminded her of the tell-tale signs that he wasn't a real winner (he peed sitting down).  /  / I also shared with her my (kind of grave and dark) views on dating and relationships. I don't think I have an easy time getting attached to people because every characteristic you find and come to 'love' in someone can be easily found in other people you meet in your every day life.
writeempat: Cannot recall a specific experience of feeling empathy for someone. Can only recall times when I watched someone go through something that I went through that was difficult physically or mentally; such as work or school. I only observed how they reacted and went through the process; but didn't have any emotional connection with them.
plove: Pity again is not the same thing as love. Love is not an emotion but a need and reaction to extreme positive emotions you feel over a period of time. Pity is feeling upset about a situation that you witness someone else experiencing.
pcontempt: Not true.
tlove: It is not love. It is acting on an awareness; due to caring about someone.
clove: No; not love. Love is a fake idea we have created to describe the emotional attachments we develope to people and objects. It can be fabricated between any two things.
slove: Not love.
elove: I don't think that empathy is a type of love. I don't think that love is an emotion; either. I think it is an attachment to something to the point of needing it to keep your other emotions in balance. Empathy is an emotion; not an infatuation.

writepity: During a math exam in my high school. I had already finished my exam and knew I was gauranteed an A in the advanced calculus class because of my hard work and dedication. However; my girlfriend on the other hand was on the bridge between an A or a B ; meaning she desperately needed an A on that final particular exam to get an A in the overall class. I finsihed my exam early as stated above; and my girlfriend has sat behind me; as she usuall sat near me during exams so I can help her out. Except this time I saw she was struggling to succeed and I knew that was stressing out which made things only worse for her and I knew if this kept up she would ruin her chances of getting an A in the class but also maybe even getting a poor grade. I lifted up my test from time to time and even rsiked getting cuahg myself from how obvious I was being; even classmates around me saw me and warned me to stop before I got caught. I was even frustrated because I kept on yelling my girlfriends name; Nora; and telling her to simply copy what I wrote down in my exam so she can get the A and move on. However; knowing her she panics at certain situations; she stressed out and the fact that the professor was so near us only made things worse. At that moment it reminded my how calm and strategic I am at these situations and how nervous; stressful and fearful she was. I felt pitty towards her for not copying and landing that solid A on her report card because she was so close.
writetende: A clear example of when I felt tenderness was when my mother came back from a long day at work and by the look of her face I could tell she was exhausted and for some reason it broke my heart to see my mother working that hard just so she could provide for us and secure a successful future for her kids. Amongst the current fight occuring between me and my siblings; two older sisters; I immediately stopped for the sake of my mothers tiresome day and decided to do it for her so she could have the rest she desrves. At that  moment I felt tenderness towards my  mother.
writecomp: A time when I felt compassion was for my junior year high school teacher for the Albanian class; Teuta Kafexholli. She was explaining the hard work she had been through that resulted in her PHD and it was really emotional for me because she had always been one of my favorite teachers due to her affectionate and lovable character. While she explained the difficulties in her journey towards attaining her PhD; she was still expressing a great deal of passion towards the subject and how she was in complete awe during her research and something she enjoyed rather then let bring her down. At that moment; I felt compassion towards her character and the influential person that she was.
writesymp: Duing my english class in junior year of high school at the American School of Kosovo. By far not only the most inflential teacher of my life; but also one of the most inlfuential person in general in my life. Joseph Day was an unusual character; and strange in his ways; but by far something inspiring amongst humanity. His words of wisdom had the ability to rapidly change your mood and make you questions the things in life you thought were most certain. One day in class we were being so loud and annoying; as usual in Joe Day's class becuase of the excess freedom he gave us to express ourselves but that we abused; and he tried to gain our attention for a song he was going to play with a guitar about the love of his life who was far away from him physically but so near the plummet of his heart. At that moment; as he sang his heart out on his feelings for the mystery women; I felt sympathy towards Joe Day...why couldn't he be reunited with his loved one.
plove: A type of love when you recognize one's pain; sadness or misfortunes and allow it to affect you.
pcontempt: No clue.
tlove: A respectful love that recognizes one's intentions and efforts.
clove: A sincere friendly love that consists of purely good intentions and recognition.
slove: A type of love that recognizes someone's inner emotions and deeper strenghts.
elove: Empathy is a type of love of acuqatance/

writepity: When my best friend Saundra's grandmother had died; I felt an overwhelming sense of pity for Saundra. Her grandmother had been a huge role model for her. She was witty; smart; artistic; and creative; and Saundra knew no one else like her. She had spent a lot of time in Saundra's house right up until she died. All of Saundra's friends including me attended the funeral and Shiva. During the service for the funeral; I felt a lot of pity for the loss of such an inspiring figure in my friends lives. Although I felt as if I could relate and had a lot of empathy for her family as I too have lost grand-parents; I still felt a marked distance towards her family and what they were going through. I wanted to be there for Saundra as much as a I could so that she knew there were people who could; or who could try to understand her from outside her family. I went with Saundra during the Shiva on a walk and talked with her as I did under normal circumstances; but of course keeping in mind her grave loss.
writetende: I felt tenderness when my little brother was having problems at school because kids were bullying him. Karl is a red-head and many of his friends wouldnt stop making fun of him. I felt a sense to protect him as well as anger for the kid who were bullying him. I felt I had a duty to protect my brother. I told him the kids didn't matter and they were jealous.
writecomp: I felt compassion for when my friend Ryan had a health condition she was really afraid of. She was awaiting results and the anticipation was frightening her. I tried to understand that my concerns and what I was feeling which was worry of not getting my homework done was not of utmost importance. I tried to help her through the situation by distracting her and talking to her about other things.
writesymp: I felt sympathy when my friend Jake didn't get accepted to his top choice school. Jake wanted to go to Princeton and the amount of effort he put into everything he did that could be related to an acceptance was unbelievable. I had never seen someone work so hard; and I felt this was a valuable virtue. I felt a kind of hopelessness (because I too was awaiting  acceptances). I first gave Jake a lot of space because I knew he was the type of guy who didn't need my sympathy. As time passed I was able to talk to him about it and make sure he knew everyone was in the same boat and talking about it would help not hurt him
writeempat: I felt empathy when my friend Rhea was feeling especially guilty at getting angry at her elder relatives who  she was supposed to be showing a lot of respect for. Rhea is from a conservative Jain family and leads an incredibly modern and Western lifestyle compared to her other cousins; grandparents; aunts and uncles. When they come to visit she has difficulty connecting with them as they find her day-to-day actions sometimes rude. Rhea likes to fill up her days with activities and when she is home; she is not always completely invested in her relatives need to converse.  /  / I felt empathy because I too come from a family who has long standing traditional values and there can often be a disconnect between old generations and new generations that are further hindered  by a language barrier. It's difficult to express what we're feeling especially with this language barrier as you feel you must uphold certain values to be apart of that community. /  / I talked to Rhea; comparing our different ethnic backgrounds as we bonded over how difficult it can be to keep a good relationship with people who have become so different from.
plove: If you can act on the pity you feel in amorous ways I think it can constitute love
pcontempt: Pity can be contempt if you look down on people with a feeling of superiority and if you despise people who are inferior to you
tlove: tenderness is like love in that you feel a deep connection for someone
cfeltother: 1. Understanding / 2. I was doing the right thing / 3. Helpfulness
clove: Compassion is like love because you express a deep level of kindness to someone
slove: Love based on a profound understanding of someone else.
elove: Empathy is a kind of love in that people can set aside judgments and appreciate a similiar kind of feeling to you. Love is very much related to how much you can understand that person.

writepity: One of my friend's mother recently passed away in a car accident. This friend had no father and therefore had to leave school and go back home to take care of his family. He was a senior and was only a few months short of graduating. I felt grief over his loss and was sad that he might not be able to finish his university degree because of his circumstances. I wanted to help support him during this tragic time but he left town before I could see him.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards a new co-worker of mine when we first started working together. He and I had just been assigned a shift together and had never previously worked together. We started talking and realized that we had many common interests and our personalities matched very well. I began to really enjoy my time working with him and thought that we were becoming pretty good friends.
writecomp: I felt compassionate for one of my friends who had been going through a very tough week and eventually broke down and started cutting herself with a razor. At first I was angry with her because she had displayed this behavior in the past and I encouraged her to stop. After the initial anger had settled; I began to talk to her and tried to comfort her. I knew that she was going through a rough time and her sadness sort of made me feel sad too.
writesymp: I felt a bit sympathetic towards one of my friends who had broken up with his girlfriend. They had been dating for a couple of months and seemed like a happy couple. One day however; he seemed a bit down and told me that they had just broken up. I felt sympathetic towards him because I knew how happy he was with her. We talked for a bit and I think that made him feel a bit better.
writeempat: One situation where I felt empathetic towards someone occured when one of my best friends in high school got accepted into a top ranked university. Since he was one of my good friends; I knew how hard he had worked and how dedicated to his school work he was and how much he wanted to go to this unviersity. I had recently been accepted into University of Michigan so I knew the excitement that he was experiencing and that all of his hard work had paid off. I was very happy for him and proud that he had accomplished his goal.
plove: I would not  call pity love
pcontempt: I think that most people do like to be pitied by othersa and don't like to feel contempt
tlove: I would not call tenderness love.
slove: I would not call sympathy a type of love
elove: I would not call empathy love

writepity: There's a guy in one of the clubs I attend. Frankly; he annoys me. He can't stay foucused on a topic in conversation; he interupts people while they're having conversations and doesn't seem to pick up on any kind of social hints. I try to give him the benifit of the doubt an excuse his behavior on the grounds that he doesn't know any better because he's an idiot or is otherwise impaired in the area of person to person comunication. I would have liked in several of these situations to "go away" or "shut up" I didn't because I pity him for his ignorance.
writecomp: I was walking to my car about to leave the city after a conference and I passed by a homeless man named Brad. I don't know how Brad came to be homeless; but it was probably not totally his fault; and I feel like people look down on the homeless and people begging for cash. I remebered that most of the the money I have and most of my possesions I didn't work for. They were given to me. What right did I have to hold back some money from Brad when it wasn't "my" money in the first place.
writesymp: Several of my friends were close to a woman named Joanna; who I did not know personaly. When she died of cancer those friends of course were upset and grieved by her passing. As I did not know her closely; I was more or less unaffected by her death; but I was aware of my friends' sorrows and as such I tried to make myself availible for talking through their emotions and overlooking anything I'd normally be irritated about from them.
writeempat: A friend of mine was going through a point in his life where he was depressed and questioning what he was living for. Having been depressed myself to the point of contemplating suicide; I was immediatly concerned and nervous for my friend because I was able to vividly recall and re-expirence the emotions I felt from that time in my life. Being able to empathize led to the concern.
plove: I do not think pity is a kind of love.
pcontempt: Yes. Pitying someone pre-supposes that you think you are better than them in some way. You pity them because you see them as inferior.
tlove: / I wouldn't call tenderness a "kind" of love; but more of an aspect of love. Specifically part of love that is between people and not as an exaggeration for "like." Tenderness is very similar to gentleness; it is aware of it's ability to be heavy handed in guiding those that it cares for; and as such takes great care when handling the emotions of others.  /  / *I was unable to think of an instance I felt tenderness towards someone which is why I did not write about it. /
clove: Compassion is a kind of love that causes people to act kindly and caringly toward others that goes above and beyond what is considered polite. It almost by deffinition motivates an action to be taken.
slove: I wouldn't call sympathy a kind of love. To me it's normal and politeness more than a deeper emotional connection.
elove: I think love causes people to empathize; not that empathy is love. The people you love you will be able to understand the emotions of more strongly. Beyond that; to empathize is less of a feeling more to mirror or simulate the emotions that someone else is expirencing.

writepity: 1) I time I felt pity for someone was when I was in 7th grade and I saw a kid eating alone at lunch. When I saw this I immediately felt really bad for him and kind of just thought about what he was thinking. / 2) I was feeling sad for him because I could only imagine what it must feel like to be the only one in the cafeteria sitting alone. And I was thinking that I should do something about the situation because I was taught to do the right and kind thing by my parents. / 3) What I wanted to do was sit with him so he didn't feel as lonely. I ended up getting a group of my friends to go sit with him and just try to make his day a little better. When I sat down I made it seem like it wasn't awkward at all; and I just started talking to the kid as if he was a friend of him. I could see him getting comfortable with my friends and me and that made me feel pretty good inside.
writetende: 1) A time I felt tenderness toward someone was a couple years ago when my friend's mother passed away. He was in such a fragile state of mind that I didn't really know what I could say to him.  I just wanted to show him that I was there for him if he needed anything. / 2) Seeing a friend of mine that upset made me pretty upset; as well. I was feeling tender towards his feelings and emotions. I was thinking that I should talk to him a lot to take his mind off of the situation and show he had a friend there for him.  / 3) What I wanted to do was get him to cheer up. I know that sounds ridiculous and impossible for someone in his state; but that is what I wanted to do. What I ended up doing was going to his house almost every day for the next two weeks to hang out with him even though there were other things I would have rather done. When I spoke to him; I didn't mention what was going on at all; because I knew the second I left he would think about his mother again. I was tender towards his feelings in the sense that I watched what I said to him and really just felt unbelievably bad for his situation.
writesymp: 1) The first example that comes to my mind when I think of a time I was sympathetic would be when my friend got his calculus exam score and it was pretty bad. Being in the Ross Business School was something he really wanted to do; and this test grade really hurt his chances. I felt sympathetic towards him becuase I really did feel bad. I was talking to him for a while and telling him it was still possible to get in to the Business School even though I didn't know if that was true. I just remembered back in high school when I felt doing poorly on one of my tests would prevent me from getting into the college of my choice. I remembered how upset I was at the time; but looking back on it now; it was a wake up call and helped me grow as a student. Having this prior experience helped me talk to my friend about his grade and made me feel sympathetic towards him/  / 2) I was feeling really bad for him because he is a good friend of mine. I knew he would do the same thing for me if I was down; so I just tried to stay positive with him. I was thinking what I would be feeling if I were in his shoes; and what someone could say to make me feel better. When I thought of that; I said those words to my friend and I could see some sort of optimism rising in him which made me feel a lot better. / 3) I wanted to let him know that it was still possible for him to be admitted. I didn't want to see him upset or doubting himself; so I stayed up for a while and even got him food to let him know that he had support. I just kept repeating how it's only one test and it's not as big of a deal as he is making it. How I've gone through this before and felt the same way. It's a lot easier to feel sympathy towards someone if you've been in their shoes before.
writeempat: 1)  A time I felt empathetic towards someone was a couple days ago when my friend's phone and computer were stolen. The technology costs a lot of money so I generally just felt bad for him. / 2) I was feeling like there was nothing I could really do for him; and he kind of just had to deal with it himself. I was thinking whether there was something I could do; but not trying to sound selfish; the situation didn't involve me in the slightest and honestly it didn't really need my involvement. / 3) What I wanted to do was buy him a new computer and phone; but I wasn't going to do that because of the money. What I did was going through the legal procedure about his stolen items. What I said was "sorry man; that really sucks. if you need to borrow my computer for an hour or two let me know." That's all I could really do; since my words weren't going to bring his computer and phone back.
plove: I definitely would not call pity a type of love.
pcontempt: I think this is a true statement because if you think of the situation where I felt pity; both words could techinically be used for how I felt.
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love. I think that you are tender to the people you care about. I wouldn say it's the type of love that exists between family members and friends.
slove: I wouldn't call sympathy a kind of love solely because you can feel sympathetic towards almost anyone. But love is really reserved for special people in your heart.
elove: Personally; I look at empathy as sympathy for less important issues; so I would not call it a type of love.

writepity: One time I felt pity for someone was when I would watch a Cross Country race and see the people who finished at the back. I felt bad because at this point because they would start to receive less applause then everyone else and would sometimes even be walking. I never finished in the bottom 10% of a race; although I was not fast; but still seeing these people struggle along at the end was difficult to watch. I wanted to walk away and not be there because it made me uncomfortable but instead I just kept clapping and yelling words of encouragment to my teammates who were in this position.
writecomp: A time I felt compassion for someone was when I was there for my girlfriend when she found out her father passed away. She got a phone call saying that he had died and I was there when she found out so I did my best to help her deal with it. There was little I could say but I was just physically by her side all day giving her someone to cry on and trying to be compassionate to what was evidently an extremely difficult situation. I wanted to talk to her and tell her it would be okay and get her to smile but that was not really feasible because she was so distraught.
writesymp: I felt sympathetic for my Dad when he was watching his father slowly deteriorate due to Alzheimers. I never knew him before the disease so it did not have as profound of an impact on me but I saw what it did to my dad and felt very sympathetic for him that he had to go through such a difficult experience. I would just try and be there for him when it going on and let him know even though his dad didnt remember him I remembered and loved mine.
writeempat: I often empathize with a  person who has struggled on an exam a friend of mine did not do well on a recent test and I feel for them in this situation becasue i have been there myself. Doing well always feels nice but when you do bad it feels ten times worse and I can really put myself in their shoes. I usually just try and tell them that they can turn it around and improve and tackle the next test. And I try and study with them if we are in the same class.
plove: Not a kind of love
pcontempt: It is in that you are somewhat looking down on someone.
clove: I think love and compassion can be connected in that your compassion can often go a lot further if it is directed towards someone you love.
slove: I do think love and sympathy can be connected because to really sympathize i think you need to care about someone.
elove: I dont believe empathy is a kind of love because you can be empathetic to a homeless man on the street but not love him; it is more about being a good person and understanding the difficulties of another person.

writepity: I felt pity for my ex-girlfriend; because she still had feelings for me and I had no feelings for her anymore. I felt pity because I realized that she was hurting and there was nothing anyone could do about it. I felt pity because she was sad and helpless about it while I was not sad. I wished for a way to help her; but there was no way. It was sad to see her all sad like that; but there wasn't any way to help and three was no way to redo anything; so she remained sad.
writecomp: I feel compassion for my girlfriend whenever I see her. I have a genuine desire to make her happy and to see her smile. I want to cheer her up when she's unhappy and bring her even happier when she's happy. I want to share with her my love and happiness and compassion so that she too can share hers. I feel sad when she is sad and I feel happy when she is happy. When I'm with her I'm not fully happy until she is as well. I feel like compassion is feeling all of the highs and lows that someone else is feeling
writesymp: A good situation of me feeling sympathy for someone is when my roomate was sick. He was very ill and was in bed for a few days straight. I felt sympathy for him because I was once in the same situation and knew how he felt; so I could relate to him and his feeling of helplessness. I remembered various time of when I myself was sick and used these memories to conjure sympathy for my roomate and help him out in whatever ways I could. I wished there was an immediate way for him to get better but since that wasn't possible; I felt sympathy because I was once inn the same situation as him.
plove: I would not call pity love under any means
pcontempt: I think this is true to some degree because you have to dislike someone at least a little bit. You can never really feel pity for someone you love and care about
clove: I feel like you cannpt have compassion without love because compassion is a direct form of love. If you don't love someone then you can only feel sympathy or pity or empathy for them. Compassion requires a certain amount of tenderness and love to be true compassion
slove: Sympathy can be a type of love if youn feel it for someone that you genuinely love and care about; but if it isn't it's hard for me to say that it is a form of love

writetende: I don't typically think of tenderness as an emotion; but as a trait that someone can possess.  I think of tenderness as a synonym with gentleness.    / 1) When my roomate was having a panic attack because he thought he failed a psych quiz I felt tenderness.  / 2.) I was feeling bad for him and  I wasn't sure what to say as I'd never had a panic attack myself.  I didn't share in his emotion but I wished that I could so I could know what to do. / 3.) I tried to calm him down and soothe him with words of reassurance; downplaying the seriousness of the quiz; and ensuring him he can still suceed in the course.  I stepped carefully over my words so I didn't say anything that would make it worse.
writecomp: 1.) When I visited Atlanta for a mission trip last year I felt compassion for the homeless people  I came into contact with.   / 2.) I felt deep sadness for them and although I wasn't going through a similar situation wanted to help them in any way I could.  I felt the need to connect with them so I could understand their situation better and give them an outlet out of their situation; if only for a moment. / 3.) I gave some of the homeless people money and helped cook and serve them breakfast and occasionally lunch on a daily basis.  I thought the biggest thing I could do is just talk to them and give them my full attention when they were telling me their stories.  I wanted them to feel like normal human beings; not like they were homeless.   /
writesymp: 1.) I felt sympathy for my friend when his dog died.   / 2.) I had gone through a similar situation recently so I felt connected to him based on the shared situation.  / 3.) I wanted to console him and make sure he was doing ok.  I tried to get his mind off the situation as much as possible so he could get over the death and get back to living life normally.
tlove: Tenderness is the feeling of love without the power to do anything for someone; no power to act on it.
clove: Love on a human level where you feel a connectedness with them based on shared characteristics despite differing situations and a difficult circumstance.  It is the type of love you feel for all others being expressed as you feel like you could easily be in their shoes with different circumstances.
slove: Sympathy is love for someone that you care about and know you can affect positively because you have went through or are going through similar circumstances.  It's a connectedness based on similar experiences.

writepity: One of my friends had been studying for her chemisty final for weeks and was very nervous about it. She's chemisty major so she felt extra pressure to perform well on the exam and in the class. It seemed like she was well prepared and I had quizzed her several times and she had done pretty well. When the exam finally happened she told me afterwards that she wasn't confident about the answers to any of the questions and had pretty much panicked during the exam. I kind of blew this off and just told her that it probably went just fine and she would just have to wait until the results came out. Eventually she got her grade back and ended up getting a D. She was really upset and I felt sorry for her. There wasn't much I could say to put a positive spin on it and I just had to watch her be miserable. I know how much it sucks to get a bad grade and watching her go through it made me just hope she would get over it soon.
writetende: A family friend of ours had a child recently and after about a month I got to see the new family. They came over to our house one afternoon and I was really excited to see the new baby and to see him with his child. He was a guy I had known for years and was always ablw to see as a future father. Finally seeing him with his baby was absolutely adorable and I was so proud of him. He looked exhausted and happy and I couldn't help but get caught up in all of the emotions.
writecomp: When my sister broke up with her boyfriend she was very distraught even though it had been her decision. I picked her up from school and she had obviously been crying and was still very upset. I was a little startled at first because I never see her so overly upset but that was part of what made me the most concerned. I immediately asked her what had happened and let her just talk about it as much or as little as she wated to. We got home and she quickly disappeared to her room. At the time; we were on the same crew team so when it was amost time for practice I went up to check on her. She was still just as upset and so I sat with her and hugged her and rubbed her back to calm her down. I wanted to do anything that would help her feel better but in the situation there wasn't a lot I could do. She didn't want to go to practice or in public so I let her convince me to tell our coach that she was sick and wouldn't be at practice that say. Even though I was a captain and almost felt guilty about making an excuse for her; I wanted to protect her and give her time and space to do what she needed to do. I did this because I felt compassionate towards her and that made me want to help her.
writesymp: I had a friend who was an excellent rower. She was working with the Junior National Development Team during the summer and was looking at getting recruited by colleges. Unfortunately; just in her senior year; she started having horrible migranes and was getting sick pretty regularly. We raced in a double together during the spring and were winning every event we entered. Until we got to regionals. We were expecting to perform just as well as we had been but when we got into the semifinal it turned out we had the fastest three boats in our semi and only three went through to finals. We finished 4th by just over a second but would have come in 1st in the other heat. When we got off the water we put our boat away and were so upset that we left our whole team and cried behind the bathroom for a solid 20 minutes. It was horrible watching our hard work not pay off or even be given a chance because of something random like the lane draw. It was even worse to see her not succeed in her last chance at regionals.
writeempat: When I was rowing in high school; I had a teammate who had unprotected sex and was really worried about getting pregnant. She was talking to several other girls on the team and trying to figure out how to get Plan B. At the time I felt sorry for her and could completely understand why she was so panicked and need to treat this as an emergency. However; I also was a bit disappointed about how she got herself into the situation in the first place. I was entirely willing to help her get everything sorted out but I didn't know what to say to make her calm down. I didn't want to make the situation seem like it wasn't a big deal or like it was totally ok that this had happened. In the end; another girl took her to get Plan B and I din't have to be directly involved in any way.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: In some cases pity may be related to contempt but pity has a broader application.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love where our are proud of someone or happy for them.
clove: A kind of love where you are invested in the other person's well being.
slove: Sympathy would be a kind of love where you relate to the person you feel sympathetic towards and can understand what they are going through.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writetende: When I was babysitting a child; I felt tenderness towards that child.  Since the child was young; I didn't want to do anything that could potentially damage him.  I was afraid that if I acted differently; the child would become worse off.  So what I did; I was gentle and passive yet firm when interacting with the child.
writesymp: My mom's friend is trying to adopt two children; one that is three years old and another that is one year old.  The reason for the adoption of those specific children is because they grew up in a very poor living environment.  The birth mother was addicted to cocaine and had an alcohol problem.  She was very neglectful and often left the children home alone with a complete stranger to the children or with a child that is seven years old.  I felt sympathetic because I felt sorry for them but I could not completely understand what they are going through since I never experienced that in my life.  I wanted to provide support for the family that wanted to adopt them and I did give them support and helped them by being a good reference.  I told them they had to get the children no matter what it takes.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards my brother when his girlfriend had an affair on him.  He was deeply in love with her but she did not feel the same way.  So instead of ending it; she decided to go for another person outside the relationship while being in one with my brother.  I was empathetic because I was in a similar situation with my previous relationship.  So I understand what he was going through and I wanted to comfort him and show him that it will be ok and not all of his relationships will be like that.  During that time; I was sorry for him and I wanted him to be better emotionally.
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love because it is showing concern and the person showing tenderness wants to take care of the person they care about and help improve their well being.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love since sympathy is showing concern for someone's situation without having a complete understanding since the one showing sympathy did not directly experience the situation
elove: I would not say empathy is a kind of love because it is when you understand what someone is going through because the person feeling empathetic went through a very similar situation.

writepity: When I feel pity I feel bad for someone and it is usually when someone does something that gets them in a bad place and is self induced. One girl I know has no self esteem so she sleeps around with so many guys to reassure herself that she is pretty. I pity her because what she is doing is not good and I feel bad because she's trying to deal with a greater problem.
writetende: When my Dad's dad died I felt tenderness for him immediately after it happened because he was very fragile and vulnerable. He cried and I never see him cry.
writecomp: When I was in Lima; Peru I felt compassion towards the little children who were much less fortunate than I was. I taught them how to brush their teeth and gave them toothbrushes because they didn't have any.
writesymp: When my best friend and I both failed our chem test I felt sympathy towards her when I was trying to comfort her because I could relate and we were both in it together.
writeempat: The other day a woman came to give a talk about her mother and best friend both dying of cancer in order to raise money for her foundation. It was extremely sad and emotional and many of us started crying. I felt empathy towards her because I felt sad and and wanted to show her that I cared and was concerned. However; I have never experienced a close family member or friend dying of cancer so I couldn't relate to her on the same level. We just showed our support for her cause and comforted her the best we could.
plove: I wouldn't call pity love. For me it is recognizing a sad situation and expressing that.
tlove: a gentle and caring love
cfeltother: 1. I felt bad for these people  / 2.  / 3.
clove: this love is kindness and selflessness
slove: An understanding love
elove: a caring love and nurtures someone or something

writepity: I felt pity for the Navy Seals who were in the situation that the movie 'Lone Survivor' was based on. They tried to do the right thing (spare the kid); but instead got attacked by terrorists. They were more than capable of handling normal dangerous situations; but horribly evil people overwhelmed them and killed them. So even though they had the skills to do the right thing and deal with the consequences that would normally follow; they got extremely unlucky and were brutally killed for pretty much no reason whatsoever.
writetende: I brought my brother some water when he was sick.
writecomp: I feel compassion towards my family in general. I don't feel like there is any one specific circumstance in which I was significantly more or less compassionate.
writesymp: A friend of our family died. I felt sympathy towards the rest of his family. I thought it was unfortunate that he (the father) died so young; leaving his kids without a father and wife without a husband at such a young age.
writeempat: My roommate took a difficult exam. I could relate to how he was feeling; but I did not really care too much.
plove: I would not call pity a type of love
pcontempt: Pity is not akin to contempt. I don't feel any contempt towards Navy Seals who died because they tried to be honorable and instead got brutally killed.
tlove: Tenderness would not be a type of love. Tenderness would be a product of love.
clove: Compassion is a product of love
slove: I would not call sympathy a type of love
elove: Empathy is not a type of love

writepity: Pity is what I feel when I hear about someone who went drunk driving. They could have an alcohol problem that caused this or just be plain stupid but either way I feel a disgusting sadness for them. Sadness that they cannot get counseling to get over their addiction. Sadness and disgust that they think that their life is more important than others on the road. I pity them and their small brain. I have no respect for them. I cannot relate to them because I think they are too selfish and too out of control with their life. I do not generally like the people I feel this pity towards.
writetende: One day during summer football practice; my friend Matt injured his thumb. I know that is not a big deal or anything; however he still needed surgery and would be out the first couple weeks of the season. I went over to comfort him and I felt a tenderness towards him. I knew he was upset so I tried to keep the conversation lighthearted and just tried to make him feel better. It was not something that was a huge deal but I knew it made him upset that he could not begin the season with the team; all because of a little thumb. I feel sorry for him; but not like sympathy because I knew the sadness he had would be a very temporary thing.
writecomp: This is what I feel for little children with fatal illnesses or who do not have enough food it eat. They have no control over the situation and I feel like I should help them. I feel as though they do not have control; but since I have enough to eat I should have some control. I feel bad; and an obligation towards them. An obligation to help them.
writesymp: I knew what my friend Jenna was going through when her Grandma dies of cancer. Mine had passed away previously and we were very close; so knew what it was like to feel what she was feeling. I knew how it effected her; and I felt like a could really be there for her because I had experienced it myself.
writeempat: Empathy is when you feel sorrow for someone; but you have never experienced this kind of sorrow yourself. When my best friend's mother died of cancer; I felt empathy for her in her situation; but I truly did not understand the sorrow she was going through. I felt sad; I knew her mother very well; however not in the same way that she did. Her emotions were deeper than mine could ever be; and unless my mom died I could not feel these same type of emotions. Because my emotion couldn't really relate to her emotion I consider it empathy.
plove: No it is not love
pcontempt: Yes; because having contempt for something is having disapproval of the situation (I believe) and if this is true then they are the same emotion
tlove: It would be a kind of love; tenderness is taking care of someone when they are vulnerable; and making them feel better. This is not something you would do for someone if you disliked them. It is an act of love.
clove: It is not a love you have for someone you know; but a love you have because you believe every human deserves love.
slove: It may not be love; but you generally understand them
elove: It would be love; because even though you never want to be in their situation you in an extent wish you were so you could sympathize with them
