I felt so much love and compassion for him as well as relieved that he handled the pressure the way he did.
writesymp: When my twin brother and I were both around 7 years old; my brother got knocked off the diving board by a dog and hit his chin on the side of the pool. He unfortunately had to get stitches. While at the time I didn't truly know what happened because I was so young; looking back at it now I feel bad that he had to get stitches; even though it wasn't my fault or his fault. I felt sympathy for him because I didn't want him to have to go through that experience. I felt like I needed to help him get better; yet there was nothing really I could do to improve his situation.
plove: I would not consider pity to be love; because it is more of a feeling about a particular situation more than a feeling toward a person.
pcontempt: If contempt can be seen as a positive feeling; then yes; it could be true.
tlove: I would say it is a very moderate kind of love; and a moderate kind of passion; not a burning desire like love can be;
cfeltother: 1. love / 2. competitiveness and drive / 3. i really really wanted to see him succeed on his own
clove: I think it is a kind of love where you want to see the other person succeeed but you also want them to succeed to make you yourself feel better as well.
slove: Sympathy would be a kind of love in which you want to see the other person succeed. It could be between anyone; but typically I think about it as being between siblings; family members; or best friends; not typically in a partner or love relationship.

writepity: 1) After taking this survey I feel that pity is the same as the sympathetic emotion. Refer to the sympathetic emotion response.
writetende: 1) Tenderness to me relates to someone who is very unable to take care of themselves and is vulnerable to many things. A very good friend of mine; as well as an uncle; have a disease called muscular distrophy (spelling?). These two people have to be in wheelchairs from now until the end of their lives (which is a predicted 30-40 years). These two people will need constant care for the rest of their life and will always be vulnerable to things that many people are not. /  / 2) I feel a lot of sympathy; compassion; and grievance for the two friends; and wish there was more that I could do. /  / 3) I want to be able to make their diseases go away; however; I know I probably can't. I have participated in multiple fundraisers for the muscular d. campaign in hopes for better research and headway with new medications.
writecomp: 1) Now that I take this survey I find that compassion and sympathy are very similar. The example I had for sympathy relates to this emotion as well. I felt compassion for the family who lost their mother; and for the husband; his wife. /  / 2) I was feeling very sad and I grieved a lot. I was thinking that no one should ever have to endure a similar situation to theirs'. /  / 3) I wanted to be able to cure cancer; but I knew I couldn't. (Refer to the other response)
writesymp: 1) A close friend of mine passed away recently. Her husband works for my dad and is how I know him and knew her. She experienced a slow death from a terrible cancer; and I saw first hand how traumatic it was for both of them; as well as their two children; who are also close friends of mine.  /  / 2) I was feeling a lot of grief and sorrow; but what I could not stop thinking about was how much worse it had to have been for their family. I realized I would never be able to feel what they were feeling unless I was in a similar situation. I wouldn't wish the experience they had on even my worst enemy and had much sympathy for their family. /  / 3) I wanted to be able to make the cancer go away even though I couldn't. My family; and my fathers companies; set up a fund for their family and tried to raise as much money as possible. I had a close talk with the father (her husband) and it was very hard to sit there and listen because there was so much pain in his voice. I said as much as I could to make him feel better but I knew nothing would make him feel better. /
writeempat: 1) Just the other day a friend of mine came up and told me how much he was worrying because he just bombed a calc 3 test. I was able to relate to the situation because in the previous semester I had bombed a calc 3 test aswell. /  / 2) When I bombed the test I was feeling very similar to him; but after time had passed I no longer felt the same way. I tried to reassure him that it would be ok and his grades would work out in the end to how he would want them to be. /  / 3) What I wanted to do was to be able to make his grade better; however; I couldn't. I told him that everything would be ok and told him that if he ever needed help studying I would be there to help.
pfeltother: 1. I thought that pity is the same thing as sympathy; so experimenter had me omit this question. / 2.  / 3.
plove: I think pity is also a degree of caring.
pcontempt: I am not sure what akin means but I am going to assume it means synonymous. I don't think this is true.
tlove: again a degree of caring.
clove: I think of it as a degree of caring.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love; but rather a degree of caring.
elove: No; again; a degree of caring.

writepity: 1) A student had gotten in trouble because they didn't do any of their assigned work /  / 2) I felt like it was their fault; and they should have used a planner or aid to remind them of the assigned work /  / 3) I wanted to give them advice on how to remember assignments better for the future; but I ended up not doing or saying anything to them
writetende: 1) Someone was sitting up leaning against a wall and crying. /  / 2) I was feeling bad that they were sad about something; and thinking about how I could try and console them. /  / 3) I wanted to go sit down next to them and talk out whatever problem they were having; but I ended up just walking past them
writecomp: 1) A friend of mine's grandma died /  / 2) I was sad for them because they were very close to their grandmother /  / 3) I wanted a did console them; and talked about it with them for a while. I discussed good and funny times they had with their grandma.
writesymp: 1) A student was walking down the diag; and slid on the ice. They fell; and I felt sympathy because I've fallen down and hurt myself as well. /  / 2) I was feeling sad that they hurt themselves; and was thinking how I could help them up. /  / 3) I wanted to go over; help them up; and talk to them saying it might be embarrassing but its okay. I also wanted to tell them about the time that I fell; and hurt myself on campus. All I actually had time to do was to help them up; and ask if they were okay.
writeempat: 1) A student got back their essay paper; and received a bad grade. /  / 2) I was feeling sorry for them since it seemed like they had put a lot of work into their paper. /  / 3) I wanted to offer suggestions on how they could improve their next paper. What I did was just tell them that it's fine and the paper is only worth a small percentage of the total grade. /
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love. It seems like its usually felt towards people you don't know that well - which isn't usually the people you tend to love.
pcontempt: I don't think that is true. I think that when you feel contempt towards something that you really don't like it; or even hate it. Pity is more just feeling sorry about something that happened even if it was their fault.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love
clove: I would not call compassion a kind of love
slove: Sympathy is the kind of love that people have for others in general. Not the same kind of love that they have for someone they know really well.
elove: I don't really think empathy is a kind of love

writetende: About a week after my brother had surgery on his knee; I went to go visit him at my parents' house.  He was lying on the couch in the living room; where he was stationed most of the time because he couldn't get up on his own.  Whenever he wanted something; someone was always there to get it for him.  I felt kind of annoyed; because usually; when someone does something for him; it is because he is too lazy to do it himself.  However; this time was different; because was physically incapable of getting anything himself; and I felt kind of bad. /  / Later; when I was sitting next to him and my parents were upstairs; Matthew said he had to go to the bathroom.  I didn't know what to do--was I supposed to help him get up?  Was I supposed to help him go to the bathroom?  Matthew said that he could go to the bathroom himself; he just needed me to wrap his leg and help him up.  I was nervous at doing so; not wanting to hurt the brother who I deeply cared about; but I was able to put my fears aside and help him painlessly.
writecomp: When I first watched the move "Freedom Writers;" I felt compassion for the students.  They were shifted around from class to class so much because they were considered "dumb" and no one wanted to teach them; and that made me feel badly; and even a little bit angry.  I have never been in a situation like that; but I can understand what the students were feeling.  Because they weren't the most intelligent people; because no one seemed to care about them; and because of the horrible things they had to face in their home environments; the students just didn't care.  I really felt for them and wanted to help them; so I was proud to see the teacher; Erin Gruwell; really get through to the students and made them enjoy learning.  It made me want to be like Erin Gruwell and help other students in similar situations.
writesymp: When I was in New York City; I saw a woman wearing a garbage back on the streets of Time Square.  She was walking around. asking for money; but no one gave any to her.  I at first felt scared; because I had never seen someone like that on the streets before; but I also felt sad.  I didn't understand why no one would help her and how she got herself into that situation.  I started to cry and told my mom how I was feeling.  I asked her why that had happened; and she told me that she didn't know; some people are just not as lucky financially as we are.  Why didn't she ask her family for help?  Well; sometimes; people's pride keeps them from accepting help from others. /  / I was only five at the time; so I didn't totally understand; thinking that everyone should have the life that I did; but now; I know that that's not the way the world works.  I often hate the lack of justice there is; but that's how it is.
tlove: It would be kind and caring kind of love
clove: Compassion is an understanding empowering kind of love
slove: Sympathy is not quite a love; it is more of a sadness felt for someone in trouble.

writepity: My aunt has endured several struggles in middle age; including an abusive marriage;  extreme weight gain; and huge financial losses.  I am sympathetic for her about the abusive marriage because I know she did not deserve it.  But when I think about her health and near bankruptcy; I feel pity.  I believe that she had the power to prevent the weight gain; the power to obtain a college degree to get a better paying job (she dropped out of college and then my parents gave her money to take online courses later); and the power to be thriftier with money. / I don't enjoy pity because I feel a bit condescending.  I feel as though I'm judging her lifestyle and found flaws with it.  I associate pity with frustration because I think the 'victim' had the ability to prevent the situation.
writecomp: I feel compassion when I am sympathetic and also feel as though I have a vital role in caring for the person affected.  For example; a lot of my friends are very academically inclined and can easily get upset if they think they did badly on a test.  I try my best to comfort them; and I am sympathetic because I understand what situation they're in.  I wish that I could console them and just help them move on to achieve greater things.
writesymp: My mother is a registered nurse; and the tales of her work experiences always find a way into my family's dinner conversations.  Most of her patients were involved in horrific accidents and now have severe and permanent brain damage and/or spinal cord injuries.  I remember telling my mom that some of their permanent injuries just "weren't fair."I find that I feel the most sympathetic whenever I hear about a patient's story in which the patient was not at fault.  Freak accidents; such as car crashes caused by another drunk driver; make me feel the most sympathetic.  The differentiation between pity and sympathy is clear to me: I feel pity whenever I feel as though the unfortunate victim had a role in the misfortune (and possibly prevented); and I feel sympathy whenever I feel as though the misfortune could have happened to anyone (like me).   /
plove: I wouldn't call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I can sort of understand the quote. I hate feeling pity; and I can sometimes hate the person or situation that caused me to feel that way.
clove: I would call compassion love an understanding and a feeling of duty to aid the person in the situation.  It's easier to feel compassion for someone that I know well and care about.
slove: "Sympathy love" would be defined in my book as care and concern for another person that has been the subject of undue misfortune.

writepity: I was walking along the sidewalk and a raggedy homeless looking man was going person to person asking for money. He was strung out; sweaty; and shaky and seemed like he was going through withdraws and cravings for some highly addictive drug. I felt sad that someone is resorted to that. They let themselves become so dependent on a drug that they cant go a day without getting their fix. It was pitiful.
writetende: My nephew was playing and knocked some fragile ceramic figurines off a shelf. I had warned him multiple times before to be careful when playing in that room; but he didn't listen. I was rather mad at him for breaking him but how mad can I stay at  a 7 year-old being a kid. So even though I was mad I still sat down and played with lego's with him when he asked.
writesymp: My friend's dog was hit by a car and killed. He had had the dog for about 5 years and loved that dog. I felt terrible knowing how much he missed his dog as I have also had dogs get hit by cars and their lives ended prematurely. I told him that his god died happy; he had given him a good life and there wasn't anything he could have done. If he had kept his dog locked up inside all day or penned up would he have been as happy; unlikely. Death of animals and people we love is unfortunatly a part of our world.
writeempat: One of my friends grandpa recently passed away. My friend life myself is a more reserved person and wasn't too torn up over the death of his grandpa. My grandpa had passed away a few years ago and I wasn't particularly close with him so I knew what my friend was feeling. Like he should care more yet at the same time; he was very old and the elderly are at a high risk of death.
plove: I would not call pity a type of love
pcontempt: I don't think this is true. Pity to me is sadness over the actions someone chooses; that they are ruining there life. Contempt to me is anger; hate; revoltsion
tlove: I would say it's even when they do something wrong you still love them and will be able to forgive them
slove: Sympathy to me is the caring about the feeling of another person and knowing what they are experiencing. I wouldn't say its  a knd of love
elove: I would call empathy being able to know and feel what another person is feeling. I wouldn't call it love

writesymp: When I found out that my Grandpa was being hospitalized for multiple medical conditions I felt sympathy for not only my Grandpa but my other close family members; especially my mother. I felt sad that my Grandpa was in the hospital in a very bad condition and I recognized the pain that he was going through; so I sympathized with him because of the personal relationship that I had with him. I know that at his age it must be very difficult for him to go through something like this. Because of my sympathy; I went to the hospital where my Grandpa was staying with my mother and tried to comfort him by engaging in conversation that didn't concern his current state.
writeempat: When I read about a story in the news in which a person was killed; because of a argument with someone else over whether or not there would be a sequel to the new 300 movie I had empathy for that persons family members. I did not know that person in particular; so I had no personal relationship with them; but I still recognized their situation and the pain that they must be going through. I understood that it is hard to lose a loved one and that it must be truly saddening for them to have to go through this experience.  I could not do anything to help this persons situation; but their story did resonate with me and force me to feel sorry and saddened by their situation.
slove: I think it would be the type of love that you have for family members or people that you have a strong emotional connection with.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writetende: For national siblings day; my little sister told her entire dance team that I was "an awkward Beyonce". Most people would find this offensive; but this is the most memorable and powerful compliment someone has ever given me. It sums up everything I would like to be (Beyonce) with who I actually am (awkward). I am not actually an awkward person; but I typically deviate from normal ideas and ways of doing things; and I'm not afraid of that. Everyone in my family thinks I'm a weirdo; but I just accept it. I was so moved when my little sister paid me such a high compliment. I knew that she really loved me and looked up to me; and accepted me every weird quirk that I had. I don't know if I will ever find someone else in my life who understands me as completely and well as she does.
writecomp: Before spring break; I had made out with this guy at a party. I had liked him for a while but had never talked to him; and when I saw him; I summoned all my courage and went to say hi. When he had to leave with his friends; he asked me to put my phone number in his phone; so I did. The next morning he texted me with his name and a short message that said "Have a good spring break :)". I hadn't dated anyone; let alone talk to a guy; since last August. My boyfriend and I broke up because we were going to different colleges; and while he took one month to completely forget me and move on; I was still pretty torn up about him. I thought that this would be the perfect way to get back out into the world and find someone new. However; after spring break; I hadn't seen this new guy at all. I thought this was fine; since we were probably both busy with school; and pushed it to the back of my mind. However; after running into him a few times; I saw that the usual response was that he made a second of awkward eye contact and ran. On one of these instances; I had a friend with me. Of course; she knew all about the situation; and as the guy I liked came out of the dining hall and locked eyes with me; I casually hit her hand. She said to me "What an asshole." I have never felt gratitude for anyone as intensely as I did in that moment with my best friend. I knew that she truly cared about me and was angry that someone had treated me so poorly; and I will love her unconditionally until I die for having my back in that moment.
writesymp: When I felt sympathy; I was hearing the story told by a friend of  mine. She had stolen prescription drugs in order to help her study more for exams. Since she had a job; a full course load; and was applying to the Ross School of Business; she decided to steal this medicine from her sister in order to make sure she had the best grades and best chance of being accepted without sacrificing her income. I know what she did was wrong; but I can't help feeling that the only thing she needed was more time in a day. She was desperate and scared and stressed out; just like many of my friends are; and I'm sad that she thought the only solution to the problem was theft and drug abuse. Since she had stolen the prescription drugs and they were in an unmarked container; my friend's roommate told their RA about the problem; who called the police. My friend was arrested and has to appear in court next August. I feel like the entire situation was extremely preventable; and that my friend didn't have to resort to such extreme measures just because of the pressure she was under. Had I known about the problem; I would have encouraged her to communicate with her professors more frequently about her grades and what she could do to improve in her classes; as well as studied with her more often. Since finding out about the situation; I have talked to her more about what's troubling her in her life and supported her; as well as studied with her.
tlove: I believe that tenderness is a very intimate love. It's not easy to experience tenderness for someone; and I think that it only comes after years of understanding a person and fully; completely loving them.
clove: Again; this would be a friendly love.
slove: I think sympathy would be considered love; possibly a friendly love. We all have times where we lean on trusted friends for support; and when you need to get something off of your chest; receiving sympathy from a good friend always helps a little bit. That way; you know someone cares about you and your well-being.

writepity: I pity someone when it seems to me they are given multiple chances yet they still do not redeem themselves. There was this kid in middle school who would always get picked on for trying to buy his friends and for being pretty shallow. I admit during freshman year I also didnt give him the time of day. Fast forward three years to junior year. He was in chemistry class and I genuinely felt bad for the way I treated him. I sent him a facebook message explaining that what I did during freshman year was wrong and I was wondering we could make amends. His reply was along the lines of accusing me that I had a different agenda (He suggested I liked him in a romantic way). I was angry for a while; but then I thought about it for a little while. This kid has some obvious trust issues; but he will never get over them if he doesnt even take what is being handed right to him. This is where I felt pity.
writetende: I am less aware of this emotion; but times when i experience tenderness arenr usually very personal to me. Sometimes; I search on youtube "military homecomings" and watch countless of videos showing families beam with joy as their loved ones come back hom from service. Without fail; I'll cry every time. I have never had that experience happen to me before (saying goodbye to a loved one for so long) and so I'm not sure why I cry every time.
writecomp: To me; compassionate means to love with forgiveness. I am often compassionate with my sister. For example; just the other day she was being pretty rude to me for no reason. She had mood swings and she would use hurtful phrases such as "awful sister" and "dumb" to address me. I am three years older than her; and although we are very close; she gets into these zones on occasion. I remember when I was 15 and I would have mood swings from day to day. That night she came to apologize;  saying she knew how she was acting but couldnt stop herself (she was either stressed or tired). I forgave her without a second thought. I guess I felt compassionate because I had been in her position before; and if I were her I would also want to be forgiven.
writesymp: Again; I'll use my sister since this just happened last night. I had come back from campus and arrived at home last night 10 minutes before my sister walked in through the door from tennis tryouts. She came in quietly; so I knew tryouts hadnt gone well. I immeadiatley hugged her; as she cried on my shoulder. She had been playing tennis all year; just to get a shot at the varsity team. Having the same coach years before; I knew he was an asshole and didn't give my sister the shot she deserved. I was right. She told me as she was crying that he matched her up with the worst player; and then when their match was done (after she beat that player by a large margin); the coach made her sit out for the remainder of tryouts so other "more likely" varsity players could have more court time. I knew my sister tried very hard and this meant a lot to her and I felt helpless.
writeempat: I differentiate sympathy as sympathy being on a more personal level; and empathy being on a less personal level. I felt empathetic when I saw the families of Flight 370 passengers crying on CNN. It actually felt as though my heart was hurting. Theres a part of me thankful that my family did not have to go through the same situation as those people; but there is also a part of me that hurts for them. Like I want to help them; but I dont know if I have the right to.
plove: I would not call it love
tlove: Autonomic Love?
clove: A frogiving type of love
slove: Protective love
elove: Helpless love

writepity: 1) In the past i have felt pity towards a number of people involved in certain events across the world. However; a more personal example would be about my friend "Brad". Brad liked/loved a girl called "Sophie" very much. Brad tried very hard to begin a relationship with Sophie and revealed to her that he cared for her a lot. However; she did not completely reciprocate his feelings; and instead told him that she wasn't in the place for a relationship. This culminated in Brad sending flowers on Valentines day; but then later that day he found out that she was with someone else from a friend of Sophie's. Brad told me this story and i felt a lot of pity towards him. /  / 2) I was feeling very sorry for my friend Brad and could relate to that type of situation. I was also slightly mad at Sophie; for what I saw as leading my friend on. /  / 3) I wanted to reassure Brad and tell him that everything will be okay and that there are plenty of other better women in the world; I also wanted to say what I thought about Sophie. However; I did not exactly tell him what I thought about Sophie. Instead I did reassure him; and told him there were plenty more fish in the sea.
writetende: 1) One of my close friends; "Hannah"; had recently broken up with her boyfriend and was feeling very sad about him flaunting his new found freedom through social media. Hannah was close to me and to see her so upset was very painful. /  / 2) I felt like I need to protect Hannah and reassure her; and I felt sad on her behalf.  /  / 3) I wanted to reassure her that everything would be okay; which is exactly what I did do. I told her that everything would be okay and that I was there for her.
writesymp: 1) My friend "Andrew" was on the track and cross country team with me and was a great long distance runner. However; Andrew had fairly serious back problems; so in his final few seasons on the track and cross country teams; he was not able to compete up to his full potential and did not achieve his goals. /  / 2) I was feeling sad for my friend; especially since his circumstance was relatable to me in many ways. /  / 3) I wanted to reassure my friend and make sure that he didn't blame himself. However; I did none of these; because I knew he could handle himself.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: In some situations it can be. However; when you're feeling pity for a friend or even anyone you know; pity is not necessarily a bad thing
tlove: Tenderness is very much central to general love in my view; although I don't know how to categorize it.
slove: I would not really call sympathy love; although it is definitely a necessary part of love

writetende: A time when I have shown tenderness is when I was with my grandma after she had a stroke. Normally a strong; able woman; after she had a stroke she was left feeble and unable to perform mundane tasks. The area most affected by the stroke was her ability to speak. When with her I had to take time talking; and make sure that when I was with her I talked slowly and allowed her time to process the information that I was giving her; and then be able to respond in an engaging way. During that time I felt empathy for her; and knew that I needed to put her needs above my own. This experience made me want to take more time with her and spend additional time with here knowing that another stroke could strike at anytime.
writecomp: I time I felt compassion towards someone was when I was my family. With the start of college and moving away; brought a loss of time spent with my family. Usually I would eat dinner with them; and participant in family activities during the week; and especially on the weekend. When visiting home for the first time during Thanksgiving Break; I was reunited with my family and the joy that swept over me had never been greater. We spent time together watching sports; eating dinner; and talking throughout the weekend. It felt welcoming to be home. This made me want to be home for longer; although I knew that I needed to go back to school. After break; I stayed in better contact with my family; calling home more often than I did before the Thanksgiving Break.
writesymp: Today I watched a video of a young kid who was allowed to play on a professional hockey team for a day. He did not play during the game; however he was given the opportunity to skate with the team before the game; and skate out onto the ice with the team during the pregame ceremony. When announced over the loud speaker; the child became very emotional. He was given this opportunity because he has a heart condition; and regardless of the fact that he has been told to not play hockey by doctors; he continues to do so. This child became very emotional; and began to cry; during the start of the game. I was able to feel what he was feeling; and joy swept over me just as it had for the child; and almost brought tears to my own face. Although I was only watching a video; the emotions felt by the child were strongly conveyed to me and made me feel empowered to help others and give them opportunities that they might not normally have.
writeempat: A time that I felt empathetic towards somebody was when I see a homeless person on the street. As I am walking by; sometime with food in my hands; I feel bad that these people live here without a home; food; and shelter. Although typically I do nothing; I feel compelled to either give them money; or provide them with a good that could help them.
tlove: If tenderness was a kind of love; it would be love in always using a soft had with a partner. Trying to make sure that your partner never changed and that they always stayed pure; and you protected them.
clove: If compassion was a kind of love; it would be always wanting to be with you other; and always feeling welcome in situations in which your partner was present.
slove: If sympathy was a kind of love; it would be love out of knowing that you make somebody else's life better; and you do not love them for self gain.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: I felt pity for my sister when she broke her arm in a playoff softball game.  She had to undergo surgery and was in a cast for 6 months. Over the course of those 6 months I drover her to doctors appointments and helped her with whatever she needed help with.  I felt pity because she wasnt able to do the things she was normally capable of doing and it was really aggravating her.
writetende: I felt tenderness when my friends mother passed away in 10th grade. I didnt know what to say to him besides that Im sorry.  Nothing can ease that pain or make it go away.  It was a really tough time for my whole friend group and we did everything we could to comfort my friend Brett. I felt sad and helpless because there was nothing I could do to make my friend feel better.
writecomp: As I reflect upon these circumstances more I have come to conclude that tenderness and compassion are the same thing to me.  In circumstances; like the passing of my friend's mother; I felt compassion and tenderness as one.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my mother when she was rushing to get to my brother's basketball game and she was rear-ended by a person talking on their cell phone.  She was so upset that she wasnt able to make it to his final game of the season. I felt sympathetic for her because the ability to get their was taken out of her hands;and she felt bad she wasnt there to support her son.
plove: no
pcontempt: no
tlove: a caring sort of love

writepity: Something that had happened that intentionally done but something that turned out to be bad was when i pitied someone. My feelings and thoughts were more so on the fact that my friend did something stupid and that  i thought of her in a different way than i had before as if I sort of looked down upon her; this is what i felt on the inside. But on the outside; I didn't show this expression. I just simply smiled and listened to her as she told me her story about how she felt like she was used by a guy. Right the; I just wanted to tell her I told you so; and that she is kind of stupid for not listening to her friends. But i kept it cool because it would have been very rude; and she already had a lot of emotion. So i simply told her that it was going to be alright and that she should move on with her life.
writetende: I felt tenderness when I was with family friend. The other family had two children age 4 and 6. They were cute little girls who were extremely cute and smart both physically and in their personality. I loved them and loved hangout with them because they made me very happy. I just wanted to hug them and give them presents. Whenever our families were together; I would take care of them and play with them as if i was their real brother.
writecomp: I felt compassion to my mom when I went to college. Living in my household; we never really expressed our love for one another orally. We never really told each other that we loved each other but inside; we all knew that we all loved each other very dearly. When I moved to college; while adjusting to not living with my mother and the new college life; I realize how grateful I was to have my mother. And I felt a lot of compassion toward my mother. I realized all the small things that she had done for me that I had not realized before or had taken for granted. Right at the moment; I texted her and told her that I loved her. This was a very rare occasion. Out of surprised; my mother asked me if something was wrong. And I simply replied that I was so grateful to have her as my mom. I felt love and a longing towards my mom. I wanted to give back to her because she had given me so much.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my friend when he was telling me that his parents were going through a tough time. Although every married couple usually goes through hard times; my parents seemed to make it out of it. And although I was never really exposed to a divorce situation in my life; I just knew that my friend was having a hard time and he needed a friend to talk to. Over all; I was understand his point of view because I feel like as human beings; we can understand and feel what other people are feeling as if that specific thing is happening to themselves. I just listened to my friend and told him that everything would be okay at the end. Although he hated his parents for getting a divorce; I told him that there might be things that he wouldn't understand so he should try to keep an open mind.
writeempat: I met a girl in England and she was telling me about her views of the world and how the world doesn't seem to be too nice. She didn't seem to think that there were that many good things in this world; or at least we couldn't see the goodness in the world because we are usually blinded by our society. I felt empathy toward her because I felt the same way. I understood her because I have experienced similar things as her. I didn't really say anything but nod my head in agreement. She said she felt comfortable talking to me about this topic. At the end when she finished; however; I told her that the world is truly a good place and that we must try harder to look at the positives than the negatives.
plove: Pity is not love.
pcontempt: No; I don't think this is true. I am not even sure what that is trying to say.
tlove: It could really be anything. It could be brotherly; sisterly; romantic. Love is love.
clove: Love is love. You know love when you encounter it. You know love when you give love. It is simple yet so complex.
slove: love as to take care of your friend.
elove: understanding way kind of love

writepity: One time I pitied a girl who was really nice and had a crush on me but I did not have a crush on her back so I decided to be really nice to her but tell her I didn't like her back. I remained good friends with her and for a couple weeks after that I felt pity for her so I was really nice to her for those couple weeks before things went back to normal.
writecomp: I feel compassion for people who are battling sickness. I feel compassionate towards these people because I have had loved ones who have gone through the same thing so there is a mutual understanding. I wanted to tell them that I have been there too; and to ask them if I could help. A lot of times I just asked if there was anything I could do to help but never truly talked to them about how they were feeling
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards the homeless people I saw on the freezing cold nights this winter because I didn't know exactly how miserable it was for them but I could tell that they were miserable and wanted to do something to help. I wanted to be able to provide them shelter for the night but the most that I did was give them money out of my wallet.
writeempat: I felt empathy for a boy who like me didn't make the basketball team in high school. I remember thinking that he must feel really upset because I know I was feeling upset. I wanted to talk to him and talk about how we were handling it but instead I was too focused on my own shortcomings in basketball that I never talked to him..
plove: Pity is like a love that you have for someone that you see is hurting and you feel you may have cause so its kind of like a guilty love.
pcontempt: Yes I think it is true because if pity lasts for a long amount of time it turns ugly.
clove: Compassion would be love that is not romantic but is very deep and meaningful
slove: Sympathy love is similar to pity love
elove: I would not call empathy love

writepity: I felt pity towards a kid in highschool who really did not have many friends. I felt bad for the kid and thought about how much I would hate to be in that situation. Though I thought about how much I would personally hate to be in that situation i did not say or do anything to remedy it for the kid.
writetende: A time in which I felt tenderness toward someone was when I would visit my grandma during her final days in the hospital. I knew that she was going to die soon and that there was nothing that I could do so I just wanted to keep her company. I would just keep her company and talk about anything as there really was not much to be said. I felt bad as there was nothing I could do but attempt to make her more comfortable.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards a friend of mine who was not doing well in school last semester. I felt bad as I did not know how I could help the situation. I wanted to help my friend but I did not have extra time nor was he asking for help so I just suggested that he study more frequently.
writeempat: I felt empathy last when a friend of mine had his mother diagnosed with breast cancer. I felt bad as I could feel the pain he was going through myself as I related my own feelings of a family member being sick to the situation and felt his pain. I wanted to make him feel better as I knew what he was going through as I had been there before myself. I did not really do much for him besides telling him that I was there for him and tried to encourage him that she will be fine.
plove: I would not say pity is a type of love.
pcontempt: I do as when you feel pity for a person you are essentially putting them below yourself as they are in a bad situation that you would not see yourself in.
tlove: Tenderness is a form of love that comes out when taking care of someone you care about that is in a weakened state.
slove: I would not call it a kind of love.
elove: Empathy is a love where you want to love a person as you have been in the same painful place as them before and know how terrible it is.

writetende: I felt tenderness towards my friend who was extremely upset after the breakup between her and her boyfriend. I was upset for her and I knew that her heart was broken. I sat with her and hugged her; and was just there for her while she cried. I tried to say things to make her feel better such as "boys are stupid" and "there are plenty of fish in the sea" but nothing I said seemed to make a difference. I continued to just be there for her and got her anything she wanted/needed.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards my little sister when she did really poorly at her swim meet. I felt very loving and caring towards her; and even though she didn't do as well as she hoped I tried to comfort her and told her that everyone was still proud of her.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my friend when her grandfather died. I didn't know what to say or do; or how to make her feel better; and I just felt extremely sorry for her and felt helpless to do anything that could somehow fix the situation or make her not feel sad anymore.
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love. I view tenderness as the closeness that a mother has with her child when they are vulnerable; and I think you experience the kind of love associated with tenderness when those who are close to you are vulnerable.
clove: I would call compassion more caring than loving. I think some people can associate it as an act of love; but I associate it with someone being caring.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.

writepity: I felt pity towards someone when my friendwas playing a video game called Runescape. He was very good at the game but one day he met his match. Another player walked right up to him and began fighting him! Although my friend was an excellent wizard; he fell and lost all of his super expensive armor. Devastated; and surprised by defeat; he collapsed and began to cry. We were very young but I felt pity for him. There was nothing I could do to help him regain his lost items; or dignity. I kind of awkwardly moved off to the side of the room while repeating; "Dude; it's ok. You can get those weapons and armor back eventually. It sucks that it happened but let's just go play basketball or something." He sat unmoved so I just continued to show him that I realized how much this situation sucked for him. At the end; I ahrdly felt bad for him anymore because he was acting like a baby.
writecomp: I felt compassion very strongly for my cousins who went through a bad divorce a couple years ago. They were identical twins and only 7 years old. Their dad was a dentist in East Lansing and their mother worked as a veterenarian at MSU. A recent string of incidents involving my uncle had lead to the two discussing divorce. My uncle is an alcoholic (now recovering; thankfully). He would get drunk around his kids and occassionally offer to drive impaired. His decisions did not go unnoticed my aunt. While the rest of my family tried desperately to get my uncle counseling and avoid the divorce; it still happened. My cousins were devastated. The traveling between houses they had to endure for the rest of their childhood years now stood as a barrier between their equivalent love for both parents. To be clear; although my uncle was an alcoholic; I deeply loved and respected him. Most of his drunken antics were not when I was at the house. He was often funny anyways and I couldn't even tell the difference between him when he was drunk or not. I loved my aunt as well. She was a very caring woman that just wanted the best for her children; given the circumstances. I felt compassion for my cousins. I told them constantly that their parents made the decision with them in mind. Despite my uncle's problem; I told my cousins that both of their parents loved them very much. After the initial year of the break up; I made sure to visit my cousins as often as possible. I didn't offer them their pity; I just tried to be a nice cousin for them. My own mother sent me over with cookies and sometimes video games for their PS2. Together; we could spend an afternoon eating cookies and playing video games or watching a movie. Whatever we did; it always shifted the focus from the divorce. Instead; our times together focused on the great times we as cousins always had together. I always was careful not to approach the sore subject. I might aks how they were feeling overall; but there was no need to interview them about what they felt about the divorce. I just wanted to be there to distract them from this horrible; life changing event. Of course; it was probably easier to distract 7 year olds than if they had been older (at least old enough to understand the gravity). I felt terrible for both of them and realized that their lives would be made more difficult now that they had 2 houses to go between. Because of these stresses; I always tried to be there to help them. I tried to be somebody outside of the problem; but someone able to guide them through a tough time.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards someone my fellow friend had gotten fired from umpiring. A particularly unusual situation had come up for him in the middle of the game while him and I were working for some of the angriest managers in the 12 year old league. As a result of this unusual play; my friend who worked behind home plate was subjected to the ire of the visiting manager. Because only theh ome manager reports to the league about the quality of the umpires; we usually disregarded the visiting manager. This; however; was probably the third time my friend had been singled out by this particular manager. Fianlly; my friend erupted on this guy and gave him the middle finger. I laughed silently because of the audacity of this 15 year old flipping off an adult. The visiting manager took down my friend's name and soon the league made its decision to fire him. I felt really bad fro my friend because he was a good umpire who just had a bad day on the field. It happens to me occassionally as well. He just had a bad string of calls that caught him in a bad mood with the wrong managers. It was just a bad situation overall to have landed in. I saw him the next day in school and said the same to him. It really could've happened to anybody. Us 15 year olds didn't even know what had happened in that play. Unfortunately; my friend had to take the heat. I told him I felt sorry and that I understand that he might be pissed or remorseful about his actions from yesterday.
plove: I wouldn't regard pity as love because it is a veyr passive way of expressing condolances.
pcontempt: I would say this is probably true because whoever shows pity does not try to enter the other person's thoughts. Pity is just another way of acting sad for a person without actually feeling bad for them.
clove: Compassion is thek ind of love that shows that you want to play an active role in making someone feel better. Rather than just being there and expressing your sorrows; I tried to help them through a rough time.
slove: Sympathy would be regarded as a kind of love because you are trying to enter the person's shoes to feel their exact emotions. You try to cope with them by understanding how they must feel. By entering their thoughts; you can get a better grasp on the best way to manage them and their emotions.

writetende: I felt tenderness for my girlfriend when she told me both her grandmas are not doing so well with their health and that they are both projected to die in a short time. I felt tenderness toward her and felt like I had to console her. The worst part was that I knew I or anyone else couldn't do anything fix the situation. It was how it was; because that is life. But I did console her and felt tenderness towards her.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards my other friend who goes to Michigan State. His girlfriend that he had been dating for 4 years; who is also my friend; goes to Uof M. When they had to be away from each other because of college it led to the girlfriend cheating on him almost every week. I felt compassionate towards my friend at State because he had no idea what his girlfriend was doing. I felt sick to my stomach that the girlfriend could cheat like that and be stabbing someone in the back while doing it. I took matters into my own hands and talked to the girlfriend. She had to tell her boyfrind and it would have to be up to him what to decide. Eventually they broke up. I felt terrible though for my friend at State that this was the way his relationship with his 4 year girlfriend ended.
writesymp: My roomate and my other friend are both walkons for the football team here at UofM. They both live in Bursley and have to get up at very early hours in the morning to go to practice. My roomate was smart enough to find a way to get to the practice in the morning as soon as he heard that he made the team because the Michigan buses do not run that early in the morning. The other friend procrastinated this and then was left to rely on my roomate for a ride every morning to practice or workouts since my roomate now had a car. The friend had a car but it was at home which he conveniently "forgot" to bring back to UofM every time he went home. He relied on my roomate everyday to drive him and never offered to pay for gas. I told my roomate that he was being taken advantage of by his friend and that he should definitely say something to him so that he brings his car up from home. My roomate did; but the friend just conveniently "forgot" to purchase any parking passes. Their workouts in the morning started to begin at different times and my roomate was having to get up earlier just so he could drive his friend to his workout when my roomate could have been sleeping. I felt so sympathetic to my roomate and wished I could have spoken to the friend; but I knew it wasn't my place to do so. I knew my roomate needed his sleep and he was having to get up very early everyday even if his workout started much later in the day. Finally; my roomate had enough and told his friend he needed to figure out his car situation by the end of the week bc he will not be driving him anymore. I felt better about the situation and was glad my roomate finally stuck up for himself. He understood that he was just being taken advantage of and that was not right.
tlove: Yes this could be a love but it could also be more of a friendship as well. It depends on the situation.
clove: Not really a love.
slove: It would be a friendship kind of love.

writepity: During practice the other day; we were doing a possession drill in a tight space. It was 4 against 2 in a 7 by 7 area. The object of the drill was to try and get 15 passes against the 2 defenders. The loser after 2 minutes or 15 passes would have to do 10 push-ups and 10 sit-ups. While playing; I felt pity for one of the defenders; because every time he came near me for about 4 passes in a row; I embarassed him by playing the ball through his legs. He was getting so angry that by the 4 time he kicked the ball away in fury. I felt pity because he was trying so hard; but he just couldn't get the ball from me; and that in turn; spurred his anger and got annoying to me. I felt pity for a certain amount of time and then it faded because he got even more aggressive than he already is; and I couldn't tolerate him.
writecomp: At an away game during the season; at halftime; I felt compassion when receving instructions from coach in the lockeroom. I felt the compassion from his voice during the halftime speech to get us motivated; and began to do much of the same thing as him when we took the field again in the second half. Rallying people on; showing how much emotion I was putting on myself to express to my teammates how much the game actually mattered. I was just feeling a lot of energy; like a spark that was trying to lift the teammates around me to rally for a crucial win. I wanted to work really hard; show everyone that I was trying my best for the team and taking no plays off. I was tackling people hard; I was sharp in my passing; I was defending; I was sprinting my tail off. I just said things like "let's go boys" or "the goals coming keep working" and stuff like that. Mostly motivational stuff. But I'm sure my teammates could feel the compassion for the situation that I had and was exerting throughout the the second half and most of the entire time I was in the game.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my roommate one day after training when he had gotten hurt severely. It was his first two weeks back after being out for 6 months with hip surgery. He hadn't played in over 2 years; and was doing everything in his power to get back and playing again. He finally was cleared to play full-contact for the first time in two years. We were doing a drill where it was 8 v 8 in a small area to goal. He was defending his man and the ball skip passed him in the air. He jump up with another one of our players and landed awkwardly; dislocating his hip again. He was in so much agony; after working so hard and doing so much he would now be out another 6-8 months to regain strength in his hip again to start practicing. I just felt really bad; it was a freak incident; and no one could really control that or even foresee it happening. I kept telling him you'll be fine; it'll get better; and tried to motivate him. At some point I just gave up because all he would rely on for healing were alcohol and pain meds. It sounds kind of extreme; but after persistence he finally got over it; got himself back together both on the field and in the classroom. By taking the right steps; he finally is practicing again and I'm really proud of him. I just felt so extremely bad for him when it first happened because he put in so much work to get back playing and it just set him back even further.
plove: You can't love out of pity; that doesn't make sense. Much like empathy; you can't love someone because you pity them because then it doesn't mean it's true love. It's contradictory.
pcontempt: I think its true. Because pity happens so often you can belief that this statement is true.
clove: If I were to call compassion love; it would have to be where I feel the utmost closeness to a person; where all I want to do is spend time with them or be around them. I wouldn't call compassion love if you only feel it certain times of the day; or certain days of the week. The connection with compassion has to be there throughout for it to be considered compassionate. Everything you do has to feel that way.
slove: You can't call sympathy love because you can't love someone because you feel bad for them. That just doesn't make any sense and would end up making things worse if you did love them only because you felt bad and didn't want to leave them by themselves.

writepity: A time I remember feeling pity towards someone else was when an old friend of mine got a girl pregnant and they decided to have the child; they were going into their Junior year of highschool.  I never really talked about the situation with my friend because at this point we weren't talking too much anymore. One of the last times I had really talked to him he had gotten sent away to a bording school for all the times he had gotten in trouble.  I felt bad for him; i knew this was going to severely hurt his future and chances in life but i also knew that this event was his fault; not that i like to asign blame when a child is being born but this event could have been avoided.  I felt bad for him but i was not sympathizing with him.
writecomp: A time I remember feeling compassion for someone else was when a good friend of mine passed away and I had to talk to his mother.  I felt a mutlitude of emotions at this time but one of them was definitely compassion; this was because she was now a mother who had no children. She is an amazing woman who I consider close to a second mom but she was going through something so difficult that i could hardly comprehend.  What I was feeling was that I knew she was in a lot of pain because she had just gone through one of the most painful experiences possible; and although I was certainly in pain I knew that she was taking it even harder and I just wanted to try and lessen the amount of pain/anguish she was feeling.  When we talked; we talked a lot about religion and belief honestly she was helping me through the experience more than I was her because it's just her nature to help me when I am in pain.  The best way I could describe how i was feeling compassion at this point in time was I saw her pain and i fully registered where and why it was occuring and i truly felt for her; i understood exactly why this was so difficult for her.
writesymp: A time i felt sympathy for someone was when my dad had retired from his job as a tax lawyer to pursue a career as a highschool history teacher.  He had always loved teaching and history but he didn't ever expect how difficult it was going to be for him to get a job in the busy teacher market that is norther virginia.  I felt sympathy for him when he had to take a job teaching entrepeneurship; keyboarding and introduction to Office. This was not what he wanted to do with is time and I genuinely felt bad for him; he was in a very bad situation because he had committed too much time to try and be a teacher so he had to accept this job.  I didn't do too much I never really mentioned that he was being forced to do a job he wasn't particularly in love with.  I left the situation alone and mostly observed from a far.
plove: I would not call pity a kid of love. you are looking down on this person for whatever reason and that to me does not feel like love.
pcontempt: It is pretty similar; at the same time i was sad i was also very dissapointed and angry that he had let such an event that was in his control occur.
clove: I would consider compassion a form of love; its understanding eachother and their emotions so you are very connected which I do believe is a form of love
slove: i wouldnt really equate sympathy with love. I do love my dad but at the time i was sympathizing with him I wasn't really thinking too much about love; i just felt bad for him; dissapointed in how the situation had turned out.

writepity: There is this kid from my high school named Anthony  Lee. From what I can tell he wass a fairly normal kid; but he was a little on the wierd side. Some people from the school noticed that and would avoid him and there were a lot of jokes about him. Eventually it got to the point that everyone knew who Anthony Lee was; and more specifically to stay away from him. He was wierd and tried to hard they said. One day my friend accidentally met him in a rite aid and they talked and she though he was acutally really nice; but then I guess he was so attention starved that he started coming on too strong. He friended her on Facebook; asked repeatedly for her phone number (I doubt he was actually interested; I think he just wanted a friend) and he kept badgering her to hang out.  / She was so uncomfortable that she started to avoid him at all costs and it only served to perpetuate the image he already had. I pitied him because he was likely being picked on and no one really wanted to talk to him; but I didn't exactly empathize with him because he brought it on himself with being extremely clingy to people who showed even the slightest kindness.  / It was sad that he had to deal with a crappy high school experience; but I wasn't inclinded to do anything about it.
writetende: My best friend had passed out after drinking too much and I was terrified for her; but after she recovered a little; she was still really sick and I sat next to her and cared for her until she fell asleep. Just  having her there and needing to take of her carefully while she was sick made me feel tenderness towards her.  / I cleaned her up; helped her get comfortable; made sure she was okay; grabbed water and tylenol; grabbed her a blanket; and set her phone by her. I did everything I though she could need and then left a note for when she woke up.  / I had been terrified for her earlier; so I was trying to be super careful with her; making sure she was okay; and making sure comfortable and felt taken care of.
writesymp: When my best friend's uncle died; I went to the viewing with her and stood there with her family and helped them mourn the loss of their family member. I didn't know her uncle; never met him; and was only meeting most of her family for the first time; but I wanted to be there for her; to let her know I was there for her.  / I didn't know her uncle so I didn't feel sad that he was gone; but I felt sad for Cory who had lost him and was heartbroken about it. I felt for her even though it wasn't something that acutally hurt me.
writeempat: When my roomate broke her leg I knew how she felt because I had done something very similar several years ago so I felt I understood what she was going through.
plove: pity is not a type of love.
pcontempt: A little; when you pity someone you just look down upon them and think that it would suck to be in their situation; but you don't particularly feel the urge to help. You almost feel like it is there fault they are there.
tlove: tenderness is kind of a caring love; you want to care for them and make sure they are okay. It isn't romantic.
slove: You care about a person and you care about how they feel; and you feel the same way.
elove: empathy is knowing how a person feels because you have felt the same way. You may be better able to empathize with someone you care about; but it isn't really love.

writetende: I spend a lot of time with my Nanny when I visit her in New York. She makes me feel amazing. She is such a sweet person; and when I am around her or anytime I speak to her I feel many emotions. Conversations with her brighten my day; they give me hope; I feel calm; soft; and loved. She has no negative vibe at all; and she always leaves me with a good feeling. She is the most tender loving person I know; and she leaves me with a feeling of tenderness.
writecomp: It was a guy I was seeing. We had a sexual relationship; but he was also seeing other people. This upset me; and it pitied me also. But I still cared so much for him. I felt sympathy for her and I both; because he was playing us; but I still feel compassion for him. I wanted him to know I knew about her; and so I mentioneed it; he denied it saying they were finished; I will never know; but I felt as though he cheated on her with me. It was just all terrible and I feel terrible about it; but I invested a lot of emotion into him; and its hard to let him go.
tlove: Tenderness is a patient soft spoken love; a love that makes you feel free and safe and comfortable. Tenderness love would be a love that is pure and unselfish
clove: If I called compassion love; I'd call it a forgiving unselfish love.

writetende: A couple of years ago when one of my family friends had his first child I felt tenderness. After being apart of his life and then being able to see his own child made me feel special and loving for the both of them. I just wanted to be apart of their lives and spend more time with them now that their family was growing.
writecomp: I have been dating my girlfriend of a year and one of the first times we hung out I felt true compassion. It was a combination of how she talked and held herself that I truly fell in love with her. It was during our spring break that we met and all I wanted to do was being a part of her life because of how strongly I felt about this girl.
writesymp: When I was younger I watched as my neighbors house burnt down. He stood outside completely torn apart as all of his possessions were being burnt to the ground. I just remember myself trying to think of ways I could help this man weather it be running in there to save the things or get him some water. Although I was pretty young at the time so I knew nothing I could do would help him so I sympathized.
tlove: The love of caring about another
clove: Pure love in the typically sense.
slove: The kind of love that deals with caring

writepity: I felt pity when a lowly looking girl got caught stealing food at a store.  She looked like someone of the streets; ripped dirty clothes with piercings and mattered hair.  People offered to help her buy food when the cashier said she didn't have enough but she acted rudely and then tried to steal.
writecomp: I was playing a softball game and it was my first game with this team. We were warming up and next thing I knew a little girl was running towards our team.  She looked as if somethings were wrong with her according to her limp and her facial features.  When she finally reached us she hugged most of the girls.  Up close you could definetly tell she wasnt 100% normal.  I got introduced to her and she was so sweet and it didnt matter that she couldnt walk normally or run normally ; but the compassion she had for our team made; the way she cheered and hugged everybody and told everybody how awseome they were and ran with us made me feel compassion towards her.
plove: No; because you feel no happiness or no desire to grow.
pcontempt: No; because one should want to be happy not contempt.
clove: It would be a kind of love where you feel happy and attached to this person.  A love where you would do anything to keep them happy and out of harms way.

writetende: Tenderness is an interesting emotion as it can go along with a number of other emotions. One event in which I felt tenderness toward someone else was when my friend believed that all of her other friends didn't like her. There had been a number of events leading up to this situation; but at one point during our Freshman year my friend told me that she thought that most of her friends didn't actually like her; and that they just tolerated her because they lived in the same hall as her. I asked her why she felt this way; and she explained that it was because some of her friends had been getting annoyed with her over stupid little things. At the time; I did not fully understand why she felt this way; but I understood that she was upset about it and that I should try and make her feel better about the situation. I explained to her that just because people were getting annoyed with her over little things didn't mean they disliked her and that in order to really find out what was wrong she needed to confront the people that she felt were annoyed with her directly. Though I could not understand my friend's situation completely; I did feel tenderness toward her.
writecomp: When I think of compassion I think of that feeling you get when you're watching the ASPCA commercials with Sarah McLauchlin. That feeling I get when I both feel for someone or something and am passionate about their plight. One instance in which I felt this emotion was in my senior year of High School. My friend had been cast in the school's play as a minor role; but it was her first ever speaking role and she was super excited about it because she wanted to get over her stage-fright. One day in rehearsal our director announced that her role had been recast. It was such a small role; three lines at most; one scene on stage; the rest of the show she was in the ensemble; so to most people it wouldn't matter that those three lines had been given to someone else; but you could see on her face that she was upset. She had wanted to prove that she could do it. That she could get out on that stage and sing those three lines just like anyone else could; and it had been taken away from her. I both felt that feeling; that desire to do well; to conquer your fear; and was impassioned by it. How dare her take away the role he had given her; how dare he take away this one chance for her to prove herself. So I stood up and said that. I told him off for taking this chance away from her and I walked out of the theater. She ended up with two speaking roles in two different scenes.
writesymp: One time in which I felt sympathy for someone was when they got a low grade on a test. For the longest time I had been the biggest overachiever and would do everything I possibly could to get good grades. I both understood and was able to feel what it was like to get a poor grade on something that I thought I had or needed to do well on. My friend got a failing grade on her Econ midterm and was nearly distraught over the fact. I truly understood what it was like to do that badly; as the year before I had also gotten a failing grade; so I explained to her that it wasn't the end of the world; that I understood exactly how she felt; and that by the end of the year I had still been able to pass the class.
writeempat: One experience in which I felt empathy toward someone was when they were feeling lonely because they were not in a relationship. My friend is straight; and has never had a relationship with anyone and though I do not feel the same way they do about the opposite sex; or even relationships in general; I can understand what it is like to be alone. I felt bad for them; I told them that I was sure that they would be fine and that there was someone out there for them. But there wasn't really anything more I could do. I understood their feelings; but I had no solution.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: Compassion to me is not a kind of love. Sure; you may say oh I love that thing or that person in a compassionate way; but to love and to have compassion for something or someone are two completely different things; in my opinion.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I would not call empathy a type of love.

writepity: I felt pity toward my good friend in high school when i knew that he was going to be the subject of a prank. He was my good friend but i couldn't do anything about it and i felt bad for him. I wanted to prevent the prank from happening but instead i just stood by and watched. I felt slightly guilty and sad after i saw the prank take place but it didn't loom over my head for too long.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards one of my good friends who is a female. Every time we hung out i would show compassion towards her and we would hug and talk a lot. This emotion that i felt often came with happiness and love. I felt really good and i was not worried about anything.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my next door neighbor in my dorm after a night of going out. She was very drunk and lost her phone and her friend got sick. She was a complete mess and i felt very bad for her and i felt sympathy toward her. I was sad and put myself in her shoes which resulted in me feeling bad. I thought that she was going to be upset for a long time. I just told her that everything was fine and that  we will find her phone tomorrow.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards my friend when his dog passed away. The fact that he was really sad made me feel very sad and it was hard to see him like that. I wanted to talk to him but it was difficult with the struggle that he was going through. I felt miserable and depressed
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: I think this is true because the word pity is often associated with contempt
clove: I think it is a kind of love where two people share a very strong and happy bond with eachother
slove: I think that it is not a kind of love because one can sympathize with someone that they do not even know. You feel the pain of another person and relate to it but you do not necessarily love them.
elove: i would not call empathy a kind of love but i do think that empathy often comes with love

writepity: One time; a friend of mine came to me to get my help on their relationship problems. They were really sad because they had argued with their boyfriend and were not sure whether or not they could still be together after the argument and the distance the two had between them. I felt pity for her because I saw how sad the situation made her which made me feel bad for as well. What I was debating at the time was whether or not it was my position as a good friend to tell her how to deal with her relationship specifically; or to give her more general advice based on my previous experiences. I felt conflicted here because I was friends with both the girl asking for advice and her boyfriend as well and we talked daily so I felt that if I did anything to make a significant impact in their relationship I would feel guilty about it afterward. /  / What I wanted to do was help them mend their relationship so that we could continue to hangout as a group of friends like we have been doing since high school.  /  / What I ended up doing was advising her to do whatever she felt most comfortable with. I knew that she was feeling more and more sad recently because of the distance between her and her boyfriend so although it would be a sad thing for her if she would break up with him; it would be better in the long term for everyone if they did not have to feel tied down or obligated to be going out anymore. I told her what I described beforehand and she agreed with me and ended up resolving the issue with her boyfriend later thanks to my advice.
writecomp: 1. One time; my little brother was crying in his room due to being scolded and yelled at by my parents because of his poor performance in school. They punished him harshly and grounded him as well as not listening to his reasoning for the poor showing; as such I felt compassion towards him because I felt bad looking at how distressed and hopeless he looked. I was thinking that I could cheer him up and help him do better next time on his schoolwork seeing as how I had already gone through the same thing 5 years beforehand.  /  / What I ended up doing was telling him that I would help him improve and listen to his problems because I knew that my parents would never listen to the reasons so at the very least I could offer an ear for him. He ended up taking my offer and felt much better afterward because he had someone who could watch out for him if he needed help.
writesymp: One time I felt sympathy towards my little brother when he was dealing with his first week of middle school track. I felt a little happy at the time that someone else could experience what I did in middle school and I was thinking at the time that I kind of feel bad for him but at least my parents would finally believe me when I said that track was pretty tough at first. What I wanted to do was to give him advice on how to get better at track (attend practice; stretch; train at home) as well as telling my parents that I was not kidding about how tough it was at first because they did not believe me as I was the oldest sibling and they thought I was making an excuse for not liking track. What I ended up doing was telling my little brother the advice that I had listed beforehand but I did not tell my parents though they eventually found out; but to my chagrin did not even acknowledge that they had been harsh with me but compassionate towards my little brother's same situation.
plove: I think pity is the kind of love that you give when you feel bad for someone deeply. It is kind of like the kind of love someone would give to a cute little animal in the sense that you feel that it how less power over its situation and that you can in some way influence and help it out.
pcontempt: I don't think this is true because I believe that contempt is only utilized to express disgust or a sort of hatred towards something based on their situation while pity is showing more compassion toward the subject.
clove: If I were to call compassion a kind of love I would call it the kind of love that you give to someone like a family member who is in a slump or bad situation. To me; it feels like a kind of familial love that you give because you feel bad for them as well as having a close relationship (or at least feel like you have a close relationship in that situation) with them.
slove: I think that sympathy is the kind of love that someone gives themselves when they are boosting their self-esteem. Since you understand and can relate to the person you're sympathizing with you can give them that same kind of love.

writecomp: I live in metro Detroit; so I did some service work through my school there.  My Junior year of high school; I volunteered for a day at a senior center in the heart of Detroit.  The building was very old and was in desperate need of repair.  All of the people who went there were elderly; and most of them were also very poor.  Some could not walk on their own and needed wheel chairs.  Some said that they lived alone; and had no one to care for them.  For many people; their family did not ever reach out to them or visit them.  There were a lot of seniors who were very lonely; and desperatley in need of love and human interaction.  I felt so bad for them; and wanted them all to know how special they were.  I just wanted to tell every one of them that I loved them.  They were all so sweet; and all so in need of human love.  I tried my best to convey by my word and actions that they were special and loved.
writesymp: My dad has had knee problems for as long as I can remember.  His pain eventually got to the point where it was affecting his walkig; which was affecting how he walked.  Because of this; he had to get total knee replacement.  He was very optimistic going into the surgery; and although it went well he took a long time to recover.  He was in a lot of pain for months after the surgery.  He had trouble sleeping; and eventually had to be medicated in order to sleep at night.  He limped when he walked; and could not kneel in church or make any sudden movements with his knee.  I felt so bad for him.  He has always been very active and constantly on the move.  He has never been one to sit still or lay around.  He had a difficult time recovering; and it was a long and painful time for him.  I wanted to make him feel better; but I knew there was no way that I could do that.  I was constantly reassuring him that everything would be ok; but I felt somewhat powerless.
writeempat: Just this morning; my friend who lives in my hall came to me and told me she was sick.  She looked miserable; and she said she ahdn't slept at all last night.  Her skin felt very hot even though she said she was cold.  She told me she had an awful headache as well.  After describing to me how she felt; I realized that it sounded liek the same thing I had just last week.  I was so sick the week before; seeminlgy with the same illness; that I had to go home.  I missed a lot of important things (exams; volunteer work) but I was so sick that I could not get out of bed.  When she told me how she was feeling; I knew exactly how that felt.  I wanted to badly to help her feel better; but I knew that there was nothing I could really do.  I comforted her and told her to go see a doctor; but I felt bad becasue I wanted to do something more to help her.  I know how  awfulbeing sick like that feels; and I would not wish it upon anyone.
