clove: Compassion is definitely a kind of love.  Compassion; to me; is loving someone that you don't even know for reasons that have no explanation except that they are human just like you.
slove: Sympathy is a kind of love.  Sympathy is a kind of love that I feel like is a natural one.  Everyone feels sympathetic at some point in their lives; it's a natural response to someone you love's pain and suffering.
elove: I would call empathy a kind of love.  It is kind of like love at its most basic level.

writepity: When I was walking home from school one day I saw a young man who was disabled. I wasn't sure why but he had some trouble walking. I thought about how difficult his life must be compared to everyone else. I did nothing. I wanted to make him feel welcome and a part of society but I didn't know how. Instead I think I just made him uncomfortable.
writetende: When I was watching a funny video about a little girl and her mother teaching her to say no to strangers. I was thinking she was so innocent and cute. I didn't want to do anything or say anything.
writecomp: I felt compassion when my friend told me about the death of one of their relatives. I could not put myself in their shoes or understand their feelings. I wanted to console them and I did my best at it.
writesymp: When my friend broke up with her boyfriend she was crying a lot and was really hurt. I was thinking about when I was in a situation like hers. When someone hurt me. I wanted to console her and make her feel better. I just told her that everything was going to be okay.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: No because I think pity has nothing to do with contempt. You don't choose when you pity someone.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: love for other people
slove: Love for understanding

writepity: Recently I had a friend who was very rude to me and started saying things that he should not have said. it was very hurtful to me but the things that he had said made me pity him because I felt bad for the fact that he thought those things about me when they are very much not true. I was mad so I said mean things back. I wanted to punch him in the face but I just said mean things in return and asked him to never talk to me again. I felt sad and hurt but at the same time i was angry and i also thought it was sort of comical because clearly he is just a sad person.
writetende: When my best friends boyfriend broke up with her after a year and a half of dating; i had to be very tender with all of my words and what I would say and do. I did not want to say something that would upset or hurt her and I had to make sure that my words were never harsh but always understanding. Hugs helped us get through a lot of hard times and just showing a little extra love and kindness.
writecomp: When I met my little would be one of the best times that I showed compassion for someone. Tara is my pride and joy in my life right now and I have this feeling of just utmost respect; love; endearment; and adoration. I know about the things she is going through with boys and with school and I do my best to be able to help her with it all. When i found out about her dating a guy much older than her i felt compassion because I knew what she was going through. I wanted to tell her how bad of an idea it was and how I just want to protect her and be  there for her and I couldnt do that if she wouldn't let me. It is important to me to be there for her and love her but I disagreed with what she was doing.
writesymp: There was recently a house fire in my home. It was sad  and devastating and three girls lost all of their belongings. I felt so sad for them and I had no idea what to say or do. I was so happy that they were okay but I know that means nothing to them. Stuff is hard to lose especially when you have a connection with that stuff. so seeing them in pain and hurting caused me to hurt and feel pain as well. I was sad for them and I felt bad for them and I did not know what to do in that situation.
writeempat: My roommate Maria told us that her mom was a binge drinker. I knew what she was going through and I knew how to help her try and handle things. She did not want to listen to me at all but I still knew what she was going through. i hated that she wouldn't listen to me and that she did not want to take my help. I care about her and I did wanted to be there for her. I would tell her all of the things that I thought might help her and how she should handle certain situations even when she didnt want to hear what I had to say.
plove: I would not call pity love
tlove: Yes; because it is showing a warm and loving side that the person needs to have in order to get through the time that they are trying to get through.
clove: I believe that compassion is a type of love. it would be a type of unconditional; understanding love.
slove: Definitely. It is a kind of love that shows how much  you care for someone even if you cannot relate to what they are going through. You are still there for them and caring about them and their situation
elove: With empathy I would consider it a type of understanding love where you understand what is going on with people in their lives

writepity: I felt pity for my friend in a way I felt sorry for the situation he was in. In high school; he did not do his school work often as he had more dire needs to consider; he was thinking of how to acquire food and money for things he wanted. School was in the back burner. Since he struggled to find good food and was often hungry; a situation I have never been in and though of since food has always been available to me; I felt pity for him. I felt bad and sorry for him. I wanted to help him in the best way I can and I often asked him if he wanted my help or wanted any food. I bought him a doughnut before because I felt pity for him.
writetende: Tenderness is a word I would describe how I feel towards my family relatives such as my mother and brother. No matter what happens; I will always love my family and would do my up most to help and support them in time of need; but there is no sexual desire from this love. It is similar to the feeling of being on a committed team or a best friend kind of bond. I wanted to protect and support them and expected the same in return. I helped out with errands; spent time with them; and hugged them. I continually asked about their days since I was curious and shared stories to have a good conversation.
writecomp: I felt compassion for a friend I really liked. She was smart; beautiful; and kind. Since she helped me so much and spent a long time together during the day; I had feelings for her in which I believe is similar to the term of compassion. I wanted to help her in anyway I can whether it is helping out with errands or consulting. I wanted her to be happy and though often how best can I make her smile and have a good time. For me; I wanted to spend time with her; we played many board games and card games; we watched movies; we did homework and studied together; we had lunch and dinner together; and we mostly talked. I asked her what she looked forward to in the future and what she liked. We mostly shared our past experiences about our own family; mostly humorous stories.
plove: Not a kind of love.
pcontempt: true; to feel pity; you have to have some sort of connection or feeling towards them.
tlove: It would be in the form of loving a family member.
clove: It would be a serious form of love. If you feel compassion; you were proud to express that love and was determined and dedicated to keep this form of love.

writepity: Someone who was once a very close friend to me had distanced themselves from everyone. For whatever reasons; they had chosen to very selfishly start doing everything for themselves. There was always an underlying motive for whatever it was they were doing; and it wasn't out of friendship for me; or anyone else. / While at first upset; I then felt pity because obviously once everyone discovered how selfish that person had become; no one wanted anything to do with them. Even though I was hurt by the situation; I more felt sorry for them then anything; regardless if it was there fault. I could not relate to why they were doing what they were doing or what exactly they were feeling; I just knew it wasn't good and that I felt helpless to give any kind of support. / My pity turned into a kind of servitude toward them; with me thinking of it as a friendship when it was truly only me helping them with whatever it was they needed help with. I was their only person to go to; not friend; and the only time they came to me was for help. I wanted to think of myself as a friend to them; and I hoped that they were my friend too. But I was lying to myself because of the pity I felt toward them. I would often tell myself I wouldn't help them anymore if they continued to make decisions that would be considered selfish and childish. But I didn't have it in me to leave them all alone and up until  recently; continued to sacrifice for them at the expense of just about everything else; regardless of how much I ended up resenting it.
writecomp: I felt compassion for my brother when he was making mistakes in his life that seemed to be out of anyone's control. While he made these mistakes; there was this rooted feeling of caring for him; regardless of how badly he would screw up. While I was upset with him; it was always overrode with compassion and just wanting things to be better for him. My parents and I (being his older brother); did our very best to give him advice to perhaps shed some light to him on what he was doing that was so wrong and why. His continued mistakes seemed to never end; and like most of us; they  never will. However; I now feel looking back that it was our compassion for him that has dulled the severity of his mistakes and have gotten him to see what he has done so that he does not make the same mistakes again. / I was upset; annoyed and hurt by what my brother was doing to me and my family through lying. I felt he was being very selfish and unreasonable and at times; felt like giving up on him in a way. Yet the persistence of my family and I; I felt; were what truly made a difference.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for a friend who was going through a little bit of a down slide in terms of just not feeling very happy. He was for one reason or another; just not seeing the brighter side to things and I knew that feeling very well. I thought that this was something he could pull himself out of only with the help with people that cared about him; as that's the way that I know  how to best help myself when I go through periods of feeling sad. / I wanted to do all that I could to make him the jovial and happy friend he is 99% of the time. Yet the other side of me again knew that this was something I could only help him with; not help him out of. I tried my best to always reassure him that it was just a rough stage that we would get him out of; we as in me and his other friends and family; which we did.
plove: I would certainly call it a kind of love; based off of my own experiences. It would be a love that you are not in control of; it just exists and its a purposeful type of love; as in it has a goal.
pcontempt: Yes and no. I wanted to help make the situation right; therefore I felt pity. However; it is more than contempt as I wanted everything to be in my mind; the way it should be; so more than contempt.
clove: Compassion is a certain kind of love that is deeply rooted in you. For me; it was my brother; so there was from my experience; a very natural inclination and need to love him and take care of him.
slove: Sympathy would be a kind of love that you have for someone because you can not only relate to it; you can understand it and you know that what they're going through is hard; so you want to do everything you can to care for them and take care of them.

writecomp: 1) I felt compassion when my sister broke her arm and she couldn't go the the national championship in her sport. She trained hard for this competition but two weeks before she fell down the stairs and broke her arm.  /  / 2) I felt bad for her and I was really sad because I knew that the national championship was her biggest dream and that she was really sad too.  /  / 3) I wanted to help her and I wished I could have had super powers to fix her broken arm but I couldn't. It was hard for me to help her because she was really sad and she knew there was nothing we could do to make her going to the national championship. I talked to her a lot to make her feel better.
writeempat: 1) The last time I felt empathy for someone was yesterday night. My friend was really homesick and she was crying. She told me that she is missing her family and her friends from home and I felt empathy because I know exactly how it feels because I am from a different country and I am homesick all the time too.  /  / 2) I felt sad too when I saw my friend crying. It made me think of home too and I became homesick too. I felt her pain and her emotions and I could imagine myself in her position.  /  / 3) I wanted to make her feel better and to make her think of something else instead of thinking about home. I also wanted to make her feel home here and show her that I am a good friend. I first talked to her about her homesickness but then I told her that she doesn't have to be homesick because she will be home soon and that she should enjoy the good moments she has here. I explained every positive aspect about being a part of the University of Michigan. Then I talked about another topic to let her think of other things so that she doesn't have to worry about homesickness anymore. I knew that this would help because I knew how she felt cause I feel the same way all the time.
clove: It's a friendship love; a love that you give to people because you care about them and you want them to feel better.
elove: It would be a friendship kind of love because you help the person get through a hard situation.

writepity: Last week; I volunteered at a food bank in Ypsilanti with my friend. There; we organized foods by category and put them on different shelves. While we were moving cans from one shelve to another; I saw a couple of people come in. The first one I saw was a middle aged lady. The supervisor showed her around and told her that; since she had a household of 3; she was allowed this many cans of this; this many boxes of that; etc. At one point; she asked if she could have five boxes of a certain kind and the supervisor harshly said "No". I pitied that woman so very much. She seemed  very poor; a bit disheveled and avoided our eyes at all cost. I think she must have felt uncomfortable and uneasy; or maybe she thought we were judging her situation. I felt so sad at the idea that this woman does not have enough food to feed her family; while we waste so much food at the university dining halls witout remorse. I felt a sense of unfairness in this world; that some people get to have so many luxuries that they don't need; while others have barely enough to get by. I pitied her so much; but I couldn't do much for her; and reassured myself that by voulunteering at this food bank; I was helping her live a better life.
writetende: I remember my aunt once had a very bad day at work and came back home really sad and started crying and told me about what happened and how she was badly treated by her supervisor. I felt really bad for her and tried to make her feel better by gently talking thing through and hugging her when she was about to cry. I felt very close to her and had a heartbreak at the idea that anyone could treat such a nice person in such a bad way.
writesymp: Once; my best friend called me and started complaining about how she is unable to trust anyone and how she feels like everything and everyone; including her family is fake; and will one day betray her. She had had really bad memories of staying over at her grandmother's and never wanted to speak to her again. I sympathized with her situation; although I had never really felt the exact same thing; I had once had the feeling of hating everyone and everything for other reasons.
writeempat: Once I went to eat dinner with my friend. She started complaining about how college life is so difficult and how difficult it is for her to manage all the coursework while maintaining a healthy social life. I told her I felt the same way; that I was going through the same trouble; the same problems; and the same dilemmas. We complained together over some other related things; and I felt really close to her because we were living the same problems and shared a lot more than we thoguht. It also made me feel better about myself because I knew I was not the only one struggling with life!
plove: Aside from having the "protective" side of love; I would not call pity love.
pcontempt: In a sense it is; because pity comes from a sense of assessing one's situation as better than someone else's. However; it is not because pity usually leads to good actions; while contempt has negative consequences.
tlove: It is a kind of love; because it involves emotional and physical closeness. It makes you want to completely devote yourself to that person and do your best to fix the situation.
slove: It is similar to love in the way you try to understand the other person's feelings and try to make them feel better about themselves.  /
elove: I would not call this love; because you are not caring for the person; you are simply sharing feelings and experiences.

writepity: Here in Ann Arbor; I always see a homeless man sitting in the same spot over by the new Walgreens; and every time I walked past him he is holding up a sign for money. When I walk past him I feel pity for him; I feel bad for him. I know then that when I walk by I should give him some money; but I have been told that some people pretend to be homeless and make lots of money. I guess that's me being a pessimist but it's how I think. I take pity on the man when I walk by him because I wouldn't want to be in his shoes. I wouldn't want to have to sit on the street and ask college kids to give me money. I can only imagine how his pride hurts when he sits on the sidewalk. Some of these kids are extremely rich; from wealthy families all over the country; yet they have this pompous attitude that everyone is beneath them and they don't feel like they should help anyone out. It's like when I walk past the man; I want to ask him how he is doing and how he got to where he is today. It's sad that he always keeps his head down when I have walked past him. I'm not saying that he never looks up and makes eye contact with pedestrians; but I haven't seen it. It's got to be almost demeaning. I'm sure this man was successful at some point in his life; yet for some circumstances; he now sits on the street over by Walgreens and asks for money.
writetende: When I think of the word tenderness; I feel as though it means taking care of someone. Not necessarily taking care of someone but making sure they are ok and you see them through their circumstances. A time when I felt tenderness towards someone was when one of my teammates tore his ACL playing soccer. It was during a big tournament down in Dallas of spring break of my junior year in high school. This was the ideal time for players of my age; 16-17 year olds; to be scouted and recruited by college coaches. This tournament was one of the biggest of the year and practically all Division 1 college coaches would be in attendance at some point. My friend; who I won't name out of respect; wanted to play D1 soccer more than anything else. It was his dream to play D1 soccer. I had grown up playing with him since the age of 9 and we had become really close. However; his injury happened during our second game of the tournament. We were playing a team from LA and they were one of the best in the country. They were quick; fast; efficient; and hard working. The day was blistering hot and the game was at 2 pm. The field conditions were hard and choppy since it had not rained in a while. My friend was in much better shape than I am but even he was gassed. In the second half he was running back to try and stop a break away and stepped in a divot and twisted his knee and fell to the ground. He was in agony. We had to lift him off the field after the play stopped and I felt a sense of tenderness towards him. I wanted to make sure he was ok and see him through his injury.
writecomp: My grandpa recently just had surgery on his neck to alleviate pressure off his spine and to increase the blood circulation throughout his body. I went home and visited him before spring break this year and he was not doing well. His neck was in a brace; he was very loopy; he didn't each much; and he was in a lot of pain. My grandma was doing the best should could under the situation. I could tell that she was under lots of stress; from the doctors; my grandpa; and other family members. She was exhausted; yet she acted like she had just gotten back from a vacation or something. She was completely relaxed and at ease and wanted to know how I had been; not the other way around. I felt compassion towards her. I felt a bond with her because she cared how I had been and it was refreshing to know that someone was looking out for me.
plove: I don't think pity is a kind of love
pcontempt: I think this is somewhat true. If you have pity on someone; it can be perfectly fine; but sometimes too much pity can turn into contempt and then that causes problems. It's a thin line and I think its one that is difficult for most people to stay on the right side of.
tlove: I would say tenderness is a kind of love. I would say its more of a caregiver kind of love. You want to make sure the person is ok.
clove: I would definitely say that compassion is a kind of love. I think its almost like intrinsic value. I think we all have compassion towards people we care about.

writepity: 1) A time I felt pity for someone was when; in Chicago; I was walking down the street with my friends. We passed a homeless man who was asking for money. Rather than pay him cash; we walked into a nearby sandwich shop; bought him a sandwich; and handed it to him as generously as possible. Rather than appreciatively accept the sandwich; he threw it back at us and screamed; "I wanted money; not some stupid worthless food!!!" / 2) I certainly felt bad for this man. He was obviously troubled; and underwent some serious life hardships; since he was stuck here asking for money on the street. But; we had done what we could to help him and tried to avoid the situation of giving him money that he may use for alcohol and other drugs; which seems to be what he wanted. We were upset and felt for him; but at the same time; couldn't exactly stand in his shoes and try to help him any more. / 3) I wanted to tell him I felt bad for him; that he shouldn't be rude to people like that. We didn't say anything; we simply walked away. He kept yelling things at us but I didn't look back.
writecomp: 1) When my sister was in a lot of emotional trouble at the beginning of the year after getting involved with drinking at a school dance; I called her every day to see how she was doing and made sure to know that she was okay. At the same time; she was having boyfriend troubles and started to see a therapist.  / 2) I felt compassion for my sister because I wanted so badly to be able to help her and felt in part that this situation was my fault. I couldn't help but think that these things were happening because I had gone off to college and left her. I felt so much love and compassion towards her because she is my little sister and we have gone through everything together. She helps me through all my tough times and I help her with hers. To be a large and influential part of her life will always be something I want to achieve. / 3) I talked with her on the phone as much as I could and went home for a weekend to be with her. She calls me now whenever she is feeling upset and I want to be the person that is there for her; the person that can comfort her whenever she's upset.
writesymp: 1) When I was in 4th grade; my mom's dad died. We went to his funeral and my mom cried harder than I had ever seen her cry. Still; when a specific song that played at his funeral comes on; she can't help crying. / 2) This was one of the first times I experienced the concept of death; but more so; the emotion of sympathy. I put myself in my mom's shoes; and pictured my life without a mom or a dad; since my mom's mom had also passed years before. Even as an adult; I knew that I would have so much trouble getting through it and this made me really feel for my mom. I could hardly imagine experiencing what she was experiencing.  / 3) This feeling made me want to comfort her and tell her that I loved her. Whenever she hears that song; I hug her and try to comfort her because I focus on picturing myself in her position. I know how much songs can have meaning to people; as some have that same effect on me.
writeempat: 1) I felt empathy for my older brother when he got hit by a car a year ago. At that time; he was having some substance abuse problems and was drunk as he was running across the street. It was his fault for getting hit by the car-- he was too intoxicated to remember any of what happened; and he broke his pelvis and his shoulder. Today; luckily; he can walk again and he didn't receive any brain damage. My family calls what happened an incident of sheer luck-- the day we went to the hospital to see him could have been a very different day. The morning my parents received the call about him getting hit; they thought he had died. / 2) During that moment; I was feeling empathy. I knew that it was my brother's fault and I knew that; no matter how hard I tried; I couldn't put myself in his shoes. I had never gotten drunk before and couldn't understand why he would do this to himself. I felt bad for him; though. We went to the hospital to see him and he was very vulnerable. He wasn't able to do anything on his own and this made me feel upset and sad; because he is a very independent person.  / 3) Although I knew this situation had been his fault; I made sure to support him and stand by him as well as I could. Once he returned home to live in a hospital bed in our living room for two months; I spent hours talking with him and even though I didn't understand completely what he was going through; I supported him.
plove: Pity is a love where you can't really understand what the person is going through or help them much further; but simply hope that they will do something to change their ways or help themselves.
pcontempt: No-- I wouldn't necessarily say that pity is completely looking down upon someone; but rather not understanding their situation but still hoping the best for them.
clove: Compassion is a love that leads us to comforting others in their time of need; their time of vulnerability.
slove: Sympathy is a love that drives people to put themselves in others' shoes and deeply care about that other person's inner feelings.
elove: Empathy is the kind of love where you may not be able to imagine what they are experiencing; but you still support them because you see how hard a situation is for them to undergo.

writepity: I remember feeling pity towards my nanny after my parents decided that we didn't need her anymore.  My family treated her very well as if she was part of the family; however I knew that she didn't have much to go home to and her life was not very easy.  I felt as though there should be something I could do to help; but there really was not.  I offered her as much support as I possibly could.
writecomp: I remember feeling compassionate towards my sister when she was getting yelled at by our mom.  My sister often gets into trouble; but this time it was not her fault.  I showed her as much compassion as possible so that she would feel better.  I felt like she was being misunderstood; but there was no way to convince my mom of that; so all I could do was comfort my sister with compassion.
writesymp: I remember feeling sympathetic towards my friend who was sick in the hospital and needed to have surgery.  I did not feel like there was much I could do; but I felt bad for her and did everything I possibly could to make her feel loved and happy.  I baked for her; brought flowers and balloons to her room; and I could see that she really appreciated it; so I felt that I was in fact making a difference in how she felt; even though I was not technically fixing the situation.
writeempat: I remember when my good friend received a very low grade on her calculus exam.  I knew exactly how she felt because I had been through the same thing.  I was able to talk to her and help her feel better about herself through talking about my experience and explaining that I had felt the same way she did. I felt like I could help her a great deal because I had been in the same situation.
plove: If pity was a kind of love it would be because one person felt bad for the other; so they though they would benefit from love.
pcontempt: I do not think this is true; the two words do not seem related to me.
clove: I feel that a compassionate type of love would be if someone loves another based on purely caring about the other extensively.
slove: I think that showing sympathy demonstrates love; but it is not actually a kind of love.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: I felt pity toward a boy at my old high school when his mother died. His mother had been battling cancer for the past two years; and although it was expected; on the day she passed everyone was very sad. I didn't really know the boy but I felt pity for him because if I was in his shoes; I would be extremely sad. During this situation I tried to be his friend. I wanted to be able to be there for him to talk to but for a while he just didn't want to talk to anyone.
writetende: A time when I felt tenderness toward someone was when my brother didn't make the high school hockey team. He had been playing hockey his whole life as a goalie; which is the hardest position to make a team as. He played on several travel teams throughout his whole life and when he got into high school his friends convinced him to try out for the hockey team. He worked so hard at tryouts and was better than all the goalies; except one of the goalies who was trying out was the coaches son. My brother ended up not making it; which pretty much ended his hockey career. I felt tenderness toward him because I didn't know what to do or say to make the situation better. I felt like anything I said would make the situation worse.
writecomp: I felt compassion toward my grandmother when she was in the hospital. One night she had a really bad stomach ache and didn't think anything of it. The next day she was rushed to the hospital and they found that she had bacterial meningitis. My mom told me it was really serious and I was really scared. I realized how much my grandmother meant to me and that if she was gone; a part of me would be missing. I felt more compassion toward her than anyone ever and I just wanted her to be okay. The only thing I did was pray that she would be okay; and it worked because she is healthy today.
plove: Pity is the kind of love that you give to someone when they are sad; or when something tragic happens.
pcontempt: I don't really think this is true because of the fact that pity is a type of love.
tlove: I would call tenderness a gentle; delicate; caring love because when i felt tenderness for my brother; I felt bad that he didn't make the hockey team
clove: I would call compassion the kind of love that you give someone when something bad happens. They need you to reassure them that everything is okay.

writepity: In psychology class; we watched a video on these two conjoined twins. They had to live a difficult life because they were extremely different from the rest of the population and they had many physical; biological and mental challenges to overcome because they were two people attached to one body. Even though the documentary showed that they were capable of living on their own as functioning members of society; I couldn't help but feeling pity for their situation. I was feeling like I didn't exactly want to know more and I didn't really want to sympathize for the situation; because they seemed fine. It was just unfortunate they ended up having to go down that road in life. I didn't want to do anything or say anything because again; they seemed okay with their lives. I just pitied that they couldn't have a life like the rest of the population.
writetende: My boyfriend was going through a difficult time trying to figure himself out. After a particularly bad day with a lot of negativity from the world against his choices; he cried. It was the first time I'd seen him cry in all of the time I'd known him; and it was a bit frightening; because he never cried about anything. I felt like I immediately had to comfort him and make him stop crying in any way possible. I really just wanted his pain and suffering to stop; so I said nice things to him and made sure to hug him.
writesymp: In church; there was this lady who was having lots of trouble with her two sons and her family life in general. She told the congregation how her divorce with her abusive husband had messed up her relationship with her children; who have no respect for her; and who have many emotional and psychological issues due to the strained relationship of their parents. She was telling us about how taking away her eldest son's video games would warrant a fight with dirty words and physical violence; so much so that she would have to leave the house. Even though I never went through a situation like that; I couldn't help but want to understand her. Sitting there; I felt sad and horrified for her life; and also wanting to help. I didn't say anything; I thought about talking to her son and seeing if he was okay after their fight.
writeempat: It was either junior or senior year of high school; and I was hanging out with some other friends at my friend Nicole's house. I hadn't seen Nicole in a while; so I didn't really know what was going on in her life at that time. After her parents left the house; Nicole began to talk about them (her parents) and I learned that she was having a difficult time with her parents.  / I don't know if she still likes her parents or has a good relationship with them this day; but back then she was struggling with the whole family dynamic. From what I heard; she disliked her parents due to their rather dominating parenting styles. She didn't like how they had complete control over her life and their often insensitive  personalities. Another friend vouched for her that her parents were indeed control freaks. I immediately could feel empathy towards Nicole because I can relate very much to her situation. My own parents were the kind that she had to deal with; and at that time I was having a difficult time liking my parents as well. I didn't say anything in particular; except maybe that I understood how she was feeling because her experiences were like my own as well.
plove: Pity is not a kind of love
pcontempt: Yes; I think it's true. Pitying someone is not offering that person any positive emotions from the heart. When you pity someone; you feel sorry for what you think they should have by your standards. Pity is a bit like contempt because while you feel sorry for them; you don't get down to their level to try to help them.
tlove: Tenderness is a very open kind of love you willingly give to a person in need. It can be physical love or emotional support; but tenderness is felt when that person actively wants to make the situation better for the person.
slove: Sympathy is a love that you consciously want to give to that person. Even though sometimes there is nothing you can do; just the feeling of loving that person feels like it can make a difference.
elove: Empathy would be a kind of automatic love that happens without you wanting it to happen or deciding to feel it for the other person.

writepity: A time I felt pity towards someone is when the Los Angeles Lakers lost in the playoffs in horrible fashion last year to the San Antonio Spurs. The series was extremely brutal and one-sided and I was embarrassed to be a Lakers fan. I felt badly that they had done so poorly in playing and I wished more than anything that the situation would change but it didn't. I wanted everything to change. I wanted to be able to help and go back in time but I couldn't. I just sat there in disbelief and said how mad I was and yelled at the television even though I knew it wouldn't change anything.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards someone when I was dating their ex-girlfriend. They had been broken up for  a while and it wasn't someone that I was extremely close with; but every time we saw each other it was a bit awkward and uncomfortable. I was feeling kind of embarrassed and a little mean. I wanted to fix the situation and make it less awkward but I just kind of ignored it and moved past it with out saying anything. I kind of just let it be and the situation only got more and more awkward each time it happened and now I don't see either of these people anymore because I don't go to high school with them anymore.
writecomp: When one of my friends accomplished something he had been working on for years was a time I felt compassion. At summer camp; every year; one of my best friends Jacob had been trying to hit a bulls-eye in archery. When we were 10 years old; he could barely hit the target at all. The next summer; he could hit the target with ease but he wouldn't come close to getting a bulls-eye. The next year after that; he finally hit the bulls-eye and I was so proud that he had accomplished this. I was personally feeling happy and proud because my friend had accomplished something. It was if I was sharing his emotional state of happiness with him. I wanted to cheer and scream. I got up and clapped and told him congratulations on a job well done.
writesymp: a time I felt sympathy for someone was when they showed the families of the passengers Malaysian flight 370 on the news. They were all screaming and crying and I felt really bad for them but there was nothing I could do. I wanted to help; but I was no where near them; I didn't know them; and there was simply no way I could help. I felt very helpless which made me feel sad and trapped. Because I was sharing emotions with people who I didn't know personally it was hard for me to find a real emotional bond between us.I ind of just sat there and watched feeling sorry but not taking any action.
writeempat: A time I felt empathy toward someone was when my grandpa; my mom's dad passed away. I was in high school and my grandpa had been in bad shape for a few years now. My mom and the rest of my family had to watch his decline over the years. When he finally passed; my mom was very upset. A little depressed and sad at most times also; I felt her pain. I felt the same emotions she was feeling when I was around her and was talking to her. I wanted to be able to fix the situation; but there was nothing I could do. I felt helpless. I was there to console her; talk to her; and try to bring her out of the sad state she was in. I talked with her about what she wanted to saying what I felt would brighten her mood.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: No I do not think this is true
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: I would not call compassion a kindof love
slove: The love of someone you don't know personally because they have gone through a difficult time.
elove: Empathy is the kind of love you feel when you can identify with someone who you have a very close personal relationship with.

writepity: I would say that I most likely felt pity in almost a sarcastic situation.  I would have to say I felt pity when my friend's boyfriend had another girl trying to talk to him.  I felt pity towards the other girl because they boyfriend had talked to her all the time before he dated my friend; and she kept trying to talk to him when he was dating my friend.  My friend's boyfriend told her to leave him alone since he now had a girlfriend.  Since the girlfriend was my friend; I didn't feel to bad for the other girl especially since she was talking to my friend's boyfriend.  But at the same time; I felt somewhat bad for her because the guy had gotten her hopes up.
writetende: I would most likely associate a tenderness experience for one about my mom.  This can be more of a general feeling; but I will describe a specific one.  When I found out my mom was married before she had me to someone else whom died of Lou Gehrig's disease; I knew she needed someone to care for her.  Since it happened so long ago; she didn't want me to feel bad for her; she just wanted some tenderness. I was supporting and I stood by her side and was loving and caring. I hugged her and held her as we sat on the couch after she told me this.  She wasn't crying; she was just appreciating my tender loving care.
writecomp: I felt compassionate towards someone when I told them I was in love with them.  My ex-boyfriend would be the best experience I can tell about having compassion towards someone.  I would say that I had been developing some strong feelings for him that grew by the day; and this is what I consider compassionate.  The feelings I had through this compassion were how strongly I cared about him; how nice I was to him; and the fact that I fell in love with him. I knew how compassionate I felt in the exact moment that I told him I loved him.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for the person I like to consider my second mom.  She had a step son my age whom I was pretty good friends with.  Junior year of high school; a tragic event that was unexpected happened.  He committed suicide.  Nothing was wrong with him; and he showed now signs of why he did it.  He was one of the nicest; most popular; well known kids at the school and in town.  After everything happened; I stood by my second mom as much as possible.  I was always there for her to give her my sympathy for this horrible; sad situation.  After he was buried; I showed her my sympathy by helping her put a flower on his casket and helped her walk away from something no one should have to walk away from.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love because it doesn't really associate the emotions you get from love with it.
pcontempt: I would have to disagree with this. Contempt means being happily satisfied.  Pity has nothing to do with happy or satisfied feelings.
tlove: I would consider tenderness a kind of love because it involves some strong caring emotions.  It wouldn't be the kind of love you describe as falling in love; it would be more so of the love you have towards family members and sometimes friends.
clove: I would describe it as the type of love as falling in love with a partner.  I wouldn't compare it to loving your friends and family.
slove: I would categorize sympathy as a kind of love. It would also be one more so towards family members and friends rather than falling in love.  You feel sympathy towards someone because you love them; not because you are in love with them.

writepity: I feel pity towards someone who doesn't try in school or in sports and expects results. It was my High school roommate for a while. He wasn't naturally smart; but he was an unbelievable athlete with a lot of talent. He never put the time in the gym; but he always expected results. I pitied him because he always expected to get things without doing anything. I was feeling like there was not much I could do besides feel bad he didn't workout and therefore never felt satisfied with his results. I wanted to get him to work hard; but I can't be a motivator to a person; it's an internal motivation one needs to have. I just didn't acknowledge when he was all down on himself; because I knew he had it in him to achieve his goals.
writetende: My grandmother had terrible accident that eventually led to her death. I felt tenderness toward my mom and her sisters as the mental state of my grandmother in the hospital was a disaster. She suffered a stroke and a bad brain bleed. She was not mentally the same person and each time my mom went to visit it became emotional. I never want to experience a time where my mom isn't the person I know her as. I was thinking about trying to comfort her; but that was more of my  dad's role. It was just a tough feeling for me too; but obviously way worse for my mom. We as a family didn't end up talking about the situation too much until her passing. My brother; sister; and I all went to a school away from home and therefore only saw our parents every few weeks. My mom seemed to improve as my grandmother was on a slow road to recovery; but I still felt bad.
writecomp: I feel compassion when we have our family reunions as I always want help and make it as fun as possible for my 40 younger cousins. I was feeling and thinking like the more energetic and excited I am; the better time I will have and the better time my younger cousins would have. What I did is acted energetic and got involved in the most meaningless and stupid activities. I would always pump up the group and make them excited to do their best.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my brother when he had his two open heart surgeries. HE was going through a tough time and I felt bad that he was going through all of these surgeries that kept him out of contact sports and caused him to be inactive for a long time. I didn't know why this happened to him and why I was perfectly fine. I sympathized him when I was able to go to summer camp that summer and when I was able to compete in contact sports. I felt genuinely bad for him. I would never wish this upon someone. The only thing I really could do to show my support was to get pricked by a needle for his INR machine to show him that it didn't hurt. Now it doesn't really affect him too much; but at the time I felt bad for him.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards Jordan Morgan last night as it was his last game as a Basketball player. I watched his interview as he got very emotional and with the tears going down his face as he answered questions from reporters. He said it was the most fun he had ever had playing basketball and that this was an unbelievable group of guys. He was proud of his accomplishments; but you could tell he was not ready to move on from basketball. I didn't really have a feeling to relate to because although I played sports in high school; it was more of the moving on to college that gave me this nostalgic feeling then actually becoming best friends with a group of guys. Also; the main sport I competed in was skiing; which is an individual sport. There was nothing I really wanted to do at this moment. I just watched the interview and it gave me the chills watching him get all emotional. I felt empathy that he would never get to play competitively the game he loves so much. It was like watching Brett Favre retire from professional football.  /
plove: No I would not say pity is love.
pcontempt: Don't really know what this means. SO i would say no to be safe.
tlove: I think it does involve some type of love. I would say it's a friendship/family love.
clove: I wouldn't say compassion is a type of love
slove: Love of something or someone.
elove: If empathy was love; it would be a relatedness love. Like a I know what you are going through type of love.

writepity: I went to McDonald's and a man about the same age as my father was working on the fryer. Seeing this man working a job that should be for someone in high school; I felt sorry for him. I automatically assumed that he was capable of working in a job that was better in pay and prestige. I wanted to help him find another job. However; I did nothing and said nothing.
writetende: When I talk on the phone with my father; I get a feeling of tenderness. Our conversations are short and to the point; but when he expresses how proud he is of my; I feel really good. The short conversation can change my whole mood for the better.
writeempat: A friend is taking care of her bed ridden father. He has been suffering from an illness for years and it is now entering its final stages. My friend watches him almost around the clock. She has little time to do anything else outside of school and work. She rarely has time for herself. I want to help her in any way that I can; so whenever I see her I try to cheer her up. Sometimes I take her out to dinner or to see a movie.
plove: I wouldn't call it love.
pcontempt: I don't think this is true.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love
elove: Empathy is not love.

writepity: I felt pity for the homeless man I saw on the street the other day.
writetende: I don't ever feel tenderness?
writecomp: When I volunteered at a senior living facility and worked with residents who had dementia and Alzheimer's disease; I felt compassion. I wanted to understand and care for the residents and truly cared about them. Many people would not like to spend time with them because of their low-functioning lifestyles but I felt compassionate towards their situation and making their lives better. I did not "love" them but I did feel passionate about caring for them.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my mom when her cousin died. I felt badly for her; could understand her emotions; and though I was sad for my own reasons; felt invested in her sadness. I didn't really express this sympathy aside from trying to comfort her and be kind although we weren't  in the same vicinity.
writeempat: I felt empathy toward my friend when she failed an important exam. I could understand her situation; as I've failed exams before and understood how unfortunate it was to fail an exam. I did not actually feel sad and had no personal investment in her feelings or the situation. I understood and could empathize with her situation; I said "I'm so sorry this happened; that really sucks; maybe you can get help for next time; etc."
plove: Pity is NOT a kind of love
pcontempt: A little bit true yes. Pity does not bring about sadness or understanding so maybe it is closest to contempt.
tlove: Maybe? I don't really understand tenderness but I'd say its a softness of your heart which could be love; but I'm really not sure as I've never felt it. (that's why I answered "not at all" to all the previous answers)
clove: I guess it would be a kind of love; but a love from outside the situation not in it - it's a one way street; I feel compassionate towards something but that something does not feel it back.
slove: Sympathy is not love.
elove: Empathy is not a kind of love

writepity: I felt pity when a friend of mine was dumped by his girlfriend of two years. People suspected that she had been cheating on him for some time and me and some of my other friends warned him of this. He didn't believe us and stayed in the relationship. His girlfriend at the time was being unloyal but he remained in love with her. Then one day; she decided enough was enough. She left him and told him that she had been messing around with other men. I told my friend before and felt pity for him because he had to get his heart broken by such an unloyal woman.
writecomp: My Grandmother was diagnosed with cancer earlier this year. When I went to see her after her chemotherapy treatment; I felt overwhelming compassion as I embraced her. She means a lot to me and taught me many things in life. Compassion is showing unconditional love to someone. I wanted to hold her longer because I can't imagine losing her from my life. I told her I missed her and I hope she gets better.
writesymp: When a friend of mine lost his grandma to cancer I felt sympathy toward him and his situation. I have also lost family to the illness and I knew how he felt about it. I knew it is a tough thing to have happen and I tried my best to comfort him. I told him that everything will get better in the future and that he wouldn't be sad forever. I helped him come to terms with the situation because I know how difficult it can be. I offered him support and friendship
plove: pity is not a type of love
pcontempt: Pity is not an angry emotion. It is simply feeling bad that something happened to someone
clove: Compassion would be unconditional love
slove: Sympathy is a type of love where you understand what the other person went through. It arises when a loved one of yours suffers from a loss of any kind

writepity: I felt pity towards someone when I was in high school. There was this kid who failed the 10th grade and i had pity on him because i didn't think he deserved what was happening to him. The things that were causing the situation were out of his control and he was doing the best he could. He was a pretty good acquaintance and he told me a lot of what was going on; and i felt pity on him because i thought he could of done better.
writetende: I felt tenderness toward a homeless man when i went to the Detroit Red Wings game when I was much younger. The way he was dressed; and the facial expression that he had made me feel tender towards him. It made me feel exposed; and it really put me in his shoes; it was an eye opening experience. I felt really bad for the guy; it was snowing; and it was cold. All i could think about was how he was going to sleep; and survive out in the cold for the night; and i wanted to help him; but i didnt know how to. I just felt really bad for him.
writecomp: During my senior year at prom i felt very compassionate towards my girlfriend. I wanted to make the night as best as it could be. I felt excited; and happy to have her; lucky to have someone that cares about me so much as i care about them. I thought about how i just wanted it go perfect; with no problems at all because i thought thats how it ought to be. I wanted to just make her smile; and laugh all night. We danced; and had a great time all night. I said sweet; and nice things and we had a very good time at prom that night.
plove: Pity is not love
pcontempt: I think it is true because in order for it to be similar to contempt you have to have standards for something. When some standards are not met; you then have pity on someone.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: I think it is love

writepity: I have a friend who is very nice; kind; and has a good heart; but can be very annoying and overwhelming. She is very clinging and attached and does not stop talking. It bugs me and a lot of my friends when she constantly asks to hang out and make plans when we don all enjoy spending time with her because it gives us anxiety/ However; I feel bad for her because she does not get invited to a lot of things and she becomes excluded. I dont want her to feel isolated so at times; I invite her out because I do feel bad that she is not apart of our plans.
writetende: I cant remember the last time I felt tenderness towards someone
writecomp: One of my friends told me her story about how her mother died. I immediately felt pain for her and couldnt imagine what its like to loose a parent at a young age. I felt so bad for her; and although ive never lost a parent; I felt her pain and anguish
writeempat: Whenever someone talks about their parent's divorce; I immediately empathize for them. My parent's were in a very messy and long divorce; lasting 11 years. I was put in the middle and caught in a nasty custody battle involving money and material items. When someone starts to talk about their parents divorce; I always understand the circumstance and what they had gone through. I am very good at talking to friends who are having a hard time with their parents who fight over the children. I've learned exactly how to convey my emotions successfully to my parent's and know how to make independent decisions. Regarding my friends' anxiety over her parents; I am able to talk her worries out and reason with her why her parents are acting so differently or out of control. I've experienced years of this drama and am very capable of making sense of it.
plove: i would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: No
elove: A kind of love associated with understanding and compassion. To understand someone's struggles give us greater insight into that person and their behaviors

writetende: My little sister is a senior in high school now; and is currently dealing with the college application process.  As most high school students do; I vividly remember how horrible this process was and how emotional and stressful it could be.  Although I know that she had to just suck it up and get through this horrible process; when she would complain to me about being stressed out I felt tenderness towards her.  I know that this situation is not all that bad and is necessary in the long run but I understood how unpleasant it was. All I could do was be supportive and tell her about how I faced this challenging process myself and got through it.
writecomp: One of my best friends and roommates here at school just recently broke up with her boyfriend of over 2 years after she found out that he had been cheating on her.  She called me crying and asked if I could come home to talk things out with her.  In my on dating life I have encountered heartbreak like and breakups and know how difficult they can be; especially when they end on poor terms like her long term relationship did.  Understanding the pain that she is likely feeling and by knowing how  painful breakups can be I felt compassion for her; I was sorry she was feeling this way because I understood how hard it can be and wanted to help.  I immediately went home to console her and tried to make her feel better.
writesymp: One of my friends boyfriends (whom I know but not on a very close personal basis) recently lost his father to a stroke.  I have; thankfully; never experienced the death of a parent and can only imagine how horrible and sad of an experience that must be.  When I encountered him; I felt very honestly sorry for his loss but felt helpless to improve the situation.  There was nothing I felt that I could do other than send him my condolences and offer any assistance he may need.
tlove: I think that tenderness is a type of love.  In order to feel tenderness for someone you need to care about them enough that you feel badly if they are experiencing unpleasant situations; even if they are not that severe.
clove: I would not say compassion is a type of love but rather than it is based on love. I do not think you could have compassion for someone unless you love them enough to really care about them and want them to be better and improve their situation.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.  Although you need to feel positively enough about someone to feel sorry enough that they are in a bad situation to experience sympathy; I do not think it is based on love necessarily.

writepity: I feel pity for the people back home that have not done anything with their lives after high school.  Many of my classmates have not gotten "real" jobs; haven't gone to any type of college; nor have they attempted to do anything.  They sit around and do nothing but drink and do drugs; not looking towards the future.  One of these kids is my best friend from growing up and I always try to encourage him to get moving by saying stuff like; "you don't do shit; when are you going to do something."   I feel that there is so much wasted potential in these people and it sort of pisses me off.
writecomp: Working at the homeless shelter my church does every year I always feel compassion.  the people that come always need help and are for the most part very thankful.  Many of the people have fallen on hard times due to issues beyond their control. I always feel proud of the way my community comes together to help others; it always puts a smile on my face.  We feed them; talk with them; and generally try to make them forget about their worries.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my towards my best friend when his mom was diagnosed with cancer.  I felt sad that his family had to go through that and my friends and I supported him through out the best we could.
plove: Caring love
pcontempt: You compare your life to theirs
clove: Caring; generous love
slove: Caring love

writepity: I pitied my friend when he tried to ask a girl out and she said "no" and walked away. I was feeling sorry for him partly because the girl said no; and partly because she made him look like a fool. He was very embarrassed so I gave him a hug and told him he would find a nicer girl than that anyway. I wanted to make him feel better so we went and got ice cream. He was still upset; but he got over it when he started eating the ice cream.
writetende: One time I felt tenderness towards a friend who was having problems with his girlfriend. She is a senior in high school deciding whether to go to the University of Michigan or Oberlin. My friend (her boyfriend) goes to the University of Michigan and desperately wants his girlfriend to pick U of M so she won't have to move away to Oberlin. I felt tenderness towards him the day that he got in an argument with his girlfriend because he started crying and was obviously hurt and sensitive. I usually tease him and play mean jokes on him; but that day I was kind and backed off. I gave him space and let him know I was there to talk to if he needed a friend.
writesymp: I was sympathetic to my friend when her grandfather died. She had been very close to her grandfather and was understandably devastated when he passed away. However; I could not relate to her situation; since my grandparents have been dead since before I was born. Therefore; I could only have sympathy for her (not empathy). I gave her a hug and told her if she ever needed or wanted to talk to someone about it; she could talk to me. I also told her If she didn't want to talk about it and just needed a friend she could talk to me.
writeempat: I once felt empathy towards a friend who was sick with mononucleosis and had to miss a few weeks of school to recover. I felt empathy towards them because I had previously contracted the same illness a couple of years earlier. I was feeling sad on their behalf because I could relate to their situation. I told them "I feel your pain; I had mono in 8th grade and had to make up a few weeks' worth of work when I finally got better." I was hoping that sharing my experiences with them would make them feel better; or at least show them that someone else could put themselves in their shoes (relate to them).
plove: pity is not a type of love. Pity is just feeling sorry for somebody and their situation. You can pity someone without loving them -- for example. you can pity someone but feel that they are a pathetic excuse for a human being. This would not be considered love.
pcontempt: It can be. Sometimes people may pity someone who they deem to be less worthy than they are. For example; people may pity someone who is unemployed but also feel that it's that person's own fault or that that person is just less competent than they are.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a type of love; but rather a way to care about someone in a sensitive and kind manner.
slove: Sympathy is not a type of love. Sympathy is just a way of feeling sorry for someone and wishing they weren't in the situation that they are in.
elove: empathy is a kind of love where people feel comforted by someone who can relate to or understand what they are going through.

writepity: It is not so much a particular situation; but many instances.  There was a person at my high school that always attempted to be the class clown.  Now although many people would label him as this; the things he would say and do got very repetitive.  I eventually began to feel bad because he was trying so hard to be funny.  I wanted to tell him to take it easy with the jokes; but i did not in fear of hurting his feelings.
writecomp: One instance where i felt compassionate was towards one of my close friends.  She is a member of the dance team here at Michigan.  One day she had not responded until it was very late in the day; and when she did text me; it was not something good.  All that was sent was a frowning face made from a colon and an open parentheses.  She explained to me that a partner of hers in a dance dropped her during a lift; and that she had broken her elbow.  The reason this was so bad was because the tryouts for the 2014-2015 year were just around the corner.  She had no idea how long this injury would restrain her from her best performance.  All she could think was that if she did not make the team; she would be letting down herself as well as her family who holds unrealistic expectations over her. The only thing i could do was comfort her and help her think everything was going to be okay.  Overall i just felt compassion for her and the predicament that she was now in.  I did not know how long this type of injury would last; or how much it would affect her dancing ability; which put my thoughts at the worst place.  Even though i assumed that this injury would last until the tryouts; i still insisted everything would be fine.  I told her that it was going to be the exact same as last year; in terms of her tryout; and that there was know way she would still be feeling pain by time tryouts rolled around.  By comforting her and feeling for her; i felt compassionate because it was easy for me to imagine myself in a similar situation with the sport i am in.
writeempat: My close friend was competing over seas and had been training very hard for this moment.  When he did not win the tournament; i felt empathetic.  There was nothing that i could say or do in the situation; because it was in his control.
plove: No i believe that pity is feeling bad for someone; but not on an emotional level.
pcontempt: No
clove: I do not think it is a kind of love; i believe that it is just supporting someone in a time of emotional distress.
elove: No i believe it is relating to someone in a personal way for things that were out of your control; yet in the other person's control.

writepity: I have felt pity when I see a homeless person.  Thinking about how they ended up where they are and what they have gone through really gets to me.  I feel terrible for them sitting in the cold with ragged clothes on.  I would call this pity because every time I see them I wish I could help them; but most of the time I just continue on my way.
writecomp: A few months ago; a family that is really close to my own lost their grandfather.  Our families have been close for basically my whole life.  The other family own a huge family farm; and everyone in that family works together every day; either in the office or in the fields.  And their grandpa was the center of the whole operation.  A huge part of their lives were taken from them overnight.  I went home that weekend to go to the funeral; and the whole time I was home my family was doing something for the theirs.  Whether it was making them dinner; watching their young child; or just offering support.  Even though the weekend was full of sorrow; I feel like we helped the situation as much as we could.
writeempat: My cousin and I were both on our high school wrestling team.  It was his junior year and my sophomore year; and we were wrestling one of our biggest rivals.  During his match; a freak accident occurred and my cousin broke his ankle and tore all the ligaments in the ankle area.   Neither my cousin nor I enjoyed wrestling; and both of us were three sport athletes.  He had to miss the entire baseball season that year and it was questionable if he would be able to play football again in the fall.  On top of it all; his family had been going through a rough time and didn't really have the money to pay for his surgery and time in the hospital.  I would have done anything to help him and his family out; but there was nothing I could do.  It was awful.
plove: I would not call pity a love.
pcontempt: I don't really know.  When I think of pity; I think of feeling bad for a person but at the same time blaming that person for the circumstances at hand and not doing anything myself to help take care of the person.
clove: Compassion to me is absolutely love.  It's understanding the situation; understanding the feelings someone else is going through (and possibly feeling the same way); and then doing everything in your power to improve the situation.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I guess I would call it a love.  But it's more like when you're really close to someone and really love them and then something terrible happens and you cannot do anything about it.  It's such a strong feeling that it eats at you for a while; but there is nothing that anyone can do about the situation.

writepity: One time I was meeting with my friend for coffee; and her boyfriend decided to come by and say hi to us.  They had recently broken up and then after a few months they got back together again; so he wanted to say hi to me as a way of kind of apologizing for how he acted when they broke up and in an effort to be friends again.  He is very insecure about himself and that causes him to say some pretty awful things sometimes in order to try to impress others.  We had started out by talking about how classes were going and things like that; and then he brought up a research proposal he was thinking about writing.  He went on to tell me that he wanted to prove that it is better from a public health standpoint to not have law requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets; because then we could just kill off all of the stupid people.  He was kind of kidding but mostly not; and at this point I felt bad for him; but not in a way that I could sympathize with him.  I felt extremely embarrassed for him and upset that his insecurities would cause him to say dumb things like this; so I pitied him. /  / What I wanted to do in this situation was yell at him and tell him how dumb that comment was and that he couldnt be serious; but I felt badly for him and I sympathized with my friend (his girlfriend) so I just looked at him for a bit and he could tell that I did not like what he had to say; so we moved on to talking about something else.
writetende: One time when I felt tenderness was when my boyfriend made me a CD full of music that we had listened to together throughout our first year of dating.  He wrote a little bit about each song and said what he remembered had been going on at the time when we were listening to the song most; and it made me feel a kind of tenderness toward him.  I already knew that he really cared about me from other experiences; but I was feeling really tender in this moment when I could look back on all that had happened in a year with him and know that he remembered it all and that it was really important to him too.
writecomp: Compassion is more of a positive emotion to me than empathy or sympathy.  Compassion can be when you try to feel someones emotions and understand what they are feeling; even if it is not a sad time.  One example of this was the other weekend when my brother won a race at the high school state meet.  It was such a big deal for him and he had worked to heard to get there; so when he won I ended up thinking about his feelings and about what he must have been thinking for the many months leading up to this moment.  I was not only proud of him; but I also had an idea of how he was feeling and I was so happy that he was feeling it.
writesymp: Continuing with the situation mentioned in Pity; I felt very sympathetic toward my friend who I was getting coffee with.  I knew that she had been having a hard time with her boyfriend and that he wasnt being very nice to her.  He had changed from how he used to be around her and me; and she was having a hard time figuring out what to do about it. It was hard for me to feel empathetic toward her when she was telling me about the hard time she was having with her boyfriend because I had such a hard time figuring out what she would keep dating him; but I felt badly for her and could extend my experiences to relate to how she was feeling; and I wanted her situation to get better.
writeempat: I felt empathy toward one of my friends a couple of weeks ago when his rabbit died.  I could empathize with him because I had a pet dog that died a few years ago and I remembered exactly how that felt.  We were both really close with our pets and considered them great friends; and I could directly relate with how he felt when his rabbit died. It was more than just being sympathetic toward him; because I felt that I had a better idea of how he felt and I could imagine it; rather than just feeling sorry that it happened.
pfeltother: 1. I was feeling sympathetic toward my friend whose boyfriend was talking / 2. I was feeling anger toward her boyfriend / 3. I was feeling happy that I am not dating someone who says things like that
plove: I would not really call it love
pcontempt: Kind of. When I felt pity I didnt do anything; but I was still angry.
tlove: I think it is a kind of love. It is feeling love for someone based on a situation or something they have done.
clove: I would say that it is a kind of love because you are trying to relate with someone about a larger variety of emotions than empathy or sympathy; and you arent just caring about them when they feel bad.
slove: I would say that it is a kind of love. It is caring about someone even though you cant completely relate with their hardship.
elove: I think it is a kind of love.  It is taking the time to relate someones situation to a situation that you have had; and trying to bring yourself back to that situation to better relate with theirs at that time.

writepity: I felt pity when I was confronted by a homeless person on the street. Instead of asking me for money; she told me that she was hungry and asked for something to eat. She looked like she could be someone's mother. I felt terrible for her. I could not possibly refuse this request. I wanted to give her much more; but we went to Jimmy Johns and I bought her some food. She thanked me and I told her "you're welcome" and that was it.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my sick mother. She looked so helpless as she was lying in bed. The woman who had cared for me and loved me for my entire life now looked weak lifeless in bed. I wanted to do whatever I could do to help her. I fulfilled her every need. I got her food; water; and whatever else she needed until she was feeling better.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards another girl because I had a crush on her. My thoughts were jumbled every time I saw her. I wanted to go up to her and confront her and say all the right things. I sent her a valentines day card; but I didn't really say anything to her after that.
writesymp: My most recent feeling of sympathy towards someone was when one of my close friend's grandmother died. He has lost other members of his family recently as well and this just made things worse. I know if my grandmother died would not know what to do. He is one of the most funniest and kindest friends I have. I felt extremely sad that this happened; especially in such a short time period. I wanted to say something that might cheer him up; or do anything within my power that would help. All I could think of was to tell him that I was there for him and that he could come to me if he wanted to talk. I told him that I was sorry for his loss.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: It can be true based on someone's perspective. If they see someone else who they pity; then it may or may not cause them to be contempt with their own lives.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love on would express towards people who are close to them and who are in need or just weaker than them.
clove: Compassion is a kind of love that one would have towards a potential mate.
slove: It would be the kind of love you have towards a close friend. Like a brotherly love.

writepity: A couple of kids vandalized some property in my home town.  They cause a large amount of damage and made people very upset.  I felt sorry for them but in a negative way.  I looked down upon them for what they had done.  What they had done made me upset but I felt sorry for them that everyone looked down upon them after they were caught.
writetende: After one of my friends broke up with his girlfriends I felt tenderness towards him.  I felt sad for him and I wanted to make him feel better.  I tried to be happy when I was around him so I could try and not make him think about it.  I wanted to do anything he need for him to feel better.  I felt bad for him because he loved his girlfriend.
writecomp: A girl from my home town passed away.  I knew the girl's sister decently well and after the passing I felt compassion for the girl; Jackie.  I felt very badly for Jackie after losing someone she was extremely close with.  Because nothing like that has ever happened to me; I was unable to completely understand how she was feeling.  However; I did feel extremely sad for her.  I wanted to reach out to her via text but I figured that she was being bombarded with texts from others.  I wanted to help her in any way that she needed; from school work to taking her out to a movie to clear her mind.  I just wanted to make her feel better.
writeempat: One of my friends; Giankarlo; played basketball and was very passionate about the sport.  He was hoping to play in college so that he could afford to go to school.  Unfortunately; in the first game of his senior season he suffered a knee injury.  I also suffered a very similar injury while I was playing.  We have both experience how an injury affects you mentally because you are unable to do something you love to do which is play sports.  I was able to put myself into Giankarlo's shoes and understand exactly what he was feeling. I reached out to him to help him deal with his injury because I had been through something like that.
plove: I would not call pity a type of love
pcontempt: I do think this is slightly true because pity and contempt have similar connotations
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love.  You have to have that "soft side" to have that relationship with someone.
clove: Compassion is a kind of love in the sense that you deeply care for the people you love.
elove: I would call empathy a kind of love because you have to be able to put yourself in the person you love's shoes and understand exactly what they are feeling

writepity: I felt pity towards my brother recently who was kicked out of his school for a semester. We'll say he did some bad things and the school decided to take action. So now he is back at home this semester with a part-time job living with my family. I felt angry and upset that he was wasting the money of those trying to help pay his way through school. I also felt disappointed with how he was handling his life and not taking it seriously. I didn't do anything because I can't really do anything at this point except talk to him. However; I don't think he will take me very seriously nor do I want to waste my time with it anyway.
writetende: Again; not really sure of this a good way of thinking of tenderness. But I think I felt tenderness toward a friend who injured themselves. They like to run and weren't able to for some time after the injury. And then when she recovered; we went for a run together. I was glad that they were back to themselves and we could enjoy something we both love to do together. I felt bad for them originally when it happened.
