But instead of running when she was injured; I kept her company and did other things.
writecomp: I'm not really sure if I'm thinking of a good defintion for compassion. But I think I felt compassion towards a friend who took the lead of a project team I'm working on. We really needed someone to organize and take command of the team in order to make progress and not many people wanted to do it. I felt like I wish I had his talents and skills to do such a thing because he would make a good team lead. Part of me also didn't want to make that type of committment. So I'm just continuing with the team as someone that just helps toward the project itself.
writesymp: A time that I felt sympathy was when my friend failed his class last semester. I felt sympathy because he was a really good friend of mine and we worked on the same project team. The projects were worth about 50% of the final grade and a great deal of time is spent working on the projects. To have put so much effort into a class and then getting no credit made me really sympathize towards him. I really didn't know what to say cause I did well from the exams and we both got the same project scores so I didn't want him to become really jealous of me. I just was like "that's awful; I'm really sorry; are you going to try to take it again?" He just really worked very hard for the class and the grade doesn't show it.
writeempat: I recently went on a spring break trip to the Grand Canyon. We camped in it for 5 nights. On the second to last day we were there; one of my friends hurt his knee. While he was able to walk; he was much more slow and in slight pain. I empathized towards him. I could understand what he was feeling. He is a great friend of mine and really was loving this spring break trip. So what happened was we just had to really take our time in hiking out the last day and he felt a decent amount of pain. I offered my assistance to help in any way as I could to give him the best last day experience. So I took on some his weight that he had in his backpack. Therefore I was carrying a heavier bag in order to help him along better.
plove: no love
pcontempt: I'm not sure what akin means.
tlove: friendly; warming love
clove: love like respect
slove: not call sympathy love
elove: not a kind of love

writepity: I had a friend; Lauren; all throughout highschool. We actually met about a week before our freshman year started. Lauren and I were good friends; but we didn't spend that much time together outside of school (she lived far away). / One night; she messaged me on skype. Perhaps the fact that she was chatting me and not video calling me speaks to the somewhat separated nature of our friendship; she never really confided in me (or anyone).  /  / She started by saying something like "Patty; I don't know what to do". I don't remember exactly; but it got me a bit worried. She then said "I think my parents are just waiting until [my brother] and I graduate to get a divorce". This shocked me; not in that I was very surprised; but more in the way that I was completely unprepared for a statement of that nature. My parents have fought a lot before; and one time I physically stopped my mom from walking out. /  / Although I felt like a bad friend for it; I pitied Lauren. I felt like there was nothing i could do; and the fact that she was chatting me and putting it rather bluntly made me feel very separated and not empathetic. I didn't feel bad really. I just felt pity for her; in her awful situation; but not in a way that i would be sad myself.
writetende: I met a boy in October. We hit it off pretty quickly. When winter break rolled around; he went back home to California; and I stayed in Ann Arbor with my family. We were texting each other a lot over the break. I think at one point it would be something like 900 messages a day. We were "together" in that we weren't really dating anyone else; and we had said the "I love you"'s to each other; but I still wasn't really sure if it was romantic love I was feeling; or deep love towards a friend you are really close to. I could say for sure that I wasn't IN love with this boy. /  / One day I woke up to a text from him saying good morning or something like that. He went on to tell me that he had a dream about me saying that we went sledding together and built a snowman then went inside and sat by a fire and drank hot chocolate. He ended with "and when I woke up I was sad cause you weren't there next to me." /  / I felt a huge warm tenderness towards him right then. It was like hot chocolate; just a warm glow; all happy; almost to the point where I got choked up (I missed him a lot too). I almost got choked up now just thinking about it.
writecomp: There was this kid; his name was Grant; who was on my swim team with me. He was two years below me in highschool (I was a senior and he was a sophomore). Grant was my favorite underclassman. He worked hard for the sake of working hard. He didn't skip practice; and he aspired to be a great part of the team. /  / One day; practice was cancelled; so Grant; my friend Anthony; and I went to go swim at Eastern's pool just to get a workout in. Before we got in the pool; I asked Grant if he wanted to grab some food with Anthony and I after swimming; and he said no; he had to watch a movie with his brother and his brother's girlfriend. /  / Later on; I was joking around that Anthony and I would follow him to the movies and sit behind them just to bother them; and Grant said "Why would you do that? You hate the people I'm going with." /  / This was followed by a rather awkward pause and then I said "You're brother? I haven't even met him" /  / Grant looked taken aback and then his face changed to something like an "Oh shit" face. I started laughing and sprinted down to the other end of the pool. I felt compassion towards him because I still loved Grant (as a friend/brother figure); but I felt a little bad for him too; being in such an awkward situation.
writesymp: My friend Grace lost her mom when we were both in fourth grade. I wasn't that close to Grace. Sometimes I would play with her afterschool; and she was on my volleyball team. Everyone knew that her mom walked out on her; her brother; and her dad; went to Texas and shot herself in a hotel. But nobody (except maybe her closest friends but certainly not me) heard her recount the story herself. /  / Sometimes when I was talking to Grace I wouldn't remember; and we would just play like normal; but every time something reminded me of the traumatic event; I felt sympathy towards her. The event was so big that I couldn't even begin to understand it; and she never confided in me; so I couldn't really empathize; but I sympathized all the same. I wished that the bad thing hadn't happened to her; and that she could be happy like me.
writeempat: There was this guy I "liked" in highschool. He started "liking" me first I suppose. He would always do nice things for me; like give me his jacket when I was cold; stuff like that. But at some point I gave him the message that I wasn't really ready for any kind of relationship or anything; so he moved on and that got me a bit upset. We were out with my friend Anthony; and we went to Red Robin to get some food. Anthony had to leave after a while; and I decided to confront the guy. /  / I confronted him about moving on after scarcely a week went by. I told him about how if I did send any message; I wasn't aware of it. He went on to tell me about how he's really bad with empathy and things; and went into his back story; involving an orphanage; bad foster parents; and getting bullied in middleschool. Although I couldn't really understand fully what this was like; he painted his feeling very clearly for me; so I was able to feel them too.
pfeltother: 1. Shock / 2. Panic (from remembering past events in my own life) / 3. Helplessness
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: I think this is true; because if you pity someone; it is because you don't feel close enough to actually feel sorry for them; or to try. I didn't want to try; because I felt that past event from my own life would come back and i would break down and wouldn't be any help to her situation at all. So I stuck to pity; and I don't know if that was the right thing to do.
tlove: I think it is a kind of love because I think you can only feel tenderness towards someone you really do love and care about. Tenderness to me is being happy because someone has bared their soul to you. They've given you their feelings which you can't understand and empathize with and aren't supposed to; but which you appreciate all the same because they mean something to you; because you love this person.
clove: I think it is a kind of love where you look down on someone more. You are compassionate towards them because they aren't smart/wise enough to know what they're doing. But you still love them
sfeltother: 1. Out of control (confusion?) - I didn't understand fully; and I knew that / 2. Fear / 3. Respect (for Grace for being strong)
slove: I would call it love. The kind of love for someone who you don't know very well; but still wish were better off because you think they're good enough to deserve it.
elove: It is a kind of love in that it is a deep emotional connection.

writetende: I spend a few hours babysitting my cousin's four-year-old daughter over Christmas vacation. She is a very bright little girl who is kind and pleasant to spend time with. I don't normally enjoy spending time with children; but I very much liked spending time with her. We pretended to bake; played with stuffed animals; and looked at picture books; and I was amazed by her energy and curiosity. She would sit in my lap and I felt as thought I were her mother for a moment. I genuinely cared for her; and I hoped she would keep that sense of wonder and innocence even as she grew older. I paid a lot of attention to make sure she didn't hurt herself while running around- not just because she was a child but because I cared about her well-being and wanted to do what I would to keep her safe.
writecomp: About a year ago my best friend Cassie's father died from pancreatic cancer. Over the course of just a couple years he had transformed from looking perfectly healthy to looking emaciated and lifeless. I visited her about two months before her father passed away; and I could tell she was visibly upset about how quickly her father's condition had deteriorated. I felt unable to help her because there was nothing anyone could do to save her father at this point. Once I heard later that he had passed away; I knew Cassie was going to have a rough time coping with the loss. I wanted to make it all better for her; and magically make all the pain go away; as impossible as it was. It hurt me to know that she was suffering so much. I talked to her as often as I could; gave her all the encouraging words I could think of; and just made it as clear as possible that; while I was unable to solve her problems; I was there to support her in any way I could. I couldn't put myself in her shoes fully; since I had never experienced the loss of a loved one. But her being unhappy made me unhappy; and I wanted to find a way to help her through her loss.
writesymp: I met my friend Amy at a summer camp; and we quickly realized we had a lot in common. One of the things we had in common was our dissatisfaction with our own weight/appearance/eating habits. She told me she has a tendency to lose control and binge when she is emotionally upset; and she hates to look in the mirror because she feels fat and out of control. I understood exactly what that felt like because I had previously struggled with an eating disorder when I was younger. Knowing she also had a similar struggle; while this was not a good thing; made me feel a bit better about myself because it meant that I was not as abnormal as I had imagined before. I wanted to share with her my own experiences and learn more about hers so that I could help her improve her self image. I wanted to do whatever I could to make sure that she didn't suffer as much as I did before. And in talking to her about the ways I had learned to feel better about myself; I reaffirmed my own self-confidence.
writeempat: Both a classmate and I did really poorly on an exam in an economics class. We both exchanged stories about why we were struggling in the class; and we decided to motivate one another to attend office hours/study regularly from now on. Knowing someone else felt the same way I did made me feel a little better about myself and that I could improve the situation- that not all hope was lost.
tlove: Tenderness is a feeling of wanting to protect and care for someone else. It is the same as treating someone gently; and should be the type of love someone feels when the other person is young or vulnerable in some way.
clove: If compassion were a type of love; it would be a type of love between any two or more people. It's the ability to understand that other people have experiences that affect how they feel and who they are and that; regardless of whether or not you have had similar experiences; you understand and respect how they think and feel about their own experiences.
slove: Sympathy is the acknowledgement that people have had experiences that affect how they feel and how they think. Your experiences may or may not be similar; but you realize that not everyone reacts to experiences the way you do. But you want them to suffer as little as possible from those experiences
elove: Empathy is sharing a similar emotion after a similar experience and wanting to help the other person recover from a bad situation in the same way you did. It is a self-reaffirming kind of love in that it makes you feel more connected to people while still caring for them.

writepity: A time where I felt pity is when a girl took a moment to be vulnerable with me to tell me her feelings towards me. This was very unexpected to me; but part of me felt bad because I did not share those same feelings at the time.  However; because I felt bad; I told her that I would take her out on a date to make her feel better. I did this out of pity; since again; I felt bad that I put her in that situation and that I did not feel the same way about her.
writetende: A moment when I felt tenderness toward someone is when they broke down crying in front of me after a hard workout. I am still not very sure why they were; but I made sure that I had to comfort them. I had to be warm and caring; and to make sure that they were alright and weren't hurt. I was protecting them from the outside; making sure no one else was staring or inquiring.
writecomp: A time where I felt compassion for someone is when they lost their father. I have never dealt with that; but I couldn't imagine what it would feel like if I had lost my father. I knew it was my duty to console this friend; to be there for them; and to be a support system for them.I wanted to help them to the best of my abilities. I had to do my best to make sure that they felt my full support throughout their personal loss.
writesymp: I had a friend who had recently lost a grandparent that they didn't really know that well; but they were still upset by it.  I felt sympathetic towards them because I had a similar experience where I lost a grandparent that I did not know that well. I could pretty much relate to everything that my friend was telling me. How they wished they spent more time with them; and got to know them. I remember feeling that same way; but I was able to offer guidance; by saying that they can use this lesson for the future. To focus on the people who they really care about and to make sure they don't feel that feeling again.
writeempat: I was consoling a friend about not getting a summer job. I had been there before; where I applied to summer jobs and I did not get any of them. I could feel what they were feeling. I could relate. I could put myself in their shoes. I had felt the failure and the uncertainty before. I had to tell them my own personal experiences with this; and I tried to help them cope with it and to lend them to other alternatives; as I had done before.
plove: Sorry love
pcontempt: Yes. Since I believe we feel pity not because we want to; but because we feel bad and we want to console in a non-personal way.
tlove: Warming love
clove: Supporting and understanding
slove: I would call it a caring love.
elove: relateable love

writepity: I pitied a friend who got a bad grade on  exam that I fared much better on. I was thinking that it was awkward when he told me his score when i told him I did ok; almost wanting me to him my score. I avoided that situation by telling him that I too didn't do as well as expected and left it at that.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards someone when someone else was making fun of them repeatedly. The individual wasn't a close friend but I felt bad for him. I tried talking to the person who was making fun of him and tried to tell him to stop. I also tried to initiate a dialogue with the other person and see if I could talk to him about what was happening. i advised him to go speak with a teacher or someone if the problem persists.
writecomp: I felt compassion when I was with my friends; especially when we went on our Spring Break trip. We shared laughs and had a good time which brought everyone closer together. I was feeling happy and also thinking about plans for next years spring break trip. We went to a casino and hung out in our hotel room at night; watching movies.
writesymp: My friend was having some trouble with her parents so I tried to best understand what sh was going through. Although I couldn't place myself in her shoes I tried my best to help her through what she was going through. I said that everything would work out and then asked what she wanted to do as well as how I could help.
writeempat: When my friend got rejected from a college she really wanted to go to; I felt like she was going through the same thing that i went through a week ago when I got rejected from a college I really wanted to go as well. I tried to console her the best I could and told her that this was only one college and that there were many other good ones; even though this was her favorite. I told her i went to through the same thing and that it would feel better soon. I also said that you never know how much you'll end up liking the college that she did end up going to as it grows on you.
plove: I would not call love pity
pcontempt: I don't think so. Contempt is when you use the pity against the person you feel it for and rub it in their face. You can feel pity for another person without saying or doing anything.
tlove: I would not call tenderness love.
clove: I would not call compassion a kind of love.
slove: I don't think sympathy is a kind of love.
elove: I do not consider empathy a kind of love

writepity: My mother was laid off right before my senior year; after working with a company for over 20 years. After she came home and told me; she expressed such confusion about the future and her path in life. She reflected on everything she'd done and her disillusionment with all the choices she had made leading up to that point was apparent. I felt so bad; but didn't know how to relate. So; I decided we should go out to eat; anywhere she chose. We did; and she said she felt better.
writetende: When I was six; my dad won me a stuffed animal at a local carnival. It was a small; blue dog--nothing special; but I became very attached to it. I brought it out with me in public until I was about nine and; even today; still sleep with it when I go home. That being said; when I was about 8; I took a trip to Oregon with my mom to stay with my grandparents. Obviously; I brought the stuffed dog. When it was time to go; the dog was no where to be found. We searched for hours and hours; as I cried and cried. but my mom wouldn't give up and said we wouldn't leave until we found it. We finally did. I felt such an affection for her; a tenderness; even right now; as I'm typing; I feel a tenderness toward her.
writecomp: I used to volunteer at a retirement center. There; I met a blind woman. We talked for a while; and she told me her husband had died but that they used to always dance together. He would take her out dancing; often times to jazz music. Then; she asked me if I would dance with her. She said she'd need some one help because she couldn't see. The absence of music also made it difficult. Despite that; I felt compassionate toward this woman and her situation. i helped her stand up and we slow danced in the middle of the common room for upwards of ten minutes.
writesymp: My best friend and I have always had busy schedules--different sports teams; lots of clubs; a bunch of homework. On top of that; her parents were constantly fighting. She was just having a rough month in general. I sympathized with her because I understood what it was like to be really stressed out and to have your parents fighting a lot (mine did too.) One night; I came over unannounced; with ice cream and her favorite movies. We sat their all night; eating and watching movies.
writeempat: My best friend's parents go divorced and there were lots of money issues involved. This was right before our senor prom; and; because of these circumstances; she couldn't buy a prom dress. We grew up in a generally affluent community; so it was rather uncommon for our friends to not purchase $400 + dresses. But my parents were also struggling with money; and I; too; wasn't going to be able to buy a new dress. I empathized with my friend because I understood where she was coming from.
plove: I don't think pity is love. You can pity people you love; but you don't have to love someone to do so.
pcontempt: Pity has some negative connotations. When you pity someone; it is often implied that you are looking down on them; that they are much smaller than you; are needy; require help. I don't necessarily agree. I think often times pitying someone is just not being able to relate to their type of problem. You pity them because you have a lack of understanding for their circumstances and situation; not because you think less of them as people. At least; sometimes.
tlove: I do think tenderness is a form of love. i think it's provoked by something; that it's being thankful; sort of. I picture someone you love doing something for you and you just being very appreciative. it's something to further proves that they love you.
clove: It's a love where you want to help people.
slove: I don't necessarily think you have to love someone to sympathize with them; but you do sympathize with those you love. You feel like you have something to offer and want to do so.
elove: Empathizing with someone is having gone through something similar and understanding where they are coming from and wanting to help. you don't have to love someone to empathize with them.

writepity: When I was 7 or 8 I went to Chicago with my parents and my older sister. It was winter and we were walking home from somewhere; I don't remember where; but it was night time so probably dinner or a show of some kind. I'm from a small; wealthy town and I had never seen poverty or homeless people before; and on this particular walk a woman approached us and asked my dad if he had any money. She looked worn. Her coat was so old I couldn't even tell what color it was; and her shoes were help together by spit and dreams. My dad politely turned her down and kept walking; until my mom saw the baby in her arms. She stopped my dad and said "Mark; she has a baby." and he immediately gave me $20 and sent me back to the woman. I just felt horrible that I was growing up in comfort and the baby wasn't. That image has always stuck with me.
writetende: A little while ago my friend was having a really rough time with school; work; and sports. We live together; and she was sitting in our kitchen freaking out and trying to get things done when I walked in. I immediately noticed her panic and felt the need to protect her and make it go away; so I calmed her down a bit and offered to make her some food or help out with anything if I could. She is what I would call a stormy person inside and she struggles with things. When she gets that way I just feel an incredible tenderness for her and an overwhelming protectiveness.
writecomp: I went to Italy this summer; and on the flight over I had an aisle seat. Across the aisle was this little Turkish Grandmother all  by herself. My best guess is that her children or grandchildren flew her over to the US to visit them in their home there. She was tiny and frail and quiet; and she just triggered this compassion in me. She spoke no English and I speak no Turkish; but we spent our entire flight trading smiles and mimed words. When she needed something she would look and me and try to act it out while saying the words in her language; and I would flag down the flight attendant or get her what she needed. At the end of the flight she gave me the biggest smile as I helped her off the plane.
writesymp: Another sports story; sorry. Apparently I'm quite one-dimensional. This year on my team one of the players got a knee injury that kept recurring. I felt very sympathetic towards her because this year I also had a knee injury that wouldn't go away. I understood what she was feeling because I understood what it was like to sit on the sidelines and support your teammates and how hard that can be when all you want is to participate. I would often check in with my teammate during the non-practice days and see how she was feeling; just to let her know someone understood.
writeempat: When I was in high school I played soccer for a club and at one of our games during the winter a player I didn't really like broke her leg very badly. She snapped the bone in 3 places and just hit the ground. She went into shock on the field and was shaking and crying and screaming. We were probably about 15 or 16 and we were all completely stunned; but the parents jumped into action (we had a number of medical professionals on the sideline). They piled our coats on her to keep her warm until an ambulance came and took her away. I felt so bad for her; and I couldn't really imagine what that must have been like because I had never been injured badly. I just tried to understand and to see things as she would during that time; she must have been so scared. /
plove: I would say it is the kind of love that gives us a place in our hearts for people who aren't as well off as we are. A love that leads us to help others.
pcontempt: No
tlove: I think tenderness is the kind of love that we need to take care of people we love; to protect them.
clove: Yes; this is love. Its another way to hold people in your heart and share their burden
slove: No; I wouldn't call it love
elove: I wouldn't call it love

writepity: I felt pity my friend when his car broke down because his car breaking down was out of his control. I guess pity is very similar to sympathy or empathy. I offered to help him because i felt bad for his bad fortune.
writetende: i felt tenderness towards someone when my friend's parents went through a divorce. I felt tenderness because i knew that my friend was very emotional vulernable. I was feeling bad for my friend and thinking that she must be going through a lot in her head. I wanted to help her but did not really know how; so i just said if she ever wanted to talk about anything i would be there for her.
writecomp: i felt compassionate towards my parents when they helped me out when i was feeling down. i appreciated them a lot and was very thankful for all that they do
writesymp: i was sympathetic when my friends dog died. I felt sad and tried to offer my condolences; although i didnt really know what to do because i have never had a dog die.
writeempat: When my friend failed his test. I felt bad for him because i also felt bad whenever i failed a test. there was nothing i could really do; other than say it happens to everyone at some point.
plove: not a kind of love
pcontempt: maybe a little bit. i feel like pity is more your feelings of sorrow towards someone when they are responsible for bringing the misfortune on themselves; rather than the misfortune occurring because of something out of their control
tlove: i would not call tenderness a love
clove: yes i would call compassion a kind of love. i would call it a deep appreciation for something that is akin to love.
slove: wouldnt call it love /
elove: would not call it love /

writepity: I feel pity when I see people being yelled at. For example; when I see drill sergeants yelling at army recruits. I feel like I could potentially help but I usually won't or can't. I feel sorry for them in a sense; but know it's partially their fault as well. It's more of a "suck it up" type thought that goes through my head; like I think they need to man-up and deal with it.
writetende: One example I can think of is when we found my dog had been hit by a car. All I wanted to do was make the pain she had go away. You could see it in her eyes. My parents and I kept telling her it'd be alright. She seemed very vulnerable and desperate.
writecomp: One time I worked at a Soup Kitchen; I saw many homeless people come through to get food. I felt good about helping them; and I could see they were thankful as well. I wanted to meet all of them; but didn't have time; so just said hello.
writesymp: I think I felt sympathy when I saw my grandmother on her deathbed. There wasn't a thing I could do to help. Nobody could help. I felt sorry for her. I wanted to help. We told her everything would be alright. She said the same. We knew differently.
writeempat: One time in middle school I watched as two of my good friends got in trouble for cheating on some Social Studies homework. I had been caught previously in the year as well for a similar thing; so I could relate. I felt a bit sorry for them; and knew what they were probably feeling as well. I wanted to tell them it'd get better; because I knew it would.
plove: I wouldn't call it love. Pity is feeling sorry for someone who maybe doesn't really deserve your attentive care.
pcontempt: I think this is pretty true; looking back on my feelings. I didn't really try to do anything about the situation; and most people probably would do the same.
tlove: I think tenderness isn't a kind of love. I think it is more of a caring for someone or something else in distress.
clove: I would call it a form of love. For me; it was sort of like a bondage between myself and people I've never met. It made me feel human.
slove: I think one could consider it a feeling of love. In my case; I think it's one of the cases where you want something to change but know in your heart that it can't and won't change.
elove: I think empathy is more of a type of understanding. You can relate to what a person is experiencing.

writetende: I felt tenderness when I hear about the stories of the poor at church or in school. I can't remember a specific story but they are the type of stories when the person basically gets screwed over again and again and can't get on their feet and have to go through some really discouraging situations. It seems like they have the whole world going against them.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards my girlfriend when she came and visited me at Michigan. To put it lightly; her mom is a complete bitch and will call her and yell at her from something that she did not even do. One time; she was visiting me for Valentine's day and she got me some great Valentine's Day gifts like Oreos; Lunchables; and Greek Yogurt. Then as the day went on; she received a phone call from her mom yelling at her for the table her brother just broke at home. I felt compassion because it totally wasn't her fault and she wasn't even home. I wanted to comfort her because she deserved better.
writesymp: Last night; I went to my friend's room to stall before I wanted to study for a test. I get to the door and he answers it angrily saying he has a test. I was a little drawn back to why he was so angry because I usually visit his room at night. I then talked to him to find out that he has a huge Bio test tomorrow and that he is going to fail it. I felt sympathy because I know what it feels like to be screwed for a test the following day. I know its not a good feeling and my friend clearly was upset. I simply told him; "Good luck. I'll let you go study now." Then I left his hall.  /  / I wanted to help him with his situation but I couldn't do anything because I don't know anything about biology at Michigan.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards someone when my friend was pledging a fraternity. I heard that he had to eat cat and dog food along with drinking a shit ton of alcohol. I felt empathy towards him because I have no idea what it is like to eat cat or dog food but I can imagine that it would suck. I wanted to say I'm sorry and to better understand the situation but I couldn't because I had never had to drink a lot of alcohol and eat cat and dog food. I just told him 'Im sorry; that sucks."
tlove: It's a kind of love in which you are willing to get emotional/vulnerable to talk to another person about their problems/emotional conflict. You can be tender even if you don't know someone very well.
clove: Compassion is sympathy mixed in with a loving emotion.
slove: I would not call sympathy a type of love. I can feel sympathetic towards a total stranger if I hear their story.
elove: Empathy is not a type of love. You can't relate to the situation.

writepity: I was the drum major of my high school marching band; and my younger sister wanted to be the drum major some day too.  She was a freshman when I was a senior (the year I was drum major); and she witnessed everything that I did as drum major; including all of my actions behind the scenes and in front of the band.  She knew how much of an impact the drum major could have on the band; and she too wanted to make a meaningful difference in the lives of some 184 band students.  The current drum majors hold "drum major clinics" in the second semester of the school year; and interested candidates come to these clinics to refine their marching and command calling; learn how to conduct; and practice interview questions.  I held these clinics my senior year; and my sister attended all of them.  I was blown away by her motivation and the preciseness about which she took on every challenge given to her.  She was one of the strongest candidates; if not the strongest candidate.  I was one of the "judges" at the drum major auditions and thought she did a phenomenal job; however; the band director did not let me sit in on the discussion of the candidates; as he thought I would be a "biased" judge because one of the candidates was my sister.  My sister was not chosen; and I was told that our director wanted an older and more experienced candidate.  My sister was only a freshman at the time; so she would've been a sophomore drum major.  I understood; but still felt bad for my sister because she was an excellent candidate and would have done an incredible job. /  / My sister tried out the next year; only to be turned down again.  She was beat by a mediocre candidate; someone I did not think would do a great job.  In fact; he did not do a great job.  My sister finally tried out again for her senior year; and yet again she did not make it.  I was angry at the system; at my band director; and at the other candidates who beat her.  They were not good; and the band quickly learned that they were not good.  My sister would have done a wonderful job as drum major; and the band program certainly suffered because of my band director's unwillingness to give my sister the position.  Most of all; I felt pity for my sister.  I felt bad that time after time; she was turned down.  I mostly felt bad because she truly deserved the position and she worked hard for it; so it felt unfair that she was not given the role.  I felt bad that weaker candidates were given the position instead of her.
writetende: I feel tenderness when I am holding newborn babies in the hospital.  I do hearing screening tests on newborn babies (who are six hours old!) and they are so fragile; pure; and innocent.  I feel tenderness toward them because I want to protect them and make sure they lead enriching lives -- when I am holding them at that moment; I don't want anything to happen to them.
writecomp: I volunteer at Meals on Wheels; and I deliver meals to elderly within my community.  I feel compassion toward them because I know that many of them are widowed or they are sad because they are aging and losing abilities to do things like cook for themselves.  Part of the compassion comes from me feeling respect for them and the lives they have lived; and part of me feels compassion for them because I know that as a younger member of the community; it is my duty to take care of them and make them happy.
writesymp: I felt sympathy toward my friend and her family when their dog passed away.  The family was so upset and their dog was young and outlived by the older dog.  My friend was devastated and I felt sympathy for her.  I was there to talk to her when she needed it; and I wrote her a card expressing my sorrow for her and her family.
writeempat: I felt empathy toward my friend when her dog passed away.  She had two dogs; and the younger and healthier one suddenly got ill and passed away.  She and her entire family were very sad; and the older dog was sad as well.  I expressed my empathy by writing a card to her and consoling her via text message and in person.  I gave her hugs whenever she needed them and was always there to talk if she felt up to it.
pcontempt: I'm not sure what this means!
tlove: I feel tenderness when I love someone and find them delicate.
clove: When you love someone; you are compassionate toward them.  You look out for them and make sure they're okay.
slove: When you love someone; you feel sympathy when something undesirable happens.
elove: When you love someone; you are empathetic when something bad happens to them.

writepity: I feel pity towards my niece; not during a single situation; but overall.  She has had a very rough life including growing up without a father until the age of 13 when she got a stepfather; being the less favored child when she was young (according to her) and having had a series of other issues when she was young.  She followed by not making great decisions in high school; not getting good grades; unable to keep a job; and moving out with her boyfriend as soon as she finished high school.  I wanted to help but it seemed futile since she was not making good decisions.  I felt bad for her but frustrated at the same time; that it's somewhat her own fault.
writetende: I feel tender towards my ex boy friend.  Not because of a specific situation; just overall due to his life circumstances.  I knew how vulnerable he was and how difficult of a life he has had; and it would make me feel extremely tender towards him.  For example he didn't have a father or a mother and lived with his grandparents; then when he was 1 7 his grandfather; which was the only 'father' he ever had passed away and he was not even able to travel home to say a final goodbye.  even though I have more than my share of negative memories in which he has made me extremely angry or upset; I still feel and always will feel a tenderness towards him.  When I felt this; which happened often; I expressed it through cuddling him; rubbing his back; etc.
writecomp: I feel compassion whenever someone is exceedingly nice to me; when they act kindly solely the sake them them being nice and no ulterior motives on their behalf.  Compassion to me is when I feel a fuzzy; happy; love for someone; usually based on their actions.  I felt this with my old yoga teacher; when I had an injury and had to stop going to class.  She made an exception for me to charge me less for my monthly class subscription; and invited me personally over to her house to show me yoga postures that would still be safe considering my physician; and provided me with a variety of natural remedies to take home with me to help swelling.  I felt this overwhelming sense of love and fuzziness that someone was being so kind to me; and i immediately had a reciprocal feeling of warmness for this person as she was demonstrating to me.  I responded by being extremely gracious; thanking her for her help; and kindness.  Compassion to me can be equated with kindness.  I also felt an overwhelming sense of wanting to be able to reciprocate the kindness and going out of her way to help me; and do the same for her;.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards a friend of mine when her cat died.  She loved the cat; would always talk about him; and absolutely adored it.  I; on the other hand was not at all fond of it.  Then it got sick for a few months; and when I went over to her house; the cat looked like a completely different animal.  It was shaky; would not look anyone in the eye; and had most of its hair - it used to have a fluffy; full coat but had become scraggly and looked like an alley cat.  Then a few weeks later I found out that the cat died.  Even though I didn't care for the cat; I knew how much it meant to my friend; and felt really bad because I knew she must have been pretty depressed about it.  I sent her a message saying i'm really sorry to hear about her cat dying; hope she is able to handle it alright; and to let me know if she needs anything.  I just felt bad that my friend must have been suffering over the situation.
writeempat: I felt empathy for my mom when she had a hip injury and was in extreme pain; and could barely get up to move around without excruciating pain.  I felt empathy with her because I am so close to her and her problems are my problems to a certain extent.  I could also very much relate to her because I have had a lot of health issues/injuries in the past year and I know what I pain and how stressful and worry-invoking it is.  I wanted to let her know as much as possible that I am thinking about her by always asking how her hip was; and trying to offer any advice/suggestions that I could that would improve the situation.  I would try to cheer her up often.
plove: Not love.
pcontempt: No; pity to me is much less strong that contempt.   I equate contempt with hatred; and I certainly don't hate most of the people that I feel pity for.  I feel that pity is feeling bad for someone while looking down on them simultaneously; because you perceive that they have have brought some of their failure upon themselves.
tlove: Yes; a more intimate love than compassion; common between lovers.
clove: Yes; I would.  It is a non-sexual love that encompasses; kindness and a deep connection with the other person.  A lot of the time they may have done something important for you that invokes this feeling of love that you have for them.
slove: No; i don't equate it with love.
efeltother: 1. Really wanting the other person to be well; not just for their sake but for my own as well. / 2.  / 3.
elove: Yes; empathy happens when you're so close with a person (best friend; family member; etc.) and you're so involved in their 'business' that you can't help but feel with them when something bad happens to them.

writepity: Everytime I walk down one of the downtown streets; I get asked for money from homeless people. They always ask me as I approach them; and I never know what to do. Should I ignore them? How do I tell them that I don't have any money for them when it's pretty clear that I'm on that street to eat or shop? I usually just say; "Not today; sorry." and they bless me and tell me to have a good day. I feel bad for not devoting my attention to them and usually don't know what to do; even though I have just a few seconds of interaction for them. I pity those homeless people for the lives that they have to lead.
writetende: I was spending a morning with a friend who I was very close to. We were not dating but were extremely close regardless. We had had some serious talks but I hadn't seen him demonstrate emotions such as crying before. One of his friends in an extracurricular activity passed away a few months earlier; and someone else sent him an email trying to set up a memorial for him. At least; that is what I think it said. I only saw the friend's name on the phone screen; and my friend immediately closed it and acted very distant. I saw tears in his eyes and he was quiet for a little while before changing the subject. I felt bad for him because of the trigger; but I didn't want to directly confront him. I just wanted to quietly be there for him; and at the time; I felt very tender in his presence. I don't really talk to him anymore; but I never brought up that situation again.
writecomp: I have a friend who is very involved with volunteer work. She needed help from others to aid with her volunteer event; but was having some trouble getting volunteers to sign up. I was initially uneasy and unsure; because I was busy myself; and I didn't know how exactly I would be able to make a difference. She described to me what I would be doing; why it would matter; and how it would touch the lives of those involved with her specific charity. Hearing her words and how personal they were really struck a chord with me and I became more willing to help her out. I ended up rearranging my schedule just to help her; but she made me feel really involved and important. I told her that I would be happy to help out; and I was feeling compassionate toward her and her cause.
writesymp: I associate sympathy with emotional; health-related issues. For example; if someone is sick; or in the hospital; or has a loved one pass away; then I would feel sympathetic toward them.  /  / One of my roommates' parents was diagnosed with cancer while I was living with her. I knew that she (and her family) was having a tough time emotionally; as well as her mother physically dealing with the ailment. I just generally felt more sympathetic toward her because she had to worry not just about herself; but very intensely about another person. I gave her more leeway for certain things; and knew that she was busy spending time with her mom at appointments so I would do small chores/tasks of hers. I wanted to help her; but I knew that I could not do much except be supportive.  /  / I had a few talks with her; saying that if she needed someone to talk to that I would always be available. Our chats were sometimes very emotionally charged. I was feeling bad for her and the situation; but I was certain that her and her afflicted parent would persevere.
writeempat: I have felt empathy toward someone when they were trying to raise awareness for a sibling who died from cancer. They decided to shave their head in solidarity; and the first time thta they did it; they had beautiful long hair. I watched her get her head buzzed; and felt very supportive of her cause. I did not feel bad at all and thought what she was doing was awesome and brave. I didn't feel so inspired as to do it with her; but I thought that she was doing a great thing to honor her brother and I told that to her.  /  / *This is the word that I have the least-clear definition for; so I was stretching for a story in the time allotted for the survey.**
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I am not totally sure what this means.
tlove: I think that it is a love; but I would generalize tenderness as something that you don't necessarily have to be personally involved in. I had no relation to the situation but still felt tenderness.
clove: It would be a friendly love; like you would be willing to do something to help out a fellow friend.
slove: I think it is sort of familial; like I would feel sympathy only toward people that I care for a lot.
elove: If it were classified as a love; it would be a very casual one.

writepity: One situation that stands out to me in which I felt pity was during 10th grade. We were asked to write an English paper. The paper had multiple deadlines; but it was possible to not pass a deadline. For example; one deadline was a date by which we were supposed to have formulated a working thesis. One could not proceed to the next part of the assignment unless the previous part had been approved by the teacher. One kid in my class; Tim; was behind on every deadline. As a result; by the time he got his thesis approved; the paper was due the next day. I remember feeling extreme pity for Tim. He had gone to my grade school so I knew his mom would be furious and ground him for months because she was one of those extremely intense mothers. He had also had his heart set on going to Harvard from a very young age; but he was guaranteed to fail this paper; which would result in a C in the class for his overall grade. A C in a class is essentially a disqualifier. I saw Tim the day before the paper was due and that's when the pity really set in. He was totally distraught. He knew exactly how badly he had messed up and it was killing him. I felt so much pity for him because I knew that he thought his life was basically over; and although now he is at a great college; at that moment he thought he would end up not going to college and settling for some job in unskilled labor somewhere.
writetende: One time in which I felt tenderness toward someone was when a girl moved to my school from Chile. I didn't necessarily feel bad for her or anything like that. I just wanted her to not feel as isolated as she did upon her arrival. It helped that she ended up being a very cool girl.
writecomp: One time I felt compassion was when my friend Daje overdosed on ecstasy when we were at a music festival senior year. While he did not die; he was never the same after that. His brain chemistry was permanently altered; and since then he was acted very strangely to the point where he lost almost all of his social skills altogether. Unlike my feelings of pity or sympathy that I described earlier; I really wanted to help bring Daje back. We all did. My entire group of friends felt partially responsible because we had been with him morning before he had disappeared to do the drug in secret. Being part of the overall situation no doubt made me feel compassion instead of just sympathy or pity. I had a longing to help him and I still do to this day. I think that is what distinguishes compassion from the other four emotions.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my brother when he broke his wrist and had to drive home 20 miles on the freeway in extreme pain. By the time we got to the hospital he couldn't feel his legs because his body had gone into shock. I could tell from talking to him how upset he was that he had gotten injured; not because of the pain; but because his track and field season was now over and he could not compete for the remainder of the year. This was more than just feeling bad for my brother. I could almost understand how he felt and I wanted to help him through this struggle.
writeempat: I felt empathy toward my friend James when he got beat up at a high school party. Unlike the other emotions; I feel like empathy is something that one person can only feel for another person if they had gone through the same thing. I've been beaten up too; so I know how much it sucks to have it happen. For this reason; I was able to feel empathy for James. It didn't really matter whether or not he started the fight or why the fight broke out. I felt empathy because he had lost and had been beaten pretty badly; which I know from personal experience is not pleasant whatsoever.
plove: It would be a kind of love that helps those in need.
pcontempt: I do not think this is true. Whereas pity leads to helping someone; contempt leads to hurting.
tlove: Tenderness would be the kind of love that warms the heart.
clove: Compassion would be the kind of love that volunteers feel when they opt to sleep in homeless shelters for weeks on end just to be able to better help the homeless.
slove: Sympathy would be a kind of love that brings someone in need back from a hard time in their life. It would be a healing kind of love.
elove: Empathy would be the type of love that puts you in someone else's shoes because you have been in their shoes before and know what they are going through.

writepity: When walking down the street and seeing a homeless man; I felt pity for him.  I felt pity for him because I knew that he was in a much less fortunate situation than myself.  I knew that he must have had different challenges that have led him to this point in his life and he could use help to get back on his feet.  In the past; I have given money and food to the homeless and tried to talk to them and see if there is anything I could do to help.
writetende: When dealing with older people such as my grandparents I have felt tenderness.  When my grandmother was in the hospital I felt tenderness because I perceived her as frail and weak.  Her inability to take care of herself and need of help especially jumped out at me.  I tried to be as encouraging as possible and do my best to take care of whatever I could.  I wanted to make her as comfortable as possible.
writecomp: When my girlfriend failed her exam I felt compassion for her.  After studying for the exam for days before; she failed her exam and was disappointed in how she did.  Since I knew how much time she put into preparing for the exam; I felt bad for her.  I listened to her vent her frustrations because I knew it would make her feel better.  Afterwards; I wanted to try to help her get over the disappointment and focus on the other stuff going on in her life.
writesymp: I felt sympathy when my friends aunt passed away.  I was able to relate my past experiences in similar situations to their situation and felt bad for them.  I thought about what I could do and tried to do my best to help my friend however possible.  I felt bad for my friend and was also sad.  I sent my friend and his family a card and made their family and relatives dinner to help them out.
plove: I don't think it is a kind of love because people are feeling bad for people who are perceived to be worse off than themselves.
pcontempt: I don't think it is true because pity is a feeling sorry for another where contempt is not.
tlove: I would say it is a kind of love that focuses on helping people who cannot help themselves or are vulnerable.
clove: I would say it is a kind of love that allows people to relate to the people around them and feel their emotions.
slove: Yes; I believe it is a kind of love that allows people to relate to others and express their sadness.

writepity: There was a girl for whom I had strong feelings; and she felt the same way about me; but there were two other guys that she considered friends that had made it clear they had feelings for her too. This took place over the summer when lots of people were travelling; so there wasn't much opportunity for face-to-face communication; and things went poorly. This girl who had shown interest in me changed her mind and explained it to me hastily and poorly; and it was clear she was not handling the situation well. I felt like she didn't know how to deal with her feelings and she wouldn't treat anyone very well. She decided to go after one of the other guys who had feelings for her; and I pitied him. At the very beginning I thought I pitied myself but I realized she was not a great person and I was better off moving on. I felt bad for the boy she chose because I thought she'd treat him terribly because she doesn't know how to handle emotional things. He liked her so much and I just knew she would drag him through the mud and treat him badly because he was so vulnerable. I was probably a bit jealous as well; but I definitely pitied the boy; just not enough to reach out to him because I wanted to distance myself from the situation.
writetende: A few weeks ago a friend with whom I have become very close was with me late at night and we were talking about all sorts of things. We were waiting for two of our friends to finish having a conversation about their relationship (they had just broken up for the second time and needed to talk things through) and we were in a weird situation. The friend I was with was very involved in our other friends' breakup; so she was in a vulnerable place too. We talked for a few hours; some about our friends; but eventually we got tired of talking about them so we talked about ourselves. I told her all about my past friendships and love interests; mostly about high school. I grew really close to her in those few hours because I shared with her a lot of my strongest feelings from the last five years of my life. She talked to me about her past and her friends and her complicated relationships with the people we both know from college. I really appreciated having someone new I could trust and talk to about stuff like that; and I feel like we strengthened our friendship a lot that night. I consider this tenderness because we were both open and she was in a vulnerable place and emotions were running high; and we were able to just talk to each other about all sorts of things without worrying.
writecomp: When two of my good friends went through an ugly breakup; it was a confusing situation. There were a lot of bad choices made and a lot of surprising emotions being felt by multiple parties and it was overall a really sucky situation for everyone involved. One of the people involved is the guy who lives next door to me; so he was my friend originally; and I only met the girl through him; but we had all become close. The first time I saw the girl after their breakup was a few days later and I could tell she was really hurt. She had been crying for the last couple days since it happened and she was still really angry at him. I could tell she was really appreciative that I came over and talked to her; because she was afraid she might not be friends with me anymore after they broke up. I really felt terrible for her because I knew it was a terrible situation and I couldn't do much about it other than comfort her; but I think I did that really well. The whole ordeal hurt a lot of people and during this conversation I had with her I felt a deep emotional connection and I felt like I was able to give her the compassion that she needed at the time.
writesymp: A few months ago I went through an interesting experience with an unnamed drug. A few of us took it together and there were a lot of emotions going on from a lot of different people. One of the people who joined us came in kind of last minute and none of us expected him to be there; so it was a bit uncomfortable. He also had the tendency to make people uncomfortable and some of us weren't exactly crazy about him. I remember being kind of mean to him; like groaning when he'd knock on the door to come back in; or ignoring him if he was trying to say something. Eventually he just left us and a few hours later I went to kind of a dark place in my mind. It felt like what I imagine depression feels like; but it didn't last too long. I felt like nothing was worth it and that live was just a waste of time because I couldn't find joy in anything. This feeling lasted less than half an hour; and then I got over it (it was due to the drugs; I'm sure). But a few minutes later I thought about the kid that we were mean to. I imagined him being somewhere by himself having these dark thoughts after we'd all been really mean to him. I was afraid that he was going through the same thing I did; so I texted him asking if he was alright and apologizing for kicking him out. He said he was fine just watching TV in his room; and even came back later apologizing for ditching us (I guess there was some misunderstanding about why he left). I thought I knew what he'd be going through and felt bad that he'd be doing it alone; so I wanted to make sure he was okay.
writeempat: Earlier this school year; in late October; a friend of mine had a medical condition that was somewhat serious. He had to go the hospital and have a procedure done. He had an abscess on his butt; making it uncomfortable to walk around and even sit down. I could tell he was in pain and at a lot of inconvenience; but I didn't know what he was feeling; and it didn't really affect me emotionally. It was more of a thing to joke about than something I had to comfort him about. I probably told him that it must suck; but I didn't comfort him or feel his pain. I explained to people if they were curious and he didn't want to talk about it; but I didn't do much to help him other than that. I understood that he was uncomfortable physically; but that understanding didn't change the way I felt emotionally.
plove: Pity is not love in any way
pcontempt: Yeah; because pity is like recognizing someone's in a crappy situation but not caring enough to worry you too much. Like the person you pity isn't even worth a real emotion to you.
tlove: I'd say it's a vulnerable love; as in a love for someone when one or both parties is highly vulnerable.
clove: Definitely a caring love
slove: I wouldn't say it's love; more like empathy with a bit more emotion invested
elove: I wouldn't say it's a type of love; because I don't associate much emotional attachment with it; more just understanding.

writepity: A time I felt empathy was when I heard that Philip Seymour Hoffman died. He was one of my favorite actors who recently overdosed on drugs; ending his life at a relatively young age. He had been through rehab and had made a huge effort to try and get his life back on track; but addiction can be powerful and recently he lost the battle. I just kept trying to read about him; hoping it wasn't true; with questions as to how this could have happened. I felt really bad for him. Drugs are a choice; but everyone makes mistakes and he really did his best to make sure this wouldn't happen to both him and others. Unfortunately; it was too powerful of a force that night. I didn't really do much because I couldn't do much. I didn't know him personally.
writetende: A time I felt tender was when I saw Berta at a family reunion. It has been a rough past few years for her. A few years ago; about 5 or so; her husband Rich fell while working outside; causing him to be paralyzed. That took a toll on his last few years; affected obviously him but also Berta as well as the rest of their close family. I felt devastated too; how could I not; but as I don't get to see them too often; it simply took a harder toll on them as they were closer to him. A year ago he died and I saw Berta at the family reunion. She was happy to be there and happy to see so many family members she had not seen in a long time; but you could tell this was a hard time for her and that she was a bit emotionally fragile. I felt a mixture of sadness; yet wanting to do what I could to cheer her up. All I did was talk to her and give her a big hug. I think the family reunion really helped her.
writesymp: A time I felt sympathy was when my little brother didn't get invited to a party by one of his closest friends. This was about 2 years ago; so he was in the 6th grade; and I felt bad for him because he thought the guy throwing the party was one of his closest friends; and from this; you would think he would expect to get invited to this party. The party had some of his other friends too. He came home crying and was clearly in a lot of pain. I felt sympathy because I had similar experiences happen to me. I have had it where some people I think are close to me don't end up being as close to me as I thought. I could tell he felt lonely and sad; and in turn; I too felt lonely and sad. I felt this way both because I could relate to him and because it was my brother and I could tell how badly he was hurt. I wanted to try and help; but my mom already was taking care of it; so all I can remember doing is telling him that I felt bad for him and then went downstairs. Later; when he was starting to get over it; I played Playstation with him to try and cheer him up.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love. I felt bad for him and his family and stuff; but I can't say that I loved them or anything. To me; pity is not love because that would require one to really internalize their emotions and problems; when I couldn't really do that in this situation. I felt bad and stuff; but not broken as I did with my brother and Berta.
pcontempt: No. I think pity is closer to compassion and caring than contempt. Contempt is more of no connection to their emotions; where with pity I feel there is some.
tlove: I feel tenderness is a love where you feel sad for the situation and the parties involved; but you are trying to help make things better. It is a very caring love.
slove: I would call it a friendship or family type of love. One where you care strongly about a person and if something happens to them that you can relate to; you feel the same emotion as them.

writetende: Last year I was in a tutoring program for students with a non-ideal living situation most of whom came from an impoverished background. This was my first experience working with kids in the 4th grade. Although we assisted all students all tutors were assigned one student in particular to work with specifically. Doug was my student; we spent about 3 moths together everyday after school for an hour or two. At first I took the assignment as strictly a job but soon I felt myself looking at Doug like a younger sibling. He told me on several occasions that working with me was the best part of his day; and I truly felt the same way. After his work was finished I would always stay a little longer to play computer games and read books with him.
writecomp: During my Junior year of high school I meet a girl that I became very close too and were very close friends that year. After becoming quite busy in the summer and following school year our friendship really dropped off. It was not until this past summer that we really talked again. Our lives had changed so much in this time but she was still someone I could confide in. During this time the nature of our relationship had changed and we began dating but; because I had never been so close to anyone she always made me feel free to discus whatever was on my mind. We had a very compassionate relationship until we both went to different schools for college.
writesymp: About three years ago my best friends mother got into a car accident and she was injured badly. I spent almost everyday with him and I saw a deep sorrow grow in him after this because of how close he was to his mother. I felt so bad that something so horrible could happen to him and I could not stand to see him in this state. I made as many attempts to cheer him up as I could but the only thing that improved his mood was the passing of time. I talked to him very seriously and wanted him to let his emotions out but he had always been a person of strong moral code and stayed to himself.
tlove: no
clove: Secure love
slove: No

writecomp: One day my very good friend and I were going for a run and she told me that she needed to tell someone about some troubles that were bothering her. She told me that her brother had recently tried to overdose and kill himself and that she was very confused and upset about how to handle the situation and she needed a friend to support her. Hearing about her troubles made me feel want to reassure her that I was there to help support her through her hard time. I wanted her to know how much I cared about her; and that we could get through this difficult time together. We stopped on our run so that I could give her a hug and I told her that no matter what she would always have my support and that I cared about her very much.
writesymp: I volunteer in the hospital and sometimes I need to help transport patients to and from their rooms. One day; a lady came in to visit her husband; however she could not walk so I needed to escort her up to her husband's room in a wheelchair. I always try to be pleasant with patients because many of them are going through difficult times. This visitor told me that she was very frustrated because she was suffering from a degenerative disease that was causing her to lose her ability to walk. Her husband was in the hospital psychiatric facilities because he had been suffering many mental illnesses. She then became embarrassed and apologized for telling me all her problems; but I insisted that I did not mind at all. I felt awful as she told me about her situation because she and her family were suffering so much. I wanted to tell her how sorry I felt and that I wish there were something I could do to fix the whole situation; but I did not want to make her feel worse or find me condescending. I told her that I understand how frustrating it must be to not be able to walk and that I wished her and her family all the best. She seemed to feel a bit better and I tried to take her mind off all the negative emotions. When she came past my desk on the way out; she gave me a big smile and said goodbye; I felt good because I felt like maybe I had helped take her mind off her problems for at least a few minutes.
writeempat: A friend of mine recently applied to college only to be denied from her top choice school. She was very confused about what to do and did not feel a strong desire to attend any other schools or know what she wanted to study. She decided to attend community college for a year while she decided what she wanted to do for her future. We were recently talking about this over breakfast; and I felt bad that she was so confused and frustrated. I reassured her that she would end up where she needed to be and told her not to worry. I felt empathy towards her because I understand that it can be confusing and frustrating to not know what you want your future to be like.
clove: Compassion is love towards someone you care about and want to help.
slove: Sympathy is love for someone's wellbeing and a desire that they should not suffer.
elove: Empathy is a form of love that shows your understanding for another person's situation. Sometimes it can generate good or bad feelings-- you can understand and share a person's joy or sadness and frustration.

writepity: I felt pity when I heard that one of my best  friends was denied from the University of Michigan.  We had both hoped that; after graduation; we would be roommates at the University of Michigan and continue our already strong friendship over the next four years.  Part of what made me pity him was the fact that I had gotten into Michigan; and I know this probably made the situation tough for him.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my dog after returning home from my first semester of college here at the University of Michigan.  Throughout highschool (and really my entire life) I have always had such a soft spot in my heart for Rosie; my dog. My heart cannot help but melt whenever I see her greet me at the door with a stuffed animal in her mouth; wagging excessively and so excited to see me.  I also have a tenderness towards her because I have always slept next to her and this is a bond we have always shared.  To return home from after not seeing her for an entire semester really affected me and reminded me about this heart melting; tender love I have towards her.
writecomp: I'm not sure what compassion means; to be honest.  I guess I felt compassion when my friend learned that he had Mono and would need to leave school for a month.  Obviously; this would be a really tough situatino for anyone.  I felt the need to reach out and cheer him up.
writesymp: One event in my life that evoked sympathy was when one of my best friends here at Michigan heard that her mother died.  While I did not hear this from my friend directly; upon hearing it; I immediately felt horrible for her and wanted nothing more to provide her with anything at all that would help her through this rough time.  What's more; I couldn't help but think about how such an event would tear me apart; and how I would be able to move on in life.  I felt an impulse to call my mom and tell her that I love her.  After thinking about my own mother;  I decided to help my friend out buying her a smoothie (speicifically her favorite kind).
writeempat: I felt empathy towards my best friend when; after receiving too many concussions; was told that he could no longer play football and would have to give up his dream of playing in college. When I was told this;  I immediately felt awful for my friend because I had gone through a very similar situatino my sophomore year of high school; and could thus empathize with him.  I too had a dream of playing sports in college. I wanted to play baseball (a sport I loved and played my entire life) in college; but due to two failed elbow surgeries; was told that I would have to give up the sport. Thus; when my friend got the concussion; I felt I would be a really valuable source for him in getting him through this tough time.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: In a sense it is.  When I think of pity; I do think of one person being higher than another; or "on their high horse" a little bit.
tlove: Tenderness would not be a kind of love; but rather the heart-melting feeling one feels towards someone they truly love.  It's that gut feeling and need to be near them.
clove: I wouldn't call it a kind of love
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I would call it a kind of love in the sense that we usually empathize with the people who are most important in our life.  Empathy requries a lot of care.

writepity: My sister got into a fight with her friends because she made a mistake.  Her friends overreacted and decided to stop speaking to her.  I felt horrible for her because what she did was clearly an accident; but her friends weren't understanding of the situation.  I tried giving her advice about experiences that I've had with getting into fights with friends.
writecomp: On my birthday; my girlfriend wrote me a really nice card.  It made me feel really good about myself; and made me feel like I loved her even more.
writesymp: My cousin is a math genius and had decided that he wanted to be an actuary.  He spent months studying for the first exam and probably put in hundreds of hours of work.  He claimed to have known the material really well; but when he took the exam; he felt nervous and under pressure.  He drew a blank and believes he had a panic attack; causing him to fail the exam.  I felt horrible for him because he put in all that work and still failed.  I tried helping him as much as possible; telling him he would pass it the next time.
writeempat: My friend was trying out for the state's best soccer team.  After working as hard as he could all summer; he made it very far in the tryouts.  Unfortunately; he got dropped at the last cut.  I understood how he felt because I have been cut from teams before too.  I tried telling him it wasn't the end of the world and there are many other good soccer teams he could make.
plove: Pity is not a kind of love
pcontempt: No
clove: It is a love where you care for someone
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love

writetende: I guess I felt a kind of tenderness when my best friend was cheated on by his girlfriend. Oh that bitch! How dare she?  /  / Anyway my buddy was very beat up about it and rightfully so. That's a pretty shitty thing to happen to you. He was fragile at this point and time and conversation had to be chosen meticulously. Couldn't really talk about anything relating to girls or even movies that have "love" in them or anything. Just made him feel bad.  I didn't want to bring up any bad thoughts and make him feel worse. I would only talk about it if he wanted to. He didn't; so we avoided the topic and pretended like it was a normal day.  /  / I just wanted to make him feel no worse than he was already feeling and if I was lucky; even better than he felt. That meant just trying to be fun and exciting to take his mind off of it. No chirping or anything. I did all right.
writecomp: I felt compassion when my grandmother passed away. I know I already used this example but I felt compassion here too. I felt very sorry for my mom and her siblings during this time. Basically for the exact same reasons I listed for "sympathy". These; too me; have the exact same meaning. So they can be used interchangeably and at the same time.  /  /  / I felt compassion for my mom because this was her mom who died. Her best friend and mentor and that's awful. I thought she must feel very alone and therefore felt compassion. An deep sorrow and sympathy.
writesymp: Hmm....I guess a time that I felt sympathetic towards someone would be when my grandmother died earlier this year. Of course I felt sad myself; but I really felt sympathetic towards my mom and her brother and sister. I mean; this was their mom who passed away. I can't even imagine what that must feel like. This is your MOM. She literally brought you into the world and cared for you more than anyone else in the entire world. Would die for you; and now she's just...gone. I'd feel helpless almost. Your mentor and biggest fan is gone.  /  / I wasn't sure what to do. I mean; yes of course I console my mother and tell her I love her. That's the obvious stuff though. I wanted to do more but wasn't sure what that "something more" could/would be. In the end I made a small toast to my grandmother at the wake and it brought the family to tears. Hopefully in a good way.  /  / I guess the only thing my mom even needed was love and compassion from her friends and family. She didn't need anything to be "done' per say. Just people there to show her that even though her mom is gone; everyone else is still here for her.
writeempat: When my good friends dog passed away; I could empathize with them. About 8 months earlier; my little pup had passed away as well. It sucks! These dogs were awesome and we would bring them on playdates together and all that stuff. It was hilarious. When his dog passed I knew exactly what he must be going through because I had gone through it earlier with my dog. It felt even more what he was going through because I was so close with his dog too.  /  / I just felt awful. It sucks having your pet pass away. That's basically what I was thinking: This sucks.  / I went over to his house and hung out with him that day. We just chilled and reminisced about ol Rex.
tlove: Again; I wouldn't necessarily call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: Compassion could be a kind of love. I know I said sympathy and compassion have essentially the same meaning; and sympathy is not a kind of love; but compassion just "sounds" more like a type of love. Can't really explain it.
slove: I don't know if I would call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: Would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: When my brother and I were growing up; we were so much alike.  We looked the same; dressed the same; got the same haircuts; attended the same schools; got the same grades; and had some of the same friends.  Everything changed when we went to school; though.  I went to Michigan; he went to State (already pitiable); and our grades were worlds apart.  I did pretty well; 3.5 average; all As and Bs.  My brother; though; failed roughly 10 classes.  He never went to class at all; and was never motivated.  I thought he was just throwing his life away; ruining his potential career.  Then he was diagnosed with depression; and it all made sense.
