It wasn't that he got dumb when he moved away; it's that the motivation he had when our parents were around evaporated; and he spent the days sleeping; or staying inside.  That's when I felt pity for him.  I knew he was suffering and that it wasn't really his fault.  I wanted to help; but there was nothing much I could do.  The best thing for him was to go see a shrink and get medication; and I couldn't do that for him.  The only bad part is that there was nothing for him to do about it until he was diagnosed; so it's really hard to decide who's responsible.  I don't blame myself and I don't blame him.
writetende: Probably the most vivid situation I can remember is back in elementary school (as silly as it sounds).  I had a crush on this girl; I don't even remember her name.. maybe it was Amanda?  Anyways; we were really young and weren't any good with our emotions; so expressing something like that was so difficult.  Mostly I just let her get away with things I didn't tolerate from others.  When she'd read over my shoulder or play with the blocks I was using; I would let her.  I didn't want to stop her; nor did I feel like it would be right to stop her.  One day though; she yelled at me for sitting in front of her and blocking her view; and that was that.  What can I say?  We were six.
writesymp: The times I feel the most sympathetic are when people I know are going through hardship.  I have a friend named Eric; who I had been friends with since 3rd grade; and he loves his pets.  He always owned a dog; and since his family is quite small they always meant a lot to him.  So when one of his dogs died; I felt terrible for him.  It's an experience I've gone through so many times; and I knew whit it would be like for him.  I decided to try to make him feel a bit better; so I opened up photoshop and loaded a picture of the ghosts from the classic star wars films.  To them I added a picture of his dog; all ghost-like; but happy.  I thought it would at least make him feel a bit better; though in reflection I don't really know why.
writeempat: I always feel empathy of some sort when I see friends going through the same difficult classes that I had.  Physics 240 was an early example.  I got through the class okay; I did well on the tests (in general) and I did okay on the in-class iClicker quizzes (in general) but the studying took a long time and it was definitely a challenge.  When my friends went through the class a semester later; I knew what they were going to be facing.  Whenever they dropped by to complain about a terrible couple homework questions; I nodded my head knowingly.  I wasn't going to tell them "oh yeah it's easy" because I knew it wasn't; and it would be insulting.  But I definitely did say "yeah; I know what it's like."  That's empathy to me.
plove: I wouldn't call it love.
pcontempt: I don't think it's true.  I think you could feel both of them in similar circumstances; but the emotional background of each is completely different.
tlove: I would call it a kind of vulnerable love.
slove: It would be love of the well-being of others.
elove: I don't think it's a kind of love

writepity: I felt pity when my friend one time came to me with academic problems. He was extremely frustrated about all this work he had to do and how everything was too close together. He was extremely worried that he would not be able to finish it all in time and get away with good grades. When asking him when he found out about the assignments and heard that it was assigned weeks ago; I attributed his situation to his procrastination and lack of initiative. From there on; I tried to give him straight; honest instructions on how to go about his days. I told him to cut out his social life for the next week or so and solely focus on his work. I even told him to throw out prior commitments with clubs etc. to work on his classes. During that time; I felt extremely disappointed in him. I thought I was better than him and that I would not have been in such a severe situation. I also felt the urge to abandon him. I wanted to leave him with my advice and allow him to fend for himself. I felt very little compassion. One part of me thought of the prospect of feeling guilty for abandoning him; but another part of me also thought that this is a good lesson for him to learn if he is to succeed later in life. In the end; I did abandon him; allowing him t fend for himself. When he came back to me with disappointment over his grades; I expressed further disapproval of his actions (as he had decided to go hang out frequently during exam time) and told him to get his act together.
writesymp: Recently; I felt sympathy for a friend whose grandmother was in critical condition. During that time; it affected my relationship with her because I thought she was very delicate and was extremely sensitive to words or jokes that may come off wrong. When talking to her; I felt bad for her and her situation and worried that she wouldn't be able to share with people her sorrow in order to ease the burden of suffering. I offered her my ears and advice/friendship if she ever needed anything. She thanked me and the conversation ended. Upon her return to school; she seemed happy but now stressed about her classes since she missed a whole week of them. From there on; I felt worried about her graduation plans and whether she would become extremely stressed next year due to the possibility of dropping one of her classes this semester. I wanted to give her a hug; hang out with her one on one and see how she was doing in general; and just try to connect with her again (since our friendship was becoming distant as well). However; I have not followed up with that plan but plan to do so in the future.
writeempat: One time I felt empathy was when I was talking to my friend during high school on Facebook. We were discussing things she had to do with her extremely hectic schedule and being on multiple club committees and having extremely hard classes. During that time; I felt quite sad for her because I didn't like to see her suffer so miserably. I felt as though she was going to break down and not be able to triumph over such menial tasks compared to what the more important things are in life. As she described her feelings of bitterness towards the other people on her committee and their lack of work ethic or competence. I felt a tinge of anger and sorrow that she had to deal with such things because I certainly understood that same feeling when working in group projects. She moved on to wanting to scream in her pillow or cry. During that time as well as when she mentioned how she was going to manage the next few weeks; I kept thinking of ways to help her with her stress; her focus; and for her to find time to relax just a little. I also offered my help if she ever needed anything. When I hit walls of thought; I decided to instead resort to sending her music I thought would help her focus and feel more positive. All the stress she feels and I feel even now is something that should never cause anyone to break down or even cry. That is not the point of college or education. It should provide a fascinating and curious standpoint on sophisticated / novel things.
plove: Pity is NOT love.
pcontempt: Yes in a sense because pity and contempt both embody that feeling of anger and jealousy.
slove: Sympathy would be a type of love where one person is dominant over another in terms of providing affection when the other person is in great need. this would resemble a mother consoling a child who has been hurt.
elove: Empathy would be a kind of understanding type of love. You are there to morally support the person; attend to things they need that are not obvious or something they need not say they need.

writepity: I used to work with a guy who had an alcohol abuse problem. We worked in the same factory together; and he'd often come in for our early-morning shift pretty hungover and looking somewhat disheveled. He was an older guy; probably in his 50s or so. It was my understanding that he had had a pretty tough life up to that point; which didn't necessarily justify his excessive drinking but definitely made it somewhat more understandable. Over time it got worse; and he showed up to work still noticeably tipsy one morning and dozed off while doing some hand assembly. Rather than fire him; the plant manager decided that they would start breathalyzing him every morning when he got into work. The idea was that if he failed; they would have him wait around in the office until he was sober enough to drive and then he would be sent home without pay for the rest of the day. They hoped this would help curtail his drinking some; but ultimately they had to let him go as he was simply missing way too much work and was unable to meet their requirements for continued employment. I felt bad for the guy; but didn't know him that well or know what I could do about his situation. I would say that I felt pity in that I didn't get any joy out of his suffering; and wished there was something that could be done; but didn't feel particularly able to intervene or contribute positively to the situation. Still; it was sad to see him struggle to maintain an appropriate level of sobriety for work; and knowing that he didn't have much family around him; I wished there was more of a support system available to him. The whole thing was kind of sad to see play out.
writetende: Tenderness is also a feeling that I felt towards my friend with the substance abuse problem. When she was staying on the couch in my house; we would often spend a lot of time talking about the things that she was going through and the things that she wanted from her life. I always thought of her as a sister in some ways; and wanted to alleviate her material suffering as well as to be open and comforting with her in an emotional way as well. It was important to me that her emotional wellbeing improve as well as her physical living conditions; and so as we had many deep conversations about things I would also open up to her about things and try to be understanding and supportive of the things she told me as well.
writecomp: A good friend of mine was experiencing some drug abuse problems for a few years; and she was in and out of her parents house and sometimes living on the street as well. At times it seemed like she was genuinely ready for help; and at other times it seemed like she had little or no regard for the consequences of the decisions she was making. She had stolen from people before to help fund her addiction; so it was difficult to trust her or to have her around. She'd sometimes come around pretty strung out; as well; which made it very impossible to really interact with her or she'd drink to the point where she needed constant care and attention. She pretty categorically refused treatment; so we were forced into deciding what to do about her living situation. She was someone I had been friends with for a long time; but she had also taken advantage of my attempts to help her in the past. Regardless; I was unable to deal with seeing her being homeless and on the street; so I let her come and stay on my couch for about a week. I just wanted to do whatever I could to try and diminish her suffering or improve her quality of life; even though I may have just been providing a warm place and consequence-free place to go for her to stop using. I wanted to make sure that she was safe; even if I may have been enabling her to some small degree. Despite what she had done to betray my trust in the past; I couldn't live with her being out on the street.
writesymp: An acquaintance/friend of mine had a friend of theirs die. I did not know the person who died; so I didn't really have a connection to them; but felt bad that my friend had to deal with the grief that accompanies such a loss. I didn't think that I could really do much to alleviate their suffering; and didn't feel that we knew each other well enough that I could be of much or any comfort to them; but I felt sympathy for them in that I understood they were going through a difficult time and hoped they could find a quick and meaningful closure. I attended the viewing and told them that I was sorry for their loss; but didn't stay very long or really engage them in any meaningful conversation of substance.
writeempat: A close friend of mine recently lost her grandparent; whom she was very close to. She was understandably devastated; as she had never lost a grandparent before and was unsure how to cope with the feelings of loss.  I had already lost all of my grandparents at this point; the last of which was my grandmother who had passed only about 8 months before; so I very much understood what it was that she was going through.  I was pretty close with my mom's parents much like she was her grandmother; and I could remember what it was like when they passed. I empathized with the tremendous emotional reaction and sense of loss; and wanted to do what I could to help her through this situation. It ultimately brought the two of us closer; as we were able to talk through a lot of how the situation made us feel. I wanted to try and explain to her that things would get better as time passed; as they had for me; and that ultimately she would have a better grip on her emotions as she moved through the various stages of grief. I think it was good that we both had each other to talk about these things with; and to have someone other than family; who is similarly affected; to help the other cope with the death.
plove: I do not think that it is a type of love. I think that is what sets it apart from compassion; which I do think is a type of love. When you feel compassion for a person; you are emotionally invested in their situation and the outcome; so you are willing to do whatever must be done to ensure there is a positive resolution. When you pity someone; I don't believe you feel obligated or emotionally invested in the outcome; only perhaps that you perhaps would like to see things would work out better for them.
pcontempt: I think that it can be. Some people pity others; and in doing so feel superior to them. I do; however; believe that you can pity someone but still hope the best for them without necessarily involving yourself.
tlove: It would be an emotional and caring love; much like compassion is. Compassion to me is more tied to physical well-being and while there is also an element of emotional consideration as well; I feel as if tenderness encompasses much more of this emotional aspect and has a degree of reciprocity as well.
clove: I think compassion is love that you feel for another person unconditionally; and despite what they may have done to you or to themselves to bring about the situation. I think there are often elements of concern or sympathy blended together with compassion; but not necessarily.
slove: I don't think that I would call sympathy love. It's feeling bad for the situation someone else finds themselves in; and feeling like you have some obligation to try and comfort them at some level; but one that is more superficial.
elove: It's a kind of love shared between two people who have experienced a similar event; one that is typically sad or tragic; that allows one person to also experience and feel part of what the other person is feeling at that time.

writepity: My friend Rachel had a lot of stomach and health problems senior year which caused her to lose a lot of weight. I felt pity for her and I felt bad for her. I also felt very disconnected from her because she was not open in sharing her problems or talking about them. I wanted her problems to go away and to make her eat and everyone also secretly thought it was a cover up for an eating disorder. I would sometimes talk about it with her but it was hard. I would say " this situation is so bizarre and unfair. I can't believe you have to deal with this. You're so strong" but when i walked away I merely felt disconnected from her. Our lives were so different as I was eating and happy; and she was anorexic and miserable. She was a difficult person to be friends with in general and I felt good when I was able to console her; but ultimately our differences made me feel as if I was talking to an adult or child; not someone my own age.
writecomp: When I volunteered in Ecuador; I felt compassion towards the children of the village. They were young children who had hard lives for no reason other than that this was the life they were born into. It was rewarding putting a smile on their face; teaching them English; and playing with them. I felt sad for them and I wished there was more that I could do.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards my friend Tali when she was in a relationship with a boyfriend that did not treat her well. I had gone through a similar thing. I felt like I understood how she was feeling and that I was on her side. I felt as if I could connect to her better and be there for her better because I had been through the similar thing. I felt confident giving her advice and being there for her. However; each person makes their own decisions and so as much as I could console her and be there for her; I could not change her actions. I wished I could have gotten her out of the relationship but at the end of the day; I knew that she would not. Also; sometimes my empathy would turn into anger because she would not listen to me. I felt like I had been through it before and was more mature than her since I had experienced it already.
plove: I don't think pity is a kind of love. I think it is something a bystander feels when they can't do anything. I think it is a pathetic emotion and if you actually loved the person; you would help them.
pcontempt: Yes I think it is true because both view the person as less than.
clove: It is a love that shows you care for others even if they are below you.
elove: It is a giving type of love but ultimately does not solve the problems at hand.

writepity: I work at an elementary school as an "after school counselor". Basically I just hang out and play with the kids and make sure they're behaving. Last week was their spring break; so we had full day child care and I worked all day on Friday. We only had about 12 kids when we usually have around 100 to start off. There is one girl who can be kind of a handful; but all of the staff loves her anyway. She is in 3rd grade and she has a lot of friend drama going on right now. At one point on Friday; she ran up to me sobbing and told me that her best friend had told her that she didn't want to ever play with her anymore. I tried to comfort her; but she was hysterical. I felt really bad for her and really angry at the other girl; because we have had a lot of problems with her meanness this year. I wanted to go talk to her and make her apologize (even though I knew she wouldn't mean it) just so that I could attempt to do something. I didn't necessarily feel her sadness; I just felt bad for her because she keeps going back to this one mean friend when she should go find some new friends; or just hang out with the the me and the other counselors when her other friends aren't around. It just made me wish she could realize that; even though she's so young.
writecomp: The summer before I started my senior year in high school I went on a mission trip with my church to Washington DC. For 2 hours each day I worked at a Vacation Bible school in one of the worse parts of the city. Many of the children there were at high risk for AIDS because of their parents or their situations; and some already had cases of it within their families. It was definitely a situation that was shocking and out of my comfort zone the first day; but as I got to know the kids I fell in love with them. I have always loved working with kids; but this was such an amazing experience. One girl stood out to me a ton; because she constantly clung to my arm; and we became very good friends in only 5 days; she was 10 years old and never wanted to go home at the end of the day. And honestly; I didn't want her to either; because I didn't know the details of her situation; but if she was that afraid of going home; they couldn't be good. At the end of the week; she told me I was her best friend; she asked me if she could come home with me; and she told me that I should never leave when I told her she would have to stay here. In this week; I felt like I wanted to do whatever I could to get her out and to help her have a better life and to give her the love and support she needed as a 10 year old girl reaching her teen years. But I knew I couldn't and I felt heartbroken by that. I was so hard to say goodbye; and i cried quite a bit throughout the weeks after; but I know I will never forget her or the other kids in that neighborhood. They hold a special place in my heart; and if I ever get the chance to go back; or to change their situation; I would never pass it up/
writesymp: Yesterday my friend in my German class came in and looked really upset and kind of flustered. I asked her if she was doing okay; and she told me not really. She was really stressed out; and had slept through 3 different alarms; missing 2 different classes; and a scheduled meeting for office hours. She also said she thought she was getting sick and she really just wanted to be done so she could go home. As she was telling me all of this; I felt sorry for her. I felt like if I had been in that situation; I would be upset; I felt pity. As she was telling me what happened; I just kept saying; "oh that sucks; I'm sorry." I didn't know what else to say; because it did. I also told her I was sure our professor would understand that mistakes happen and that she didn't purposefully skip the meeting. I told her that we're all stressed; but that soon it will be over and she can go home feeling really accomplished that she finished her freshman year of college.
writeempat: My friend told me the very detailed story about her past relationship. She is a year younger than me and she told me that she is in love with this guy still and wants to be with him but he cheated on her multiple times. I felt so much empathy for her because I saw a lot of myself at the same time last year in her. I was cheated on in a relationship and I had the same feelings as she did at that point after our break-up. When she was telling me; I could feel the pain that she was describing; I could feel the emptiness and hopelessness; even though; I don't feel them for myself anymore; I felt them for her. I was thinking of the ways that I coped and what helped me get over the situation and wanted to tell her; and tried to tell her; but as I was; I knew that it wouldn't do much. When I went through this; so many people tried to help me; and I really appreciated it; but nothing they said helped. It was something I had to work through on my own terms. I knew that all she needed was someone to listen and be her friend; she didn't want people to tell her it would be okay; because she didn't think it would and got annoyed when people did; just like I did. So I didn't tell her it would be okay. I just let her rant and cry and tell me everything she wanted to about the situation and her feelings. and I felt them with her.
plove: I don't think pity is love.
pcontempt: I don't think it is true
clove: Compassion is definitely love. I think of it as loving someone in the way that you would love your closest family member. It's wanted to help give someone everything they deserve.
sfeltother: 1. Pity / 2. Understanding / 3. Relief (That it had never happened to me)
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: Empathy is understanding and caring; and by understanding and caring; you are loving.

writepity: To me; pity is either when I feel sorry for someone who is somewhat inferior; or when they caused the situation and it backfired on them. It can be just as detached as compassion. For example; I felt pity toward someone on a TV show; when he accidentally destroyed something very valuable. It was a comic book in mint condition that he was going to sell for two thousand dollars so that he could afford his wedding. On his way to the pawn shop; though; he stumbled and the comic book fell out of its cover and into a puddle; rendering it completely worthless. I felt really bad for him; because he really needed the money and it was just an unfortunate incident; and because it reminded me of when I had accidentally lost or destroyed valuable items. However; I still felt like it could have been easily avoided if he had just been more careful. I suppose I did sort of feel like he was inferior to me; because I imagined that I would have been more careful and less clumsy; and would have avoided the situation. I wanted to go back in time and fix it for him; but obviously; I couldn't (and it didn't matter because it was a TV show).
writetende: Tenderness is a more affectionate emotion than any of the others; and it can be felt in much more positive situations. It is sort of like a gentle kindness or a gentle affection. An example of when I felt tenderness is when I met my baby niece for the first time. She was so small and looked so helpless that I just had to be as gentle as possible with her. I felt a great deal of affection toward her; because she was now family; and perhaps also because I felt like I had to feel that way toward a helpless baby. I picked her up as carefully as possible; taking care not to hold her too tightly or too loosely; because I was terrified of hurting her. I just wanted to hold her and to help her in any way that I could. I suppose tenderness is somewhat similar to pity; in that you often feel it toward someone more vulnerable than you; but it also is less detached; closer to love.
writecomp: While compassion is similar to empathy; I think it is slightly more detached. For example; I can feel empathy toward my friend; but for strangers; I feel compassion. One example of when I felt compassion was when I heard about the shooting at the Sandy Hook Elementary School. When I heard the news; I was absolutely shocked and horrified and thought about what it must be like for the parents and friends of the people inside the school when they heard about it. I tried to understand their pain; but felt like I never really could until I experienced a similar thing; or at least until I had a child. I could try to imagine what they were going through; but because I didn't know them and I hadn't had a similar experience; it was less powerful than empathy. I still did try to imagine it; to understand. I wanted to help as much as possible; although I knew it would be difficult - I would not be able to comfort someone directly; only help by raising money or raising awareness.
writesymp: Sympathy is similar to both empathy and compassion; but it is less involved than empathy and less detached than compassion. I would feel sympathy toward someone I know but only if I could not understand what they were going through. One example of when I felt sympathy is when my friend's father passed away. He seemed to be healthy; and it was an unexpected heart attack that left everyone in disbelief and shock. I started crying when I heard the news; but mainly because I felt so awful for my friend; not because I knew him or because I knew how she felt. I tried to understand what my friend was going through; but since I had never had a family member die; especially one so close to me; I just couldn't understand. I felt like I really wanted to help; but I just wasn't sure how I could help; because she needed people who could better understand the situation. I tried comforting her; but I didn't feel like it did very much to ease her pain. I actually told her that I couldn't imagine what she was going through; but that I would try to help in any way possible and I would be there for her if she needed me.
writeempat: To me; empathy is when you can actually feel someone else's pain or disappointment or other emotions. It often comes from having experienced that same emotion. An example of when I felt empathy toward someone is when my friend's dog passed away. She had had that dog since she was born; and he was one of her best friends in the world. He died unexpectedly after being hit by a car. When I heard; I was first shocked and in disbelief; and then the pain washed over me. Not only did I feel for my friend; sorry that she lost her best friend; but I could also understand and feel the pain myself; because I went through a similar experience when I lost my beloved dog to a reckless driver a few years earlier. This experience brought back the painful memories of that day. I thought about the phone call I received from my parents while I was at school; the wave of shock and disbelief and pain that hit me so hard I had to sit down. I thought of the first day without her; expecting to hear her clacking across the floor but only hearing silence. When I came over right away to comfort my friend; she mentioned that she had the same experiences. I told her that I was really sorry for her loss and that I understood exactly what she was going through; because I had gone through the same thing.
plove: To me; pity is not a kind of love. Like with compassion; you can feel pity even when you don't know or don't like someone.
pcontempt: I think this has a grain of truth in it. If you pity someone; it does not necessarily mean that you have contempt for them; especially those you think inferior to you; like children and the handicapped; because it is difficult to hate someone in a situation like that. Pity is more related to superiority; thinking that if you were in that situation; you would have done better. However; there is something along the lines of scorn or disdain.
tlove: I would call it a kind of love; a kind of affection. It is a love that is reserved mainly for those who seem helpless or vulnerable; those with whom you feel the need to be gentle.
clove: I don't think that compassion is a kind of love - it is much more detached than that.
slove: Sympathy is a little bit like love; in that it shows that you care for someone and want to try to understand what they're going through; even if it is impossible for you to imagine. It is more of a friendly affection than full-on love; though; because you can feel sympathetic toward people you don't know very well (although I don't think I feel sympathy toward total strangers; but rather compassion).
elove: I don't think it's necessarily a kind of love. You could feel empathy even for someone you hated; but showing empathy and acting on the feeling could be showing them that you care.

writepity: As a vice president in my sorority; one of my duties was to work with our advisers to approve or deny excuses girls would send in to miss out on mandatory events; or to explain why. In order to ensure that people actually show up for things; girls have a certain number of excuses per semester. One girl wrote to us asking for more excuses because she was beginning to apply to grad schools; was studying for a test (the MCAT or GRE); and was also working. However; our chapter advisers voted her request down; meaning she now also had to balance the sorority into that mix. At the time my sister was doing almost the exact same thing (minus the sorority involvement) and I knew how stressed she could be. I felt pity because this girl really deserved the extra excuses I though; and so I was angry at the advisers (who are older women) for not understanding how times had changed and how it is acceptable to miss several events. So after all the voting was done and I had to go tell the girl; I also had the president come with me; and together we worked out a deal between us to help her technically have more excuses; but it just wouldn't be documented.
writetende: I felt tenderness when my boyfriend was telling me how he often got homesick. As an international student; he only sees his family once or twice a year; and having recently relocated across the country for a new job; he is feeling it more now because he had to leave Ann Arbor and all of his friends here behind. I felt tenderness for him because I understood how split he must feel: excited to begin his job and make new friends and memories in Seattle; but also how frightening it must be; and how much it aches internally when something is too new. I am moving to St. Louis myself soon; leaving behind my family and friends as well; so as he was telling me how he felt (scared; anxious; excited; just wanting familiarity) I was imagining how I will feel in a few weeks; and tried to act in a way that I thought would be comforting to me. I told him what a great opportunity he has; and what a great job he will do. I reminded him that when he came to Ann Arbor he felt the same way; and look how quickly he got to feel at home here. I made sure to stress the fact that all his family and friends are here for him if he needs anything; that the distance wont matter because there's still the ability to visit; and they are all cheering for him.
writesymp: My grandmother was recently diagnoses with an aggressive form of dementia; and she has been doing badly ever since; moving from one care facility to another. It is very trying on my dad; who not only has to travel several hours to come visit her; but who then is not guaranteed that she will remember who he is when he arrives. My grandmother was a very optimistic person; a sweet grandmotherly type; who had traveled to dozens of countries and to all the continents in her lifetime. Seeing her frail; nervous; quiet; and lost is something no one in our family is able to get used to. As the oldest; my father was made responsible for carrying out her will when the time comes; and that realization hit him quite hard. It has made him reconsider how his own life is going; and I see how uncertain it has made him.
writeempat: My hometown has a large homeless population. Whenever I travel home I see them on the side of the roads with signs; or laying down under overpasses just trying to find shelter of any kind. This makes me feel sad and helpless; because I do not know what I could do to help them; especially since I would love to help them all; but I do not have the resources to do that. This is especially hard in the winter months around the holidays; because while my family; friends; and I are all warm and celebrating; trying to stop the holiday weight gain; those poor souls are out there freezing and starving. I feel selfish because I have so much when they have nothing. But then I feel confused when others tell me to not worry about them or tell me to not give them anything because they brought this on themselves due to drugs; involvement with gangs; or laziness.
plove: I do not think it is a type of love.
pcontempt: I could see how it is true. I think you can feel pity for someone regardless to if you like them or hate them; it depends on the situation they are in; and if you think they deserve to be in that situation or not.
tlove: Tenderness is a type of love when you are emotionally connected to the person. It doesn't mean that you are able to empathize with them; agree with what they are feeling; or imagine yourself in their shoes; it just means you care about what happens to them/ their emotional well-being regardless of the situation.
slove: I think it is a type of love when you wish you were able to change or alter their situation; regardless of how they got into it. Generally they are sad or upset so you want to make them feel better.
elove: I do not see empathy as a type of love.

writepity: I felt pity for my dad because of his relationship with his daughter; my sister. I felt sad for the situation and wished i could do something about it. I dont get involved because i dont want to get my sister to be angry at me for getting involved; so i dont. I said that he should just except the situation. My description would be "why dont you tell her to call me; i really7 want to talk to her"
writetende: I feel tenderness towards my ex-girlfriend because of my love for her. I felt happy; warm and bubbley. I wanted to love her for the rest of my life; i still do and i told her i loved her. her soft smooth skin made warm by the blood in her veins and the glow in her eyes is how i felt towards her
writecomp: i felt compassion towards my sister because i love her and feel like i can relate with her because of our life experiences. i was feeling joy and warmth and understanding towards her. i wanted to always feel that emotion; i told her i could relate with her and i said that we both can get through this
writesymp: i feel sympathy towards my mom because she works two jobs and has to deal with my dad; among other things. I felt like i could relate with the situation because i had two jobs and had to deal with my dad too. I wanted to help; but i didnt because i couldnt. I didnt say anything
plove: pity is the kind of love that is beneth you
pcontempt: yes; because both contempt and pity involve anger; and thinking you are better than this person in this regard
tlove: it would be the kind of love that shakes mountains; flows through valleys and flies through the open skies
clove: compassion is the type of love that can relate with a person
slove: it is the kind of love that is relatable and the kind of love that has similar experiences

writepity: I remember seeing very poor people in Mumbai; India; some of whom had physical disabilities; and feeling pity for them.  I was not sure all of the physical disabilities were real; but felt pity for them nonetheless; if they had to fake such things in order to get enough to live on.  Their circumstances were so distressing that one could not feel otherwise than pity; even if they were trying to take advantage of tourists.  What a way to live!
writetende: This morning at breakfast; I went to get half and half for my coffee and remembered that I had used the last of the carton the morning before.  I was about to feel frustrated when I discovered that my husband had gone to the grocery the night before and bought me half and half; which was so typical of his wonderful care for me that I felt much tenderness toward him.
writecomp: I just finished reading a book titled "Mermaid"; which was written by and about a woman who was born without legs as a result of her mother's having taken Thalidimide when she was pregnant. This woman had such problems coping with her loss of legs that it was distressing to read about it.  I felt sorry for the mother because she was experiencing morning sickness; which is why she took the drug; and she would have been horrified if she had known what it would do to her fetus.  I remember reading about all of the cases in Germany; and thought how awful it would be for these women.  Of course there was nothing that I could do for or about this woman in the book.  Her whole life was affected and it took years for her to come to grips with her situation.  It affected her whole family; including her parents; and was such a sad situation.
writesymp: A good friend's wife was diagnosed with ovarian cancer; in spite of having lived a life as a vegetarian and an avid practicer (and teacher) of yoga.  A totally healthy life; and it seemed so unfair.  Numerous measures were tried to stop or ameliorate the circumstances; but nothing helped.  She and her husband were very brave about it; and I admired their attitude.  I could not think of anything to do or say that might help.
writeempat: I just came from a senior exercise class in which we were doing some moderate exercise and the man who was standing next to me passed gas.  I felt empathy; because at our advanced age this is a common affliction; and I knew that he was aware of what had happened; and that he would be embarassed.  I was embarassed for him; and felt "there; but for the grace of God; go I."  I did not do or say anything; because that would have made it worse for the man.
plove: Love of fellow humans; no matter how dissimilar or unpleasant the circumstances.
pcontempt: No.  Contempt is despicable.
tlove: Love itself.
clove: Love for fellow human; particularly fellow woman.
slove: Love for fellow humans; particularly for fellow women.
elove: Love for fellow human; particularly older people.

writetende: When I think of tenderness; the first example that came to mind was the feeling towards my younger sister. I attribute tenderness to gentleness; and because my sister is 5 years younger than me; growing up I have always nicknamed her my "baby sister". When I interact with my sister; I care for her a lot and make sure she is feels safe; protected; fed; happy; etc. A more specific example of when I felt tenderness would be tucking her into bed at night and kissing her on the cheek; "good night." I think tenderness comes with a lot of care; warmth; and love.
writecomp: (I'm not familiar with the technical definition of compassion; so I am typing of what I know) A time when I felt compassion was when I tried to help my friend feel better after he had failed an exam. It was a situation that I couldn't really do anything about; but I could help him feel better emotionally. I felt bad that he didn't do well on his exam; but I truly did care of his well-being and hoped he would feel better.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards one of my close friends who was suffering through many misfortunes in her life. Her relationship with her boyfriend wasn't as stable; her mom had recently been diagnosed with stomach cancer; and she had financial troubles at her college. I was greatly concerned for her well-being but felt also felt like I couldn't do much to help her; except offering myself as a listener and a friend she could open up to. I didn't like hearing about the unfortunate circumstances. I felt that my role was more of a 3rd party because I wasn't directly involved in the happenings. However; I felt that my role was more of support for my friend.
tlove: Love that is gentle

writepity: I feel pity for a family member who has problems with narcotics. I feel bad that she is in the situation she's in; and I think that it is an awful place to be. However; since I haven't experienced what she's experienced and don't feel the same things she does; I often forget to be gracious and only pity her; continuing to be angry at her choices even though she doesn't have that many options. I recognize that her lifestyle is hard and that she only has so much control; but because I am distant; I often wrongly feel pity more than empathy or sympathy.
writetende: I often feel tenderness; and remind myself to feel tenderness; toward my little sister. I try to be gentle; calm; and slow to get angry with her. I am tender with her when I remember that she is only 8 years old; and that some things aren't worth getting angry about. I want to giver her grace and forgiveness. When I do get angry with her; there should still be tenderness there; she should know that I don't love her any less when I'm angry than when I'm happy with her.
writecomp: A few summers ago; I went to the Dominican Republic on a mission trip with my church. I felt huge compassion for the Dominican people in the village where we worked. I felt automatic; strong love for them. My heart went out to them. I worked with great joy and gave my all in everything we did in the DR. I loved what I was doing; and the people I was doing it for.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my roommate over the past few weeks when there has been a lot going on in her life that is overwhelming her. She and her boyfriend had been fighting a lot; and she broke up with him; which was a big step. Then that wasn't as easy as it should have been and is still having lasting effects on her. A lot of stuff had also been going on with her and her family's health. All of these things have been compounding and while I am not directly experiencing them; I care for her and see her struggling so it causes me pain for her. I talk to her about all of these thing and tell her that I'm sorry about the situation and make sure she knows that I am here for her and support her.
writeempat: I felt empathy for a friend of mine whose family friend recently died. I empathized with him because my grandmother died about a year ago; and I understood the confusing emotions he was feeling; and that they are hard to deal with and comprehend because death is such a powerful force that effects everyone a little bit differently. In talking with him; I was thinking about what death does to those it touches; and that it is different for every single person. This range and unpredictableness can actually bring people closer together; as it allowed me to have empathy for my friend.
plove: A very distant love.
tlove: gentle; graceful; merciful love
clove: a strong; inherent; joyful kind of love
slove: A true; genuine; sorrowful; and slightly distant love. Not necessarily badly distant; just in that there might not be much you can do.

writepity: I think I just realized that pity and sympathy could have a similar definition. Pity is the way that you feel for someone in situation where they have just had misfortune. I felt pity for one of my friends who was a dancer. She was preparing for a competition for months with rehearsals everyday. A few weeks before the competition all of her efforts were crushed because she fractured something in her ankle during practice. I felt so bad for her because this one injury ruined her chances of competing and all that she had worked for.
writetende: Tenderness is most associated with the word love and I can always see the phrase "love and tenderness". The best situation of tenderness is when my sister fell off her bike and had scrapes all over her arms and legs. My mom just patched her up with band aids and gave her hugs and stuff to show her love and it made my sister feel better even though the pain from the fall was still there. Essentially; tenderness is a part of showing someone affection in a way that is close and has impact on the other individual.
writecomp: Compassion is a kind of love I think and it is when you show praise and gratitude to someone that has done something great for you. I had a research paper due in the morning and I only brought in a hard copy and forgot to turn it in online. I called my mom as soon as I got to school and asked her to log onto my computer and submit the document before class started. With no questions asked; she quickly did the task and efficiently and I was so grateful. I felt great compassion and gratitude towards her and was so lucky to have her do this for me.
writesymp: Sympathy is just when you feel bad for someone; even if you have no relation to the situation. This one guy was walking down the hallway with a science project. And my high school being pretty small in size; the hallways were not that big; so it just looked like a disaster about to happen. The project was immense 3D diagram of the human heart and looked like it took many hours and time and effort to finish. As soon as the bell rang; hundreds of students stormed out of classrooms towards the front door to leave; while bumping and accidentally hitting the guy. And then after one unfortunate hit; the diagram fell to the floor and broke into many pieces. I felt really bad for him; because he clearly put so much effort into his work and all of that was ruined. All I could say or do was help him pick up the pieces and there was nothing more.
writeempat: My friend had just had their dog; Beau; die and I was there with them to provide empathy because I had gone through a similar experience before. I had lost a pet recently and I knew what it was like and all the emotions that run through someone's mind when they have to go through such a traumatic event such as this and how to deal with the situation. I went over to her house and just sat and talked with her while she was crying. I could not say that much; but I felt empathy for her and her situation and just being there for her really helped her out I think. She did most of the talking with all of her memories of her dog and I just sat there listening to her vent and this process really just helped her clear head.
plove: Pity is not a kind of love.
pcontempt: I am not really sure what the saying is trying to get across.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love. The specific type of love I am not sure; but it is the feeling of warmth and homeliness when you receive this kind of emotion.
clove: Compassion is a type of love and that of great gratitude and praise.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: When I feel "pity" towards someone; it is when I feel bad for them and consider their circumstances to be unfortunate. One example that comes to mind of when I felt pity was when I was in Detroit and a man came up to my friends and I asking for spare change. He said that he was an Afghanistan veteran who was down on his luck; couldn't find work after returning to America and thus ended up on the streets. I felt pity for him because he was a former soldier who had done great things for our country and this is how he was rewarded: with no home; no job; and no prospects but to beg others for money to live on. I could tell that he wanted to put his life back together because he had made an effort to dress as nicely as possible and had a way about him that spoke to his intelligence and demeanor. I pitied him because I knew that his circumstances were not entirely his fault; he was a victim of bad luck; a bad economy; and bad government systems to support veterans with health care/employment/housing. I felt sad for him; and I felt relieved that I was fortunate enough to not have to live the same lifestyle as him. I felt a strong desire to help him; so I gave him some spare change and said "I hope this helps".
writetende: Tenderness is when you have a special fondness for somebody and really care about them. I feel tenderness towards my brother because I have a special place in my heart for him and I don't feel like anybody else could replace his role in my life. One instance where I felt this tenderness was when I returned home from a six-week solo vacation away from my family; and my brother took me out on a drive just so we could talk and catch up. My mom said that he had missed me and that he said that the house seemed empty without me; and his gesture showed me that he valued me as a person too. I felt very close to him at that point because I had also missed him greatly and it was good to have him back in my life. I felt tenderness in that particular moment because I realized how important he was to me and how empty I would feel if he were no longer in my life.
writecomp: I define compassion as an understanding of another's difficulties and specifically a desire to help. When I volunteered at a food bank; I saw parents coming in with many kids in tow and signs of a lower socioeconomic status. The fact that they told me they were dependent upon food stamps and food bank donations to feed their children made me feel compassion for them because I understood a situation that was different than mine and felt an emotional attachment to their situation; and also because I had a strong desire to help them. I was thinking that I hope their situation is improved because I do not want to see them continue struggling to get by financially. I did my best to help them by providing food for them; but I wanted to do more to help; even though I know I couldn't personally help alleviate their poverty.
writesymp: Sympathy is where I am able to understand another's situation and feel the emotions they are feeling. An example of when I felt sympathy was when my dad was the victim of fraud on ebay and a phony seller ended up stealing $3000 of his money ;and he had no way to contact ebay and get back the money. I felt the same emotions he did; which were disbelief; anger; and feeling cheated. I couldn't do anything about the situation because it was his money and his financial affairs; and I had no place involving myself in that; but I did feel bad for him and sympathize with his situation regardless. I felt like I understood his emotional pain and suffered with him.
plove: PIty is a kind of love because it shows you care enough about another person to feel sad that they are going through a certain situation.
pcontempt: No; I don't think this is true. You can feel pity for someone without looking down upon them and judging them relative to yourself. It is important to keep in mind that many "pitiful" situations could happen to anybody; including the onlooker.
tlove: Tenderness is absolutely an expression of love! I think tenderness is having a special fondness for someone and feeling connected to them; which also qualifies love. Tenderness is an expression of my love for people.
clove: Compassion is love because you are feeling a connection to somebody else and want to help them.
slove: No; I don't think sympathy is a kind of love per se; because you can be sympathetic towards another's situation and not love them any more than a platonic love.

writepity: 1. For high school; I went to a private school after having gone to a public school up until then. I remember visiting the high school I would have attended to pick up my younger brother (who just ended up staying in public school); and seeing many of the kids sitting outside waiting for their parents to pick them up. It was obvious that many of them didn't care about school; and their parents/teachers had probably given up on them too. Obviously not all the students at that school were like that; but many of the kids waiting outside were. I felt guilty and sorry for them at the same time. They were close to my age and my brother's; but they were leading such different lives from both of us; just because of their environment. I thought it was unfortunate that most of these kids; probably from a young age; were encouraged to do well in school from those around them. I thought that if I ever had kids; I wouldn't want them to be like those kids I saw; and hopefully; I would be able to help some other children in the future grow up to be more motivated to succeed academically.
writetende: My mom and I are very close; and because I've been away from home for a long time (I went to a boarding school since 9th grade); I feel like that bond has gotten much stronger. In high school; we were required to leave campus for all breaks but in college; that isn't the case. I didn't go home for fall break and was tempted not to go home for Thanksgiving because I had tests coming up right after the break. However; I remember my mom calling me and asking if I would come home for break. The tone in her voice made me feel like it would be awful if I said no; so when I said yes; she was genuinely excited. When she came to pick me up at the airport; she was thrilled to see me; and it was then (and when I told her I'd come for break); that I felt tenderness towards her. After such an occasion; I have tried to text and call my mom more frequently and try to come home for breaks if it's not too much of a burden on my schedule.
writecomp: I volunteer at a local assisted living home frequently. This location is mostly filled with residents on Medicaid or Medicare; so the facilities are much poorer than that of private-funded assisted living homes. When I first decided to volunteer; I was reluctant as I hadn't spent much time with old people and felt like I wouldn't be able to connect with them. However; as I spent time with these elderly by playing games with them or just chatting with them; I developed a connection with many of them. A lot of them saw me more often than they saw friends or family; and they were genuinely excited to see someone outside of the assisted living home to visit and spend time with them. I felt great for being able to provide some sort of comfort for them; and decided to try to get other people to volunteer at the assisted living home. At this particular one; no one ever came to volunteer. I think the staff and residents were very pleased with the volunteer and excited to see them when they came to visit.
writesymp: There was a boy named Jay in my grade in high school. No one was fond of him because he was rude and had a horrible temper. But when my senior year started; we were told in my school's opening Assembly (similar to the idea of chapel that some schools have; minus the religious part) that Jay was in a coma. Later; I heard he had been scaling a wall on some dorm that he was staying in for a summer camp and fell from the third/fourth story. I had been in several classes with him and though I always founded him rude and short-tempered; I felt terrible for how I had felt about him before. But I felt terrible for his younger sister; who was two years younger than us. She was a staff writer on the school newspaper; which I was an editor of; and I found her sweet (and the complete opposite of her older brother). I felt sorry for her; and knew that although Jay wasn't the most loved guy; he really cared for his sister (I could tell when he talked about her sometimes). I never said anything to Katie (his sister) about Jay; but tried to be nicer to her and look out for her more. I did tell my friends that I felt terrible for Katie; and really wished Jay would wake up from his coma (I was never clear on what state he was really in. Some people said he was in an induced coma; some people said he had woken up; etc).
plove: I wouldn't call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: No. Just because you feel bad for someone does not mean you dislike/are disgusted by them.
tlove: It's the kind of love where one is emotionally invested and deeply attached to the other.
clove: It would be the kind of love that involved some sort of emotional investment; which would allow for one to care deeply about the other person one is feeling compassionate towards.
slove: A love where one is emotionally invested in the other person.

writepity: My friend was struggling with a lot of self-worth issues as result of some bad dating experiences. She had tried dating a few different guys; but each one wasn't interested in being in an official relationship; and just wanted to hang around when they were interested; and then would be scared off when she ever approached the subject of being together. I pitied her because she really didn't need to put herself through the situations she was putting herself in; but kept repeating the same process and making the same mistakes. I told her that she needed to find a different type of guy than she was looking at for the past couple ones; because otherwise she was just going to keep getting disappointed; and I wanted her to just relax and try to find someone she didn't feel the need to be fake for; and just be herself around. I pitied her that she wasn't doing that for herself.
writetende: My boyfriend was suffering from extreme exhaustion; to the point where he couldn't function and was shaking and needed to rest. He needed me to get him dinner and help him rest for the remainder of the day. I felt tenderness for him due to his need for me to help him function the rest of the day; because I knew if I weren't there he probably wouldn't have fed himself that night; and my role as a caregiver brought out those feelings of tenderness toward someone who was relying on me. I told him he shouldn't get out of bed; that he needed to sleep and that I was there to take care of him and get him what he needed; and he didn't need to worry about anything else.
writecomp: I felt compassion for my grandma when she was struggling to walk. My grandma has a bad knee due to an old injury and arthritis; and if she walks on it too much it gets very painful for her and she tries to just get through it; but my whole family can tell when its really bothering her. We've gone on many walks where we've made frequent stops to let my grandma rest her knee; because she insists on going on walks despite the pain. Myself and my family all feel a great deal of compassion for my Grandma; and want to take care of her and ensure that she isn't pushing herself too hard; even though she is determined not to let it stop her.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my sister when she was dealing with problems with peers at work. My sister and myself have always been a bit different then our peers due to the way our parents raised us; and so we've both had difficulties fitting in and getting along with peers. She often gets frustrated dealing with peers because they tend to form cliques and exclude her; which is something that also happened to me on occasion. I feel sympathy for her because I know its difficult sometimes dealing with these people who think just because she's not a typical teenage girl she doesn't belong in their group; and I try to tell her that it's more important to find people that will love you for who you are than try to be friends with people who won't; and that they aren't worth her time; because that's something that I've found in my experience.
writeempat: My friend was having family and money problems; and was worried she would have to take out loans in order to pay for college since her divorced parents weren't agreeing on who was going to pay. She's my best friend and her divorced parents have been arguing since I've known her; especially about money; because her mom is in debt and her dad thinks his child support has been enough over the years; and so there's always been a money struggle between the two. Once she went to college it became more difficult with tuition checks. My parents are married and we've never really struggled with money problems; so although I couldn't directly relate I could imagine the precarious situation she was in and felt really bad about it and wished I could help or give advice. For the most part all I could do was be a shoulder to cry on; but I tried to help her out the best I could.
plove: I wouldn't call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I wouldn't say it is akin to contempt; because I think contempt is too strong a word for comparison; but I do think that pity isn't necessarily a positive emotion; although it elicits a response.
tlove: Its a kind of love where you give more than the other person; because the other person is unable to do so at that time; and needs your help as a loved one.
clove: Compassion is a type of general love for humanity; where you see anyone struggling and your heart goes out to them.
slove: I wouldn't call sympathy a kind of love; I would say its a by product of compassion; which is a general love of humanity.
elove: I would call empathy a type of love; as its part of being compassionate towards others; but more specific.

writepity: In class; we did an activity where almost everyone; including me; got a full half percent of extra credit added to our final grade for the semester. However; one of my friends int hat class; who was doing the worst out of all of us; did not get the extra credit even though she needed it the most. I pitied her.
writetende: My older brother slipped and fell down the stairs. I felt a tenderness towards him; aske dhim if he was ok; and offered to help him get up or get him ice. he wasn't badly hurt; he was just a little surprised and a little bruised. I remember wanting to take care of him to make sure he was ok. He seemed fine though and got up so there wasn't really anything I could do.
writecomp: I saw a commercial on children in africa who were hungry; poor; had little clothing on; were caked in dirt; and had a sad expression on their face. There were sitting in the streets all by themselves. The commercial was asking for people to donate money to an organization that would help these children in Africa. I was very moved by these images and felt compassion towards those children in Africa who looked miserable and hungry. I thought about what their lives must be like; living in such extreme poverty; most likely without an opportunity for education and I felt as if I wanted to adopt themself and take care of them. It made me realize how priveliged I was.
writesymp: I remember talking to a student here who's house burned down right before classes started. She and all her housemates had to find a last minute living situation and move out. Some of their things had been ruined. I have never experienced what it is like to have my house set on fire by I can imagine it must have felt scary; frustrating; stressful and a sense of loss.
writeempat: My friend started complaining about how bad a paper was written; unaware that the editor was in the room. She then realized the editor of the paper was in teh room and listening to her so she felt so embarrassed; sorry; and awkward for talking bad about it that she left the room. I understand what it feels like to say something bad; not realizing the person is there and listening. The feeling of shame; guilt; and embarrassment was pretty overwhelming for me too so I could empathize with what she felt. I told my friend that this happens to all of us which is why I have become more conscious and aware of when I talk negatively about something I don't like because I don't want to end up hurting anyone.
pcontempt: No

writepity: I felt pity on the handicapped man who worked at my elementry school. Whenever I saw him moving around in his wheelchair cleaning lunch tables I felt pity for him because it wasn't his fault that he was handicapped. Why did he has to have such a misriable life just becasue of something he was born with. I remember one day asking him about his condition. At the time; I didn't undertand that someone could be born with a physical disorder and have to live their whole life with it. I had never seen such a n old man (about 40) that had spent his whole life in a wheelchair. The main reason I think I felt pity rather than sympathy was the man couldn't do anything to change his situation where as with a sympathy the person usually is somewhat to blame. If not that person than someone else is to blame. I remember not doing anything to help the older man; in retrospect; I wish I would have tried to help. Although I knew that trying to help in anyway was futile. What was a little boy going to do to help a handicapped old man?
writetende: The greateest feeling of tenderness I have had is while taking care of a fallen baby cardinal in my backyard. I remember walking outside on a chilly fall day and looking up into the large elm tree in my yard to see a small nest near  the peak. After looking around the base of the tree a bit I found a baby bird that seemed to be laying on the ground trying to yell out. It must have fallen the nest almost excatly above it. How had it survived? I feel hurt inside for what that baby bird was going through; just sitting there on the ground in pain and suffering. I wanted to help so I tried to lift it up with my hands as delicately as I could. The cardinal was so soft and tiny I felt as if I would break it. I saw that it's leg was out of place so I took it inside and had my mom try and treat it. She said that it couldn't be saved and that we should put it back outside. I went to school and she did just that.
writecomp: Compassion is when I accidently tripped my brother while we were walking in a store. He feel and hit his knee on the edge of a table and had to go to the emergency room. I think I felt compasion over other types of feelings because I had something to do with another person being hurt. I remember feeling like it was all my fault. Well; it kinda was. I told him I was very sorry and that it was an accident; however atleast from my end that didn't end the terrible feeling I had inside. He learned to forgive me; after all it was only something small. It's just that he is my younger brother; I feel protective over him; so nothing makes me feel worse than when I cause him pain.
writesymp: When my brother was taking the ACT this past year; it was the best example of sympathy I can think of. I saw that because standardized test taking always came so easy for me to do; however my brother found it every difficult. On top of that; my parents expected my brother to live up the results I had when he just couldn't do that. He would come home from the test telling me how hard it was and how he was so stupid. I just felt horrible for him because I knew that indirectly I was putting this pressure on him by how well I had down a few years earlier. It wasn't his fault; he just couldn't help that he wasn't very good at test taking.
writeempat: Last week my girlfriend was stressing out over a paper for her food and nutrition class. I felt empathy in this situation because I have been in her position many times; freaking out about an exam. Nothing I felt I could do could make her worry any less. I would try and comfort her by telling that everything would be alright; she would get through this and that next week would be better. As much as I could try and comfort her; I really couldn't do anything because in this situation; freaking out the paper is her own doing. She didn't start writing far enough in advance; so now she was running out of time. I felt almost helpless in this situation. I want to make her feel better but nothing I was doing was working. Eventualy she got through the paper and turned it in and my empathy for the situation passed. This would be a bigger deal if it didn't happen all the time. I feel as if empathy is something that most people feel for someone everyday.
plove: Pity isn't a type of love to me. Pity is something that you take on someone or something that isn't your fault and you can't change.
pcontempt: I don't think that is true. I wasn't comptemt when I felt pity.
tlove: Tenderness is the kind of love that is your parent picking you up after you hurt yourself and singing to you to make you feel better.
clove: Compassion would be the love similar to tenderness. You have fallen and someone picks you back up; and tells you that you will be ok
slove: I would not call sympathy a type of love but rather a type of friendship. Your are sympathic to your friends; you are compassionate towards your love.
elove: Empathy is the kind of love that has you comforting a person who just messed up something in their life. There is really nothing you can do or say to make them feel better; just giving empathy will help.

writepity: I felt pity for my neighbor when she didn't get into U of M. She got into some other great schools but I felt pity for her when she didn't get into the school of her dreams; U of M. There is nothing I could but I ultimately felt sorry for her because I knew how badly she wanted to go to school here in Ann Arbor. I  care for her so I reallty just felt sorry for what happened.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my brother when recently he and his former best friend got into a fight. I still feel tenderness for my brother because it has been 2 months and they still have not been talking. My brother is only 13 so for him to be going through this; my heart aches for him. I feel sorry for my brother and just want to give hima big hug right now. If you knew the circumstances you would understand why I feel so sorry that they aren't talking. I have told my brother that if he ever wants to talk that he can call me. When I have seen him since they stopped talking; I have given my brother plenty of hugs and told him I was there for him. I feel tenderness for him because he is still so little and really such a good kid who shouldn't be going through what he is. I still want to think of him as my innocent; sweet little baby brother so this feeling of tenderness makes sense to me. I can't  hide him from real world experiences but I just feel sorry for him.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards my mother when she was offered a job through her business that she really wanted. She was compassionate about this and therefore I felt compassion for her. I was compassionate for her because it was a job she really wanted (she is an interior designer); therefore i felt her excitement as well. I became compassionate towards her because I am so proud of her and happy for her. I respect her so much and therefore took my emotions as being compassionate towards her. I love her and I want what is best for her.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my best friend when her dog passed away. I felt sympathetic for her because I could tell the passing of her dog was making her really sad. She wasn't crying but you could tell that she felt upset. I felt sorry for her because I wouldn't want to go through the same situation. I gave her a big hug and told her I was there to listen if she needed to talk.
writeempat: I felt empathetic towards someone just recently. I've happened to become really close with this girl across the hall from me in my dorm. She has been struggling with her chem class and has been having a hard time in the class. Just recently she was considering dropping the class and receving a W on her transcript. Unfortunately for the major she wants to pursue she would have to take chem again. I immediately felt empathy for her when I saw her struggle with the decision to either stay in the class and bring up her grade or drop the class; receive a W on her transcript; and have to take the class again. I could see the stress in her eyes and how it was taking a toll on her. The deadline is tomorrow and the entire past week she has been constantly thinking about whether to stay in the class or drop. I don't want her to continue to be stressed because I ultimately want her to make the decision that is best for her. I've been a good listener the last couple days when she questions what she should do; weighing the pros and cons. I don't feel sorry for her; but I wish this decision were easier for her to make.
plove: I do not think pity is a kind of love.
pcontempt: I have no idea what this means in all honesty.
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love because it it showing your support for someone and that you care for them and their wellbeing. Tenderness is acting loving towards someone but not in the romantic way.
clove: I would call compassion love because it is a form of expressing your excitement and giddyness and even love of someone or something.
slove: I offered my sympathy of form of love through the support that I gave to my friend. I told her I would be there for her if she needed anything or if she wanted to talk. This is a form of love because I was showing her how much I care for her and how important she is to me and that I don't want to see her upset because it makes me sad.
efeltother: 1. I felt caring; if that makes any sense / 2.  / 3.
elove: I would call empathy love by means of support; guidance; kindness; and caring towards someone else.  Not the romantic side of love but the caring side; where you would help in any situation or be there for the person who was experiencing something.

writepity: It was during the week and my friends and I were studying together at Shapiro library. One of my friends; Annes; told me that she left her car around the packard st. and she wanted to park the car nearby the library so that she doesn't have to walk or take bus all the way back to the packard st. from Shapiro library. It was already dark outside so I said that I would willingly go with her. We all were feeling sort of hungry at that time; and Annes said that she would buy everyone fries from Frita Batidos on her way coming back from packard st. So Annes and I went out to get her car and we drove to Frita Batidos to get fries for everyone. When we got to the main st.; a homeless person approached to us and begged for fifty cents. He was wearing really old; dirty clothes; and his voice was almost gone. He seemed to be old; maybe around his 60s. I felt sorry for him because the fact that he's old and still lonely; begging for changes; means that he has no family; no house; and no children. I was first scared to see a stranger saying something to me and Annes; but then in a few seconds; I felt bad about his situation.
writetende: I don't think I normally feel tenderness in terms of my own definition of tenderness. Tenderness reminds me of a mom breastfeeding a baby. One of my mom's colleague had a newborn baby and when I visited her house to see them; she breastfed the baby. When the mom looked at the baby when she was breastfeeding; she was looking the baby with very soft; loving eyes; and I think it was tenderness.
writesymp: There was a screening about a North Korean refugee from one of the clubs that I joined. The screening showed how people are helping each other to rescue a single North Korean from the repression. It showed a long route/journey of a refugee; escaping from North Korea to a better environment and freedom. The harsh environments of their journey made me think that I would not be able to do it if I were in that situation and the refugees struggled so much to obtain freedom that I didn't even really think of enjoying.
plove: That kind of love would be the love from the Bible where the Bible says love your neighbors.
pcontempt: It can be; because a person who might be feeling pity; might also feel a bit of superiority toward a person; who is pitied.
tlove: Motherly love
slove: I would call sympathy a love but I'm not sure what words I should use

writepity: I was teaching in collaboration with this old professor; and although I was the young inexperienced one; he was extremely unprofessional and seemed unable to take care of himself. He would send me emails asking me to cover for some classes; explaining that his mother and father were in a hospital and all sort of personal things that had nothing to do with work. He was desperate to talk to someone and he wanted people to feel for him so badly that I completely lost any respect that I had for him. This is what I would call pity. I feel sad that he is such a weak and weird person; but I have lost any respect for him and kept a big distance with him because there was nothing I could do for him.
writetende: I feel tenderness towards my ex-girlfriend. We had an extremely beautiful story; and I am extremely sad that things did not work out. We left each other with a lot of respect and tenderness; probably we were both still in love with each other; but both knew that this was not meant to be and that moving on was the best for both of us. So I felt incredibly sad; and I know she felt the same. And even now; that I am still in love with her; but that I am slowly letting this feeling go away; all I have left is an infinite amount of tenderness for her. It is not love; even if it implies love. It is love without hope for a future; it is acknowledgement that you believe that a person is a beautiful and great person; without any will to build anything out of this feeling. I would call tenderness uninterested.
writecomp: My little sister is a medical student in her fourth year; and she is now so swamped with work that she gets litterally depressed. Even if she had doubts for the main reason that this is so difficult; she has told me many times how much she loves what she does and that this is really meant for her. So whenever she talks to me about it and she looks so tired and depressed and sad; I can't help but feel for her. I have been through tough years of studies as well; but really love what I do now; so the situation is kinda similar; even if my studies were probably not that hard. Anyway; I would call this emotion that I get whenever she talks to me about that compassion; because I know exactly what she is going through; so I feel for her; but I also know that this is for a great reason; and that she is strong enough to handle this.
