So somehow; this is different from pity where I would really feel I have to do something for her and maybe lose some respect for her. Here; I just acknowledge what she is going through; and of course I feel sad; but I have the greatest respect for her ability to going through this.  /  / I think compassion is extremely close to empathy; now that I think about it. /  / So whenever I talk with her; I do not say much; I just try to make her laugh and to show I am here for her. I remind her that this will end eventually and that this is a good thing in the end; And that's it; it does not bother me too much because I know she's going to be allright;
writesymp: Sympathy is a feeling that you get towards someone who you are pretty distant with; but feel close for just a brief moment. As an example; I am teaching to a class of students; so our professional relationship imposes some distance. However; I cannot help feeling sympathy for some of the students when they help me out. As an example; I have this funny student; who really likes my lectures; and wants to help out. So everytime I ask a question to the class and noone answers; after 10 seconds he just goes kamikaze; raises his hands and tries any answer; as stupid as can be. And this really helps be because I can use his answer to keep on being interactive with the students.  /  / So we have of course a distant teacher-student relationship; but I definitely feel sympathy for him.
writeempat: Empathy is this feeling when you know exactly what someone is going through. It can happen for people you are close to or not at all. It is just this deep feeling "I know exactly what he/she is going through". /  / I experienced empathy for my little sister; as I explained in the "compassion" part. Though I think compassion is a kind of empathy; but that empathy can alsop include being happy for soneone.
plove: Pity happens when you lost respect for someone; so it has nothing to do with any kind of love.
tlove: Tenderness is what is left when love has gone away.
clove: Compassion is not a kind of love to me. It is an acknowledgement of someone's sad situation; when the person happens to be someone you love.
slove: Sympathy is loving something about someone who is for some reason distant.

writepity: I don't think I've ever really felt this emotion either; in most cases I don't care about other people's problems enough to even concern myself with them and if I did feel some sort of emotion it would be disgust or disdain rather than pity.
writetende: This is another emotion I don't feel that I've felt for another person; again because I just never been close enough to other people to warrant this emotion.
writecomp: I don't feel that I've ever felt compassion for another person; I've just never been close enough to other people to feel this strong strong an emotion for anybody.
writesymp: Last year I was locked-up in Wayne County jail and one of my fellow inmates suffered from seizures on a regular basisand wasn't receving the medical assistance from the guards thsat I felt he should be receiving. I felt concern and sadness for the inamtes helth issues and anger at the guards for not doing what I felt they should do in light of his health issues. I wanted to file a complaint against the guards for their inaction; I ended up makig many vocal complaints that they should take him to the hospital but never filed a formal complaint.
plove: I don't think pity is a kind of love.
pcontempt: Yes. Pity is an emotion you feel in situations where someone allows themselves to be treated badly; not situations where neagative consequencesoccur that are outside of the persons hands. It is in essence a negative emotion that shows you think the person is sad and/or unworthy.
tlove: In some situations tenderness could be a kind of love; those situations would be situations where one person felt the need to protect another such as a parent with a child or the caregiver of a sick person.
clove: I love to listen to music. / Her gentle soul made me love her. / Only fools fall in love. /  / I wouldn't call compassion a kind of love.
slove: Love is a many splendid thing. / I love the Fall season. /  / I wouldn't call sympathy a kind of love.

writepity: I feel pity towards the homeless people I see on the street. I feel sorry for them but not sorry enough to do anything about it. I feel bad that they do not have a home; food; clothes; etc but I do not feel driven to give them money and often times ignore them.  Occasionally; I feel disgusted by what they are doing and I figure there are better ways to find support for yourself than for begging for money by people on the street. Since these people are complete strangers; it is easy to feel pity towards them and look down upon them.
writetende: Feelings of tenderness are something I felt when my friend was going through a rough time with family issues. I could not even begin to relate to her family issues or understand the complexity of them. My friend was visibly upset and her family issues were taking over and getting in the way of her school and social life. I remember feeling so sad for her and feeling like I should care for her but unsure of how to relate to her feelings or exactly what to say to her to make her feel better. Instead; I stayed over late at night and watched movies with her to try and get her mind off of the situation and try and be supportive of her. I also did little things to cheer her up from making her tea to texting her more often to make sure she was ok.
writecomp: A time when I felt compassion toward someone was when I was working with them to help them to navigate an unfortunate situation. Specifically; this occurred when I was on a service trip working with a family to help re-build their house. I remember feeling sad to hear about their unforuntate situation but we were there to help make their situation better not to feel sorry for them. I felt compassion as we were working to build their house and making it a better place for them to live and to help improve their situation. By working alongside the family; we were able to get to know them beyond their unfortunate circumstance and get to know them as people. I think that component of the service made me feel more compassionate toward them than if they had not been working with us. This act of compassion was felt because I was DOING something to help improve someone's unfortunate conditions instead of just feeling badly about it.
writesymp: I felt sympathy when my brother was going through inense medical procedures. I felt for him but I could never understand his pain or what he was going through. I supported him and was there for him in any way that I could be. I tried to ask him questions to try and understand the situation better. Often; I did feel sorry for him; but I tried to hid those emotions by offering support and positivity. I badly wanted to understand what he was going through and better support him but I could not which is what made me feel sympathetic.
writeempat: Empathy is a form of sympathy that I felt when she told me that her mom was going through the same medical issues that my brother was going through. I empathesized with her becuase I understood what she was going through and could relate to her experiences. I wanted to support her in any way that I could and I know that by being able to offer her support from my experiences; I was able to help her through that situation. Feeling empathy felt different to me than sympathy because I could understand and relate to what the person was going through and I could better understand the situation.
plove: I would not call pity love;
pcontempt: I'm not sure what hte meaning is behind this saying--I've never heard of it.
tlove: Tenderness is a deep love that gets down to raw emotions
clove: I would call compassion a kind of love. I think it would be considered a selfless love; becuase an act of compassion you are doing with little expectation of a tangible reutrn.
slove: It is a kind of love; but I'm not sure how do classify it.
elove: I think that empathy is a kind of love; but I am unsure of how to classify it.

writepity: I saw a man on the street asking for money to eat. I felt very sad for him and thought how lucky I was to be in a great state of living. I wanted to give him money but my parents said no. I did not say anything to him.
writetende: I felt tenderness toward my girlfriend when she was telling me about family problems. I felt that I could give her the love and support she was not receiving from her family. I wanted to get her to explain everything that led her to that conclusion and did. I told her that I would always be there for her and that she could find love and comfort in me if she did not find it there.
writecomp: I remember when my sister did not make the basketball team. I felt very sad for her and I understood how she felt because I had also not made the basketball team one year. I felt the disappointment that she was undertaking and the sadness and anger that welled up in her. I wanted to tell her that it would be alright and that there were always other things to do; including training harder for next year. I stood her up and took her to go play outside with some friends; I told her there was no point in being sad with what had transpired because she could not change it.
writesymp: I remember when I saw someone who was depressed about their weight and was talking to me about it. I felt very sad and understanding because I had gone through weight problems; depression; and the social stigma that comes along with each. I wanted to show them that they could change their lives. I told them to come workout with me and I made them work hard to motivate themselves to change to who they wanted to be.
writeempat: I am clearly remembering a time when my childhood friend Paul graduated from high school with honors. All of our family and friends were there to celebrate his achievement. He stood with his graduation gown and cap with a special golden tassle to identify his honors. I felt very happy and understanding. I was able to go back into my memory; to when this happened to me the year prior and all the emotions of that moment came rushing back. I felt happiness for my success; elatedness for the completion of this portion of education; and nervousness or excitedness for the things to come. I was able to feel these things for Paul which made me empathetic toward him. I wanted to congratulate him; and I did. I told him that it was an awesome achievement to complete high school the way he did and that he was going to love being able to move into the next stage of his life.
plove: Pity is not a type of love.
pcontempt: No; I think pity has more of a gentle connotation than contempt.
tlove: Tenderness would be a fomr of love in which you display a receptive air to someone to comfort and come to you with anything. That you will be there for someone in their hardest moments.
clove: It is a a kind of love that shows understanding and warmth to a person in tough times.
slove: I do not think sympathy is a type of love.
elove: Empathy is the type of love in understanding the situation of someone else and feeling for that person. I do not think the word empathy is necessarily tied to a connotation. You are happy when someone else is happy and feel bad for them when something goes bad.

writepity: I felt pity toward my friend when she got knee surgery and couldn't play tennis for one season. I felt bad because the situation was pretty much out of her control; and she couldn't do something that she loved. However; she would be healthy again soon so I wasn't too worried about how it would affect her in the future. It must have been boring to sit out; and she must have felt restless; but it wasn't the end of the world.
writetende: My brother is in the process of recovering from drug addiction. I feel a lot of tenderness towards him right now because he's trying his best to recover; but the process is slow. I have no idea what it is like to go through something like that; but I sincerely want him to get better and I believe he will. He's also very vulnerable right now to temptation; which I can understand. However; although some people are predisposed to addiction; I felt that he could have helped himself out of this a little earlier; rather than let his life spiral out of control before doing something about the situation. Now that some time has passed and he shows major signs of improvement; I feel tenderness and love for him because I can see how hard he is trying.
writecomp: My friend's house recently burned down. Luckily; only the father and their 5 dogs were in the house and he was able to get all of their pets out. He was also able to save some jewelry and some artwork; but everything else was gone. When I heard about this; I couldn't imagine what it must have been like to watch your own house burn down; knowing there was nothing you could do to stop it. My friend; who is in college; must have felt awful knowing his childhood home was gone. And with five dogs; I don't know where his family is going to go now.
writesymp: I felt sympathy when my brother didn't get accepted to Stanford; his first choice college. It was far from the end of the world; as he got into other amazing schools (Duke; UPenn; Northwestern; Johns Hopkins; U of M; you see what I mean). However; it was one of the first times he'd been rejected academically; so I felt bad that he had to take that blow. It was also the first school he got a letter from; so I didn't know what that would mean for getting into other schools. I know what it is like to fail at something in school; so I could kind of relate; but I knew he would be just fine after the initial sadness wore off.
writeempat: My best friend and I were lying in the same bed. I think we were about 13 years old and we've been best friends since we were three. I know her better than anyone else and I understand her emotions sometimes better than I understand my own. She has always been an insecure person; and that night I finally understood why as she told me about how her mom had made her go to a clinic for overweight children when she was in elementary school. I think if you're a girl especially; you struggle with body image for your entire life; so I could completely understand how that must have hurt her and made her doubt herself. Your mother is supposed to love you unconditionally; no matter what you look like or even act like. I told her that it didn't make me see her any differently; and I remember that made her cry. From that moment on; I felt like it was my job to help her feel more secure with her appearance.
plove: I do not think pity is a kind of love at all. I think it has a negative connotation that does not connect you emotionally to the other person at all.
pcontempt: In my situation; no; but I do think this could be true in some situations. I think people generally feel pity for those who they view as helpless in comparison to them.
tlove: Tenderness is definitely a kind of love because it means you sincerely want the situation to improve and to see that person do better.
clove: I don't really love the people whose house burned down; but  I do think compassion is usually a kind of love. It's the kind that makes you want to understand the other person's situation so you can help them.
slove: I love my brother; but I don't think my sympathy for him was an act of love.
elove: I think empathy is the kind of love that makes you feel as close to how a person was feeling in the situation as possible. It makes you understand what they went through on a deeper level because you have a personal connection to the person; the events; or both.

writepity: Unfortunately the feeling of pity is slightly elitist in my opinion. I mostly feel pity towards the people who are less attractive; less physically fit and less intelligent. I will never say it to them directly but with every feeling of pity I get comes with a slight feeling that I am better than them in a certain way. However; I do hope for them to have a better attribute somewhere else. For instance; if I am walking on campus and see a stereotypical nerd rushing to class and slipping on the Ice; I will walk up to them to help them up. However in doing this "generous act" I tend to feel like I am his savior rushing in to rescue him from his life. Almost like a god complex. With this also comes me thinking that he will remember me as the cool kid who acknowledged his existence. The side is that I will also wish that he is going to an exam and will ace it. I have a desire to see him succeed in another facet of his life so I know that he will be happy somehow.
writetende: My blunt and slightly sexist opinion of this emotion is that tenderness is a feeling reserved for women or a man taking care of his significant other. The only times can say I have felt tenderness for someone is when my significant other fell asleep in my arms after a long; hard day. For a male like myself; I feel tenderness when the well-being of my girlfriend is completely dependent on me. It not that I don't think she is fine on her own but rather that she is but I want to help ease the burden.
writecomp: When I experience a scene in public where a person is being judged or discriminated against I feel compassion towards the person. When I feel compassion it is a mixture of pity for the person being harmed and anger towards the injustice. Like in the word itself; I put much of my passion towards the situation. It cause my heart to pump and my blood pressure to raise as I personally feel hurt watching the other individual in pain. I think and do stand up for the person as much as I can. This is one of the few feelings I have that cause me to loose my temper and cause my thinking to become irrational.
writeempat: Recently; one of my new college friends had a best friend die in a complete accident. I also had my best friend die from something out of everyone's control. I could empathize with him. One thing that made the situation stand out is that for both of us; the best friend was a female. And with us both being male; we always felt like it was partially our job to protect them from the cruelty of the world. Empathy to me means the ability to understand on every level about the situation going on. When we talked I think we both felt a sort of comfort to go along with the pain of remembrance and loss. When I felt empathy it caused me to talk with him and reach comfort with the passing. It also helped with understanding a loss that felt unfair to us in life.
pfeltother: 1. I felt that I was better than the victim / 2.  / 3.
plove: I do not believe it is a form of love but rather a way to remove guilt from someone.
pcontempt: I am inclined to agree although contempt is a little stronger of a word than I would use. It is not love nor contempt you feel; but a way of compensating for your own selfish thoughts.
tfeltother: 1. A melancholy calmness / 2. Almost Peaceful / 3. Slightly romantic
tlove: This is the most romantic type of love of the 5 emotions that I believe is the what a man can only feel towards an important woman in his life.
clove: Brotherly love for the victim but a hatred towards the reason for the victim being victimized.
elove: Brotherly love of two people who connect on an entirely new level

writetende: I recall feeling tenderness toward a woman I was dating. She had lost her mother to pancreatic cancer two years before we met. I felt I could help her through the grief  from sharing my experience with my own father's passing from pancreatic cancer.  The two moments I felt tenderness were 1) watching her gaze at a picture of her mom that was her iPhone desktop picture; and 2) 6 weeks later; I felt comfortable enough with her to suggest to her that when she find's the right way to deal with the loss of her mother; it won't hold her back or feel bad.   /  / Recalling those moments of tenderness opens the same physical and emotional sensations that I felt then and recalling those moments opens the memories of other tender moments and feeling of tenderness. The majority of tenderness feelings seem to be associated with a physical-emotional touch of intimacy with women. However; I understand tenderness is not a sexual energy.  /  / The sensation of tenderness feels or is perceived as a softening and relaxation in the mind associated with a sinking feeling of the heart organ itself. Tenderness may differ from empathy given the associated physical feeling and one's own organ sensations that stimulate one to relax the requirements or expectations of another in order to allow the other person to move forward or manage their situation without critique.
writecomp: Compassion is felt when the passions of two or more people or combination of people and animals  join their feelings together or attach their feelings and passion to one they feel compassion for.  /  / For example; I felt compassion when a family member; friend; or my pet could no longer share in an activity we enjoyed together; such as taking the dog for a walk with my mother; the loss of a friends job; or the inability of my dog to continue our long runs together.  /  / Compassionately; we find alternative tasks to enjoy together; that are tasks that we enjoy separately.  / For example; my mother's early Alzheimer's led to her inability to go on long walks; so I started a yoga program with her to join our interests.  /  / Compassion seems to not invoke any visceral response or sensation in the brain nor the heart. It's a confidence that we'll work something out and seems to originate from just the general sense of being.
writesymp: Sympathy and empathy and compassion have been difficult concepts for me to differentiate in the past. I had include dthem as all being a general understanding of another's loss. However; with maturity; more relations; more experience and being more attentive to emotions for learning how to speak foreign languages to native speakers; as well as keying in on another's emotional needs in a relation and even my own physical sensations when experiencing different emotions. /  /  / I don't feel sympathy when a friends family member passes away. I feel empathy; because I understand and share the same experience from my youth.  /  / I feel sympathy when I mentally know someone is going to have difficulty moving forward having experienced a loss; i.e. loved one; job; pet. Sympahty invokes a response to acknowledge the other's loss; but without dutiful action to alleviate their loss. Compared to empathy; sympathy is a fleeting feeling as we all deal with loss and have to make our way forward. Empathy lasts longer and invokes a sense of duty or need to help.  /  / Moments of sympathy are experienced when one suffers from an illness they contracted or a disease their suffering from due to no fault of their own.
writeempat: I empathize with others when I can feel and share an understanding of their loss; as well as hope to or actually do something to alleviate their sense of loss.  /  / For example; I empathize with my mother who is suffering elder abuse by our sister. Our mother has been emotinally abusive; isolated her; exploited her finances; and delayed medical care to our mother.
tlove: Tenderness is tangential to love. One can experience tenderness without love or knowing the other person. Although my experiences are associated with love and attraction. For example; I automatically feel tenderness toward an infant regardless if their a member of the family; a friend's baby or at the nursery. So tenderness includes some perception of vulnerability; yet I give adults their due respect by believing they are mostly in control of their situation. So tenderness can have many contexts. Common denominators maybe vulnerability; an affection toward the other -non sexual or sexual; i.e. non sexual would be general concern; general caring or general reponsibility toward another human or animal.
clove: Those feelings of love; kindness and empathy are structured as follows:  / Empathy and kindness lead to or build toward love. Compassion is derived from love.
sfeltother: 1. loss of another / 2. hardship of another / 3. loss of control and regulation by one another
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love. It is an act or emotion of friendship and general love of all sentient beings.
elove: Empathy may be a love through identification and understanding of another's soul through their losses and hopes. Empathy invokes both a mindful sensation and a heartfelt (heart organ) response.

writepity: 1) I feel pity whenever I see a homophobic or racist or other such negative person on the news; online or in person. I cannot imagine being that narrow-minded and hurtful. /  / 2) I feel like they should educate themselves; just look at the world they live in and realize that their antiquated notions have no basis in reality. I end up getting extremely riled up and angry. /  / 3) What I want to do is immediately voice my opinions to combat theirs; for example downvote or report slurs on a messageboard online; join organizations like HRC; sign petitions to end this absurdity.
writetende: 1) I found some legal documents that had my mother's name on them and asked her what they were about. She took them away and asked me to forget about them; and then when I continued asking questions I got the sense that there was something she didn't want me to know about. I then asked my father about them and he explained a complex personal situation to me. They both then sat down and told me the whole story and the circumstances about that event in my mother's past; where she was misused by another man before she met my father. So this was something they had hoped never to mention again; and it was something that changed the way I saw my mother at the time; only because it was a traumatic experience I had no idea she had been through it; and also because she felt the need to hide it from me. /  / 2) I felt hurt; betrayed; angry; horrified; confused and sick. I couldn't believe that I had only found out by accident and that they had concealed this from me and lied to me when I used to ask them questions about their lives. Then the very incident that she had been through seemed to become the most important and listening to her emotionally explain it to me made me feel nothing other than tenderness for her. She is in her 60s but I felt like I needed to comfort her; reassure her that of course I wouldn't think any less of her for a mistake that she did not make knowingly and for the hurt that was caused not by; but to her. /  / 3) What I wanted to do was never forgive them for hiding the information from me; for a number of reasons. What actually happened was a lot of crying and shouting on everyone's parts. In the end I tried to hug her but she didn't want to be touched; and although that hurt me as a child; I understood why.
writecomp: 1) When I was in India I would see families of homeless people living on the street; begging at the stop-lights; cooking food on paraffin stoves in the open; etc. /  / 2) Every time I saw these things I'd think about how little I could help; since I was very young at the time. I'd wonder how I would feel in their place and knew that I probably wouldn't have the strength they had. Then I would immediately feel grateful for all the things in my life I took for granted. /  / 3) What I wanted to do was get out there and help them; but I didn't know where to begin. In the end I would just discuss it with my parents and they'd tell me that they would continue to donate to charity and that as I grew older there would be more opportunities for me to actually help them myself.
writesymp: 1) This incident occurred last week; when I found my roommate crying about an exam grade. The subject was Organic Chemistry Part 1; a course I had previously taken and struggled with in much the same way; and so I instantly knew what she was going through without her having to explain it to me. Her situation was that her grade was so bad that nothing she could do for the rest of the semester would salvage it; she felt she might end up with a failing grade. She only needs this course as a prerequisite and has no actual interest in the subject; the same reasoning process I had used when I took it. /  / 2) What I felt was an instant need to get her to understand that her anxiety was normal and that this course is hard on everyone. I brought up my own experiences and remembered and recounted feeling like I wouldn't be able to do well; get a terrible grade on my transcript; get a low GPA; which would therefore get me fewer recommendations; fewer successful applications to summer programs; internships and jobs; which would in turn affect my income. In addition to all these concerns; I felt terrible for the issue that she brought up that I hadn't encountered yet: that she would have to drop the course and take it again; thereby prolonging her stay at the UM. She is already gearing up for her 5th year as a senior and the expense is taking a toll on her family that has already put 3 children through university. /  / 3) What I wanted to do was get her to stop feeling so hopeless. She mentioned that she had been crying for 4 hours before I came home; which made me extremely worried because when that has happened to me in the past; I have given myself migraines and a fever that take a few days to recede; and that would just compound her problems. What I said; was basically an account of my similar struggle through this course and my freak-outs at the same points in time. I told her what ended up working for me; because I actually did end up finishing the course with a good grade despite having done less than well on the midterms. I then asked her to walk me through her decision making process in terms of dropping it; because I felt that that might hurt her since one of her main concerns was delaying her graduation date. I then helped her reason through all the options and provided as many arguments for and against each one as I could think of; while letting her know that I would support her decision no matter what it was. I have also been helping her with her material throughout and I reminded her that she could come to me for more help with HW; etc any time.
plove: I wouldn't call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I think for this situation that it was true of the pity I felt. But I can understand how that may not always be the case.
tlove: It would be the kind of love you reserve for fragile things to be cared for gently.
clove: The kind of love human beings are capable of because even if we haven't shared an experience; we are able to imagine what it would feel like.
slove: The love born of the pain of shared experience.

writepity: My friend was feeling very sick and throwing up. I didn't like to see her like that because she was very vulnerable. I couldn't do anything about it; but hope that she felt better. I knew that I just had to be there for her and make sure that she was okay.
writetende: My friend helped organize a diversity conference. During a breakout session; she was "called out" for trying to shift the conversation from race to class. She said she walked out and was crying. I wasn't there; but as she was telling the story I could tell that she was really hurt by it. She was part of organizing it and someone should have respected her. There were other administrators too and it was disappointing that they didn't say anything.
writecomp: My friend got in a car crash. I don't remember the exact details; but her engine stopped working and her car was pretty damaged. At first when I heard I couldn't believe it because I think it was the second one of my friends that got in a car crash in the recent months. I was concerned about her health; but luckily no one was hurt. I knew that this stuff happens sometimes and sometimes it's about luck: wrong place; wrong time; so I knew she wasn't to blame. I asked her if she was ok and what's going to happen next because she was car-less for a few months or weeks. She said she was going to get a new engine; and she would have to take the bus to school everyday.
writesymp: My friend didn't do well on an exam and she was pretty torn up about it. I could relate because I have been in the same place. Especially when you know or feel that everybody else did better. I tried to comfort her; and I told her it happens and the important part is to do better next time. That she wasn't the only one.
plove: It is a love where you care about them; but it's not as emotional because you don't relate as much. You just feel bad.
pcontempt: No
tlove: A warm love
clove: Compassion is a true love.
slove: A caring love

writepity: One of my very good friends spontaneously broke up with his girlfriend a couple months ago and since has been struggling with the decision. Some days he wants her back; some days he doesnt; but he just keeps stringing her along. He seems genuinely confused and upset about the whole situation and while I don't think his intentions in breaking up with his girlfriend were to be mean or to hurt her; he did hurt her and he was mean. I think he's just genuinely clueless and dumb when it comes to women and dating. So I pitied him because even though he was sad and upset; he had brought it upon himself and he had the power to make the situation better. I told him that he had been an asshole to his girlfriend and that if she took him back I would be surprised; but that I liked them together and hoped one day they could work it out. He always asks me for advice and I give it to him but I don't like to him about the fact that he made a mistake and wasn't a nice person. I was sad for him that what he did caused him so much pain and stress but at the same time understood that he deserved to feel how he was feeling because his ex girlfriend probably felt even worse.
writetende: A time that I felt tenderness was when I first met my knew baby cousin. He was so small and vulnerable and little and I felt soft and gentle and careful around him; like I had to be careful not to hurt him. I felt like he needed a lot of attention and love from everyone around him; including me. I held him a lot and have since babysat him a lot. He is now one year old.
writecomp: When my mom's father passed away when I was in 10th grade in high school I felt a lot of compassion for her and all of my other aunts and uncles; and my grandmother. I just felt like I needed to be there for them. I didn't so much as feel bad for them; even though I did; but I also was sad to; so I felt compassion and a need to just needed to show them my love and support.
writesymp: A time I felt sympathy for someone was last fall. My friend and I were at a Halloween party and he had been acting strange and distant all night so I asked if he wanted to talk. We did and he started telling me about how his parents were filing for bankruptcy soon. I had no idea this was going on in his life and I didn't know how to help or what to say. I felt so bad for him because his parent's finances are completely out of his control; but obviously this would have a great effect on his life. I kept trying to assure him that it would be okay but it's not like I actually knew that. I just assured him that I was there for him to talk whenever he needed. I felt like I wished I could have done something but the situation was out of my control and there was nothing I could do to make it better; which made me feel even worse. I also felt like I couldn't relate to his situation since my parents have never gone through financial troubles like bankruptcy. I sympathized that his parents had to go through this.
writeempat: What happened to make me feel empathetic was a situation between my sister and her boyfriend. My sister's boyfriend cheated on her with someone who he had said was just his friend. Later her boyfriend tried to explain and backtrack about the situation but then kept telling the other girl different things than he was telling my sister. My sister is good friends with her boyfriend's roommate; and the roommate sided with my sister; thinking that the boyfriend had been in the wrong. I empathized with my sister because I went through a similar situation. Someone that I was dating cheated on me with another girl that was supposedly just his friend; and I am also best friends with the guy I was dating's roommate; who sided with me and thought that I had been wronged. My sister and I went through almost exactly the same situation; which is why I felt bad for her and knew what she was going through; could relate to it; at the same time. When my sister was telling me about her situation I felt like I wished I could help her. I was feeling sad that the same thing had happened to both of us. I was thinking about how to tell her to leave her boyfriend and not take him back or let him  stay in her life when he had messed up so many times. I wanted to tell her to stop talking to him forever; but I told her to do what she felt was right for her because I didn't want to tell her what to do with her life.
plove: Not
pcontempt: I have no idea what this means.
tlove: Not
clove: true love
slove: Not
elove: Not

writepity: On the news; I saw reports on a famous athlete from South Africa (may have competed in Olympics?) who was accused of murdering his girlfriend. I felt pity for both families and for him. I felt this way because I had no control over the situation and that it was already over; that she was already dead and there was nothing anyone could do about it. I thought that it was so sad and unnecessary that she had to die. I forget the situation; but I feel like the problem could have been solved in a better way. After hearing bits of neighbors and a past girlfriend talking about him; I felt even worse for him because it all made it seem like he was guilty. I felt pity for him even though he committed a murder because he probably felt terrible about it now and wished so much he could do anything to undo it.
writetende: I felt tenderness when I played with my baby sister during her first months and year of her life. There's something about babies that make you feel good and tender inside. Her skin was so soft and her eyes so dark and clear. She was so innocent and cute; it felt like nothing could be wrong. Whenever I played with her; I was always careful to be gentle to not hurt her and to protect her from falling or playing with dangerous objects. She was so helpless; I felt that it was my job to help her. She could just be herself and make everyone smile and feel tenderness.
writecomp: A time when I felt compassion towards someone was for my mom when my sister was born. We are almost 17 years apart and she is my only sibling. For the months and weeks before her birth; I had kept it a secret from even my closest friends. I told everyone the week before she was due and I think I did this because I was a little embarrassed but also felt that it was extra stress I didn't need during junior year of high school. Even though my mom was very tired all the time; she still kept on doing chores and cooking for us every day. I didn't feel bad; even though now I do for thinking that way. After my sister was born though; I felt that my mom was so brave and strong for having her. I felt like I had to do everything I could to help her out. I became much more loving and kind to her; helping her taking care of the baby and cleaning and cooking. I felt that it was my job to be understanding towards my mom and to help her in any way I could; even if that meant sacrificing sleep or time with friends or school work. / +
writesymp: When the grandma of one of my friends from childhood passed away; I felt sympathy for her. I couldn't really relate to her because no one in my family that I am very close to has passed away in my life time. I knew she felt terrible because she loved her grandma so much and was very close to her. I knew her as well; and she used to babysit us when we were little. It happened so suddenly and so unexpectedly. I felt really sad just thinking about it. Even though we don't talk much anymore; we still see each other sometimes during school breaks; but the way I remember her feeling about her grandma makes me sympathetic towards her when she passed away. I can't even imagine how I would feel if one of my grandparents passed away; but I know it must be a terrible feeling.
writeempat: I felt empathetic towards my roommate who tried very hard this year to get an internship for the summer but still hasn't found one. I felt like that because I also have been having a really hard time finding one. I totally could understand her situation. She was upset; nervous; and  worried that she wouldn't be able to find work this summer; especially since she needs to pay for her own tuition. I was especially nervous because as a junior this year; it's my last summer to get an  internship before trying to find a real job after graduation; it's so important because I've never had an internship before. Although she is still a sophomore and has some time; I absolutely know the sense of urgency she's feeling. When I talked to her; we discussed other options like doing research over the summer; and I gave her some advice on that since I've worked in multiple labs before.
plove: a kind of love that recognizes what's right and what's wrong and is honest
pcontempt: Somewhat. It's easy to dislike someone for something they did (especially if it was bad) but also pity them because you would feel terrible in their situation.
tlove: comforting love
clove: unconditional love
slove: friendly love
elove: understanding love

writepity: When I walk down State Street in Ann Arbor; I tend to feel pity towards all of the homeless people begging for money on the sidewalks. As much as they are looked down upon and ignored; I really pity them because they are just trying the best they can to stay alive and feed themselves and stay warm during the harsh winter months (and year-round). Once in awhile if I am feeling particularly generous; I will give my change to the homeless people I pass by; but that happens very rarely. I feel pity towards them because they seem to be stuck in their situation and deep down I wish I could help all of them; but I know that it's not possible and if they want to get back on their feet they should take control of their situation and try to find a job or another way to make money.
writetende: I felt tenderness when I was in my last relationship. I was with this guy for three years and I had grown to feel a lot of tenderness towards him. I had a deep urge to take care of him and keep him happy; which I would do by comforting him when he was sad or stressed out; and surprising him with things like gifts or dates when I was able to. I feel like our emotions were deeply connected because when he felt happy; it made me happy; and when he was sad it became my sadness as well. I would connect those feelings to the tenderness that I felt towards him because I truly cared for him and wanted to make him as happy as I could.
writecomp: I feel compassion towards my patients when I am at work (a nurse assistant at a hospital). When I am at work and am taking care of my assigned patients; I truly feel compassionate towards them because I feel like it is my responsibility to take care of them and make sure they are comfortable. Hospitals can be scary; stressful places for patients and I want to do everything I can to help them during their rough times. I feel compassion because it makes my job worthwhile when I can make a patient smile or have them thank me and tell me how wonderful I have been to them.
writesymp: I was in clinical one day (I am a nursing student) at the U-M hospital and I was in a patient's room with my nurse mentor helping pass medication. While we were in there; the patient's doctor and some other residents came into the room to speak with the patient. The doctor told the patient that her test had shown that her cancer had spread to her liver and there was scarring present. Because the women was elderly and already sick; the doctor felt that going through chemotherapy would not be beneficial because the cancer only had a 20% cure rate and it would just make the woman feel more sick without much benefit. They informed her that they would switch their focus onto palliative care in order to improve her quality of life and just do everything they could to make her more comfortable. The patient had tears in her eyes and was holding her husband's hand and did not appear to be listening very well - she was lost in her own thoughts trying to comprehend what the doctor had just told her. I felt sympathy for her because I didn't know how to relate to what she was going through and I wished there was something I could do to help her.
writeempat: A friend of mine has been going through a breakup at the same time I have been; so we frequently talk with each other about our feelings and ask how we're holding up. I often times feel very empathetic when we talk because she will have rough days when she misses her ex-boyfriend and wants to get back together with him and she will tell me about those feelings. Although I no longer feel that way about my breakup; I definitely remember the feelings very strongly from just a month or two ago and can relate extremely well. Through my empathy I tell her that I know exactly how she feels and that the situation will improve because I went through it as well and it improved after time for me. I give her advice about how I got through it so I can help her get through it as well. My empathy by relating to the situation helps me talk to her and brings us closer as friends.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
tlove: I would definitely consider tenderness a kind of love. When you feel tenderness towards somebody; you really care about them on a personal level and would do many things to keep them happy; which is similar for what you would do when you love somebody.
clove: I would call compassion a kind of love because when you feel compassion towards a person; you want what is best for them and you are willing to do things out of your way to make them feel better; which is very similar to what you do when you love somebody.
slove: Sympathy could be connected to love because you are more likely to feel sympathetic towards somebody you love versus somebody you do not know or do not look at in a loving manner.
elove: I would call empathy a kind of love because when you love somebody; you are able to relate to them more and feel more empathy for that person than you can towards somebody you do not know or view in a loving manner.

writecomp: My grandfather was diagnosed with an advanced stage of cancer two years ago. My family had suspected this as we observed his deteriorating health and a visible lump which appeared on his temple area. When the news was finally out; my heart sank. I suddenly felt like I loved him even more; cherished him ever more greatly; and became fond of the many memories I shared with him as I was growing up. I felt helpless for sure; because there was nothing else I could do; but to spend more time with him during his dying days even as the situation got tougher with every week that went by.
writesymp: A classmate of mine had her dog run over in an accident by a moving vehicle just last week. As she was describing what had happened; I could also observe her beginning to tear up. At this instance; I felt sympathetic towards her. I did not know what to say; and I never had a pet getting into such an accident; or let alone a pet in a really long time. All I thought I could do was to sit there and listen and go "I'm sorry to hear that;" and that's what I did.
writeempat: A classmate of mine was hopeful on getting into the Ross School of Business. Given his high GPA and active participation in co-curricular activities at school; he was confident that he stood a good chance. Unfortunately; his application was declined and he got really discouraged. I was filled with empathy because I knew what kind of feelings he was experiencing having been rejected from something he was very sure about. I told him to consider the Ross Business minor at the end of this sophomore year instead; or to apply for the Organizational Studies program.
cfeltother: 1. Sadness (while observing my grandfather's suffering) / 2. Helplessness (as there was nothing I could do to have stopped this from happening) / 3. Hopeful (that he would have somehow got better or not suffered from the pain)
clove: Compassion is a kind of love.
sfeltother: 1. Cluelessness (on how to respond; what to do) / 2. Helplessness (as the event had already occured) / 3. Concern (for her well-being from here on)
slove: I wouldn't call it a kind of love. It's an act of showing concern for someone you may not be too close to in general.
efeltother: 1. Stressed (to think of possible solutions/alternatives to help him) / 2. Started thinking about a similar event which occurred to me in the past / 3.
elove: It can be considered a kind of love; though at a lower level when compared to compassion.

writepity: Last week I was walking down State street when I saw a women standing on the side of a building with a sign that said "Single Mother. Need money for food. Any bit helps." This is the first time I had ever felt anything toward a homeless person asking for money. Usually I just walk by ignoring them because half the time their stories aren't true. However; I felt pity for this woman because she had kids to provide for and she must have been so embarrassed to have to ask others for money. I wouldn't ever want to be in her position. She couldn't provide for her kids and as a mother; she's failing her job. I highly considered giving her money; but instead I kept walking. (I was followed by a homeless person once so I have a strict rule of not interacting with them anymore.) But I realized that her life must be very stressful; embarrassing; and that she was at her lowest point to have to ask others for money. I pitied her for the life she was stuck in and I pitied her kids for the life that they must be experiencing.
writetende: My brother had broken his arm several years ago from skateboarding in the rain. He had broken both bones in his arm and had to get surgery; which of course led to a long recovery process. Being an older sister; I felt the need to take care of him. Every day when he was watching television; I'd try to help in any way I could: bring him lunch; bring him water; play games with him; entertain him; and most importantly sooth him. I did all of this with tenderness because he was already in pain and I wanted to do anything I could in order to make him feel better. I wouldn't want to make the situation any worse so I took care of him. I'd frequently brush his hair out of his face with a soothing touch. I used a softer tone of voice. I tried to make him smile. I was nice to him. To me; this is what tenderness is all about.
writecomp: Last February; my current boyfriend; Jason; and I went to his family's cabin for Valentine's Day weekend. It was our first trip together. We have only been dating for 6 months so the car ride and the seclusion of the cabin really allowed for us to get to know each other a lot better. We learned many new things about each other and got to have a really fun get away from school. We made dinner together; watched some movies; went walking on the frozen lake. It was beautiful and very romantic.  I am in love with Jason and I therefore; obviously;  feel very compassionate toward him. I care for his well-being; I always want to be with him; close to him; experiencing new things together; etc.
writesymp: Recently; my father had to attend a funeral. It was for the man who saved his life. When my Dad was only 2 years old; he was in his basement and it exploded. A neighbor ran into the house and pulled my Dad out of the basement. Obviously; my Dad survived because I am here today; but it wasn't without burns all over his skin and countless surgeries growing up. Several years back; we got the opportunity to meet this man on his 70th birthday. He said he had always wondered if he had made the right decision by saving my Dad's life; or if his life would be worse with the future obstacle he'd have to overcome from being burned. However; after seeing my Dad with his family; he said he knew he had made the right decision and his mind was at peace. My dad and this man stayed in touch since then. My dad received a phone call two weeks ago informing him of the news. My dad went with my mom to this funeral for his friend; but also to pay his respects. How does someone say goodbye/thank a man for saving their life? This seems like such an impossible feet; and I felt so much sympathy for my dad. I know how hard it must have been for him to face that day; to see a man that we are eternally grateful for pass on. I can't imagine how difficult it must have been or how my dad was feeling. I was at school unfortunately; but I tried to send my dad comforting messages and phone calls to ease the struggle. With that being said; Thank you sir; for saving my dad.
writeempat: I am somewhat unclear what empathy entails. For this entry; I am operating under the assumption that empathy is when you can put yourself in someone else's situation and experience their feelings as well.  /  / Earlier this semester; a girl on my dance team opened up to me and told me that her boyfriend had recently broken up with her and that she was struggling with it. It was distracting her from her school work and practice and her head was all over the place. I took her out for coffee and was talked about it. I could relate to what she was saying because a year ago; my boyfriend of 2 years had broken up with me; and I had gone through many of the same emotions she was currently experiencing. I listened and let her get everything out of her system; and then tried to offer advice about things she was worried about by drawing from my own experiences. In the process; I remembered many of my old feelings of rejection and struggle; but I was also glad to not be feeling that way anymore. With this perspective; I was able to look at the situation objectively to try and help her. However; I could empathize with how crappy she was feeling because I know that feeling and it's awful. I wouldn't want that for anyone; especially my friend.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I don't think this is true. Contempt is more of thinking you are above/better than someone else. Pity is more so you realize someone is in an unfortunate situation; and you are not.
tlove: Tenderness is an emotion/action you portray when you love someone; whether it's love for a family member; friend or significant other.
clove: Compassion is certainty a kind of love shared between two people. More specifically; usually two people in a relationship. However; small amounts of compassion can also be shown in extraordinary situations.
slove: IN this situation; sympathy occurred because I held so much love for my father. I ached to have to see him go through this because i love and care for him so much. However; I also believe that sympathy can occur for people without love.
elove: In my experience; I wouldn't say I empathized out of love (I'm not that close to her haha). However; I would say that I certainty cared about the well-being of this person.

writepity: I felt pity when I heard about a girl who several of my friends knew dying by being hit by a car earlier this year. I read articles about how her brother had also died in a similar kind of accident a few years earlier; and I believe she had one surviving parent. I couldn't help thinking how absolutely horrible it would be to lose two children years apart in the same way. It made me so very sad for them. The whole situation was just tragic; and made me angry that we live in a world where this happens so often.
writetende: I felt tenderness last week when I was out with my friends at this club by First and Huron called Live. I was there with a few friends who I had not seen in a while. I remember that my friends were just being so caring towards each other and reminiscing over memories they had together; and I just felt so moved by their love and affection for each other. I remember thinking that this is what gives me faith in humanity; that people can care about each other so much. Maybe a club was an odd setting for this to happen; but I think people's love for each other can come out in all kinds of situations. I think they were showing tenderness for each other; and I definitely felt tenderness toward them. It made me smile and I probably hugged them and maybe told them I loved them (I'm the kind of person who does these things regardless; so I'm not positive if I did these things this time but I'm sure I wanted to).
writecomp: Compassion is the word that I have the hardest time defining because I think it is the most vague. However; I would call it compassion when I read blog posts by a friend's sister who is raising a child with a rare neurological disorder. I don't know the sister or her daughter; but I like reading about their lives and experiences. I sometimes feel sad or excited based on what she writes in the blog posts; and sometimes feel worried thinking about what I would do if I was in that situation. However; for the most part I feel considerable respect for what they go through and how they handle it; regardless of the fact that they handle some things in a very different way than I would (e.g. through religious involvement).
writesymp: I felt sympathy for my mother; uncle; and aunts when my grandmother passed away this summer. I felt sorrow about it as well; of course; but to be honest we were never that close. However; seeing my grandmother's children remember her and mourn her passing evoked sympathy because I could understand their sadness and feel sad for them. I tried to be there for my mother as much as possible; and add my own memories in to show that she will not be forgotten.
writeempat: I have felt empathy when one of my transgender friends talks about their experiences of discrimination or being triggered. One of my friends talked about feeling so upset by one of his professors that he was literally shaking. I think I was almost shaking when he told me about it; because I care deeply about him and I absolutely hate that he could be that emotionally hurt in a UM classroom. I imagined what he must have felt in that situation and felt upset and angry. I tried to be there for him by talking about how he felt and what his plans were going forward.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I think it can be - pity and respect often do not go together. I think I have felt pity without contempt though.
tlove: I think tenderness is not necessarily a kind of love; but tender love can occur; especially in the kinds of situations where you just feel soft towards someone and are struck by how beautiful you are and how much you love them - I imagine people feel this a lot at weddings
clove: Again; I do not think compassion is necessarily the same as love. Compassionate love might be the same as romantic love; though (as opposed to passionate love - I always thought of companionate and compassionate as similar).
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I don't think I would call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: My high boys school track team was always known for being a bit crazy and having something weird things go on in the locker room. At some point three juniors on the team got in trouble for hazing and were actually arrested and expelled/suspended from the school. Two of the boys were well known around the school for being especially intelligent students; and they were also two of the top runners on the team. I think that one of the boys had an incredibly high GPA and was likely to be recruited by Princeton for track. I was not close to any of the boys so I did not doing anything about the situation; but because I knew about their stories I did feel some pity that their future's were basically ruined. I did not know the details of what happened in reality with the hazing.
writetende: Several years ago there was a boy that I was talking to / getting close to etc. Over the course of only a few months I felt incredibly close to him and loved spending time with him. Very suddenly he stopped talking to me when he started seeing an ex girlfriend again; and we went months without talking. Finally we started talking again and hung out several times. I think that I would describe part of my emotions then as "tenderness" because the situation was like starting anew with an old situation. I had previously felt close to him and was sort of touching on this again? I felt very strange because I still felt like I knew him very well but I had not talked to him for a very long time; and his personality had also changed in many ways.
writecomp: My high school boyfriend and I loved to do all kinds of cool things together around New York City (where we grew up). I think that on each sort of "adventure" that we went on I would feel an especially high amount of compassion for him as we spent the day together. I guess one example is we walked over the Brooklyn Bridge and explored part of Brooklyn; went to a supermarket and bought cheese because we both love trying cool types of cheese; and then went out for a nice dinner. I felt very close to  him and just very comfortable and happy. /
writesymp: In my freshman year of high school my best friend's aunt passed away. Her aunt was middle aged and died because of cancer. She had two teenage children. My friend had never lost a family member before. I think I found out because she texted me or called me in the middle of the school day and I met her during a class and she was crying and I really did not know what to say to make her feel better. I think this partially stemmed from the fact that I had never dealt with this kind of situation before myself; and also just from the fact that no one ever really knows what to say when someone loses a loved one. I remember thinking that I wanted to be there for her and make her feel better yet at the same time I knew that I really could not make it any better; and I could just be there as a sort of presence so that she knew I was there.
writeempat: My friend from high school is a grade below me so he went through the college application process after I did. Several months ago he found out that he was deferred from one of his top choices. He was not totally devastated but it was the first college from which he had heard news; which just isn't a great way to start off hearing back from colleges. I felt empathy because I had gone through the same process before and had had to deal with some rejection from several colleges. This empathy meant that I felt like I could relate to him because of the shared experiences. Due to this empathy; I felt a responsibility to make him feel better about not being accepted. I basically told him the same things that I thought about or was told when I was upset about not being accepted; such as assuring him that he would find a place where he will be happy.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I do not think this is true. I would define contempt to be strong dislike. I think that pity is different and is more like sympathy but in a less caring way. I think that in some situations; you can pity someone for whom you have contempt; but I think that these emotions are two different things.
tlove: I would call tenderness a kind of love. I think it is a kind of love that has a history behind it. I also think that my definition of tenderness is very different from the one hinted at in the questions.
clove: I would call compassion a kind of love; and I would say it is related to joint emotions between two people.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love. I would say; however; that people are often more empathetic to people for whom they have feelings of love.

writepity: I do not have an experience where i felt pity/don't know exact definition/feeling.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my dad when my mom would always blame him for my sister and my mistakes. I would feel tender towards my mom because i dislike when she does that. Even when she does it now i still feel tenderness. It the weird friction between the family and its when my dad and i are one side and my sister and mom are the other side battling against each other; but you try to stay together as a family; but you know no matter what dad will get the blame and never my mom.
writesymp: Sympathy. I felt sympathy when  my dad's mother died. my dad would just sit there in a room alone and just start crying. I would walk into the room and know that he was crying but he wouldn't say a word. I felt so much sympathy. I knew i could not do anything to bring back his mother. Days went by where this happened day in and day out. Everything reminded my dad of his mother. I just sat there staring at him not knowing what to do feeling sympathetic. Its like the moments where you possible can not do anything to make somebody feel better. You are unable to fix the problem or help solve it so the only response is to be sympathetic. Seeing my dad stare at my grandma in her casket. with tears running down his face without effort. Just not knowing what to do but to cry with him and to be there for him. To see how much his mom meant to my dad. And to see how much pain my dad was in because of his grandma.
writeempat: when  my sister finished both of her triathlon races i was so happy and actually started crying; and so did my dad. Just to see her complete something that i have never done before is amazing and to see her ability to keep going and pushing forward is awesome. I felt empathy after her race was finished and she completed it!
plove: i would not call pity love
pcontempt: not sure what it means
tlove: i would not consider tenderness love
slove: i would call love sympathy. sympathy means you have the love of somebody and you care for them enough to have some feelings towards them; in this case the feeling of love.
elove: yes. Empathy is love because you care. i care about my sister. i love my sister.

writepity: One time I felt pity was when one of my old roommate was having some issues with me and my other roommate. We were all once very close but this roommate started to jealous of how close me and my other roommate were becoming and she felt as if she was getting pushed out and didn't like it. She was try to make us feel bad about leaving her out or she would try to include herself in situations when she wasn't invited in the first place. Neither me or my other roommate thought she was a bad person or felt like anybody deserved this; but she kept playing herself as the victim and wouldn't listen to any reason. I felt pity in one particular time when me and my other roommate when to a friend's birthday party where the old roommate wasn't invited to. She kept calling us and trying to see where we were and tried to get her boyfriend to find out where we were and come join us. I just didn't realize how desperate some people can be just to feel included even when they know that the aren't wanted in that particular situation.
writetende: One time when I was feeling tenderness was when my dad got sick really sick and eventually realized he had bronchitis. He lied in bed most of the time and barely could talk. I would help him out with whatever he needed and warmed up food and tea for him. I also knew my mom was stressed out with everything going on; like taking care of my dad and going to work so I tried to help out around the house as much as I could and didn't argue or yell with anyone so that it was a lot calmer around the house. I remember just trying to be soothing and comforting as much as possible.
writecomp: One time when I felt compassion toward someone was when I was in a relationship with my first boyfriend in college. He lived in the dorm across the street from me so I would see him almost everyday and spend a lot of time with him. We aren't together anymore; but not because he isn't a great guy. He was always very sweet and kind to me and always put other people; not just me; before himself in all kinds of situations. I felt very compassionate towards him and the kind of personality he had. He would always be open to doing all different kinds of things; whether it be just sitting in bed and watching tv or going out to a party and hanging out with my friends even though he didn't really know any of them that well. One specific moment was when we were on our way to a party that one of my friends was throwing and towards the end of the night another one of my friends started to feel really badly. My boyfriend stepped up and took charge of the situation and really knew how to handle it when nobody else did. I saw that he really knew what he was doing and that he was a strong person.
writeempat: One time that I was feeling empathy towards someone was when the best friend of a close friend of mine committed suicide. My friend was really; really heartbroken over her loss even though that friend of hers had been having a lot of issues for a while and had been on a rough path for a long time. My friend was coping okay after a couple of days but I just felt bad for what she was going through because I know I would feel the same way if I lost my best friend in the same way. I wanted to be there for her but she kind of pushed me away and wanted her space so I gave her as much time as she needed until she was ready to talk to me. Eventually she did come and tell me how she was feeling and we talked it out which made her feel better and made me feel like I was able to help her out even a little bit.
plove: Pity is a kind of sad; unrequited love
pcontempt: I think in some ways pity is like comtempt because you can feel anger towards the person depending on what they did.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of gentle; soothing love.
clove: Compassion is a kind of powerful; giving love.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: i felt pity is the situation when there is someone who supposed to achieve something; but for some reasons; he/she cannot achieve the certain goal he/she wants.  /  / for example; a very good friend of mine is very good at study; and always he can achieve very good result in academic performance. However; he just too shy in the interview (Maybe; i guess); then he lost a chance for internship in a company. so that's why i felt pity.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards someone includes a situation when i see someone who works so hard; but they just cannot make it because of some inevitable social/political/economical situation which prevents them to do so; and still; they have a very lower living standard and they deserve a more justice treatment and cared by more people.  /  / actually; i really want to change the social system to a more justice and fair one; but i just don't have the power to do so. and government officials are so corrupted; so basically this situation will last
plove: i would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: No; I think pity is just an emotion of when seeing others who supposed to succeed but not. Everyone fails; so i think i at least i have the responsibility to cheer them up; tell them to face more positively. So; to listen or not is their choice; and everyone should be responsible for their own fate and career.
elove: it is a love to protect those who are in a weaker status or the minorities. everyone has the responsibility to be involved;

writepity: 1) I felt a lot of pity towards someone once when I was at Cedar Point. A women who was very large was trying to get into the ride but she was not fitting and there was no way that she would be able to. She then had to get out of the seat; pretend to smile as if nothing was wrong; and leave her friends as they got to enjoy the ride.  /  / 2) I was feeling extreme pity for the woman because I felt so sad for her that she had let her own body get to that point. Although I didn't know the woman at all; I felt so sorry for her because I could only imagine the pain she was feeling from public embarrassment because of being too fat. I was thinking how sad it is that she was that large because I felt as if she couldn't have been too happy with herself and she couldn't have been very healthy at all and I really felt pain for her.    /  / 3) There wasn't anything I wanted to do because I didn't know the woman. I didn't do anything except feel sorry for her and I didn't say anything to her; except to my sister as I expressed my sadness and feelings of pity for the woman.
writecomp: 1) In a high school; a class mate of mine committed suicide. Although I didn't know her very well; I have always felt it is important to attend viewings and funerals. I went to the viewing and saw her parents crying. Her fathers face was very red and he had his head in his hands sobbing. I felt compassion towards him because although I could never know what he was going through; I felt so sad that he had to be going through this. I could feel his pain just by looking at him. I felt compassion for the girl's father and her family.   /  / 2) I deeply wished that there was a way I could make the family feel better but I didn't even know them so I knew I couldn't. I felt good that I was there to show support; but all I could was cry and feel so sad for the family and for what the girl must have been going through. I was probably crying more than anyone there. It was very painful for me to see the family so devastated.  /  / 3) I wished I could help; but all I did was offer my condolences; sit in the funeral home for a while; and talked to some of the family members of the girl.
writesymp: 1) One of my best friends is frequently in a tough situation in that he doesn't get deserved help from his parents. One day he told me he was afraid of literally starving since he had to worry about paying bills and his parents were not helping him enough with food. This made me feel very sympathetic.   /  / 2) I was feeling very sad towards the situation and sad for him because I have always had the luxury of supportive parents who take their role as parents seriously. I felt desperate to find a way to help him and I also felt anger towards his parents. I understood the situation and all of its components and it made me even more sad to think about how deserving my friend was of more help from his parents.  /  / 3) I really wanted to help in any way I could. I gathered some extra food I had that I could definitely spare and I gave it to him. I continue to keep an eye out for any food I could offer to him. I told him that what is happening to him isn't fair and that he should always know that he deserves better than this. I made sure to tell him I loved him because I could only imagine the lack of love he felt due to his parents' neglect. I told him he would get through this and I would always be there to help and offer support.
writeempat: 1) I felt empathy towards a friend of mine when they returned from a midterm exam crying. They had taken time to study for the exam and upon taking it; the GSI proctoring the exam started late and failed to give extra time to the students. This resulted in my friend not finishing the exam.  /  / 2) I was feeling very sorry for my friend because I know how stressful exams are and how frustrating it is to put so much time and effort into something only to come up short and because of unfairness. I could easily place myself in his shoes and understand why he was so upset.  /  / 3) I wanted to make him feel better but I knew there was not much I could do. I did; however hug and gave him advice. I told him to immediately email his professor to explain what happened. I told him I would also be upset in this situation and I stressed that I would explain the problem to the professor immediately because it was extremely unfair.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I don't think this is true.
clove: Compassion is a deep heart-ed kind of love that can hit the person who is feeling it hard; and if the other party is aware of the compassion; it could be a nice thing to feel that someone is feeling compassion towards you.
slove: If sympathy were a kind of love; it would be a kind of love that comes from someone who cares about the person and exhibits a support towards the person that shows they are there for them.
efeltother: 1. Annoyed at the GSI / 2. like I couldn't help very much  / 3.
elove: Empathy is a supportive kind of love. It helps people see they are not alone.

writepity: Once when I was biking home from swim practice; I saw a guy lying on the side of the road.  He was my neighbor; and pretty overweight; so I stopped and asked him if he was okay.  He was clutching his knee and couldn't really speak; so I called an ambulance. Meanwhile; I got a few of the older boys in the neighborhood to help lift him into the ambulance when it got here; and I kept talking to him to try to make him feel comfortable. Eventually the ambulance came and he was taken to the hospital; and when he came back; he had to be in a wheelchair for several weeks; but he was okay.  I think mostly; he was embarrassed that he couldn't stand up by himself; so I tried to be as respectful of him as possible when talking to him.
writetende: When my baby sister and I were little; we used to rescue animals all the time. Birds; frogs; cats; squirrels; and especially turtles.  Once; we found a squirrel that had gotten a wicked case of Mange; a type of bacteria that makes you lose your fur; so our mom brought some medicine home from work (she's a veterinarian) and we made some peanut butter balls with medicine inside for her to eat. The squirrel gobbled them right up! A few weeks later she had fur again and actually became a mom to three baby squirrels. :)
writecomp: Right before I walked into this study; a man was walking into East Hall before me; and he had a walker to help him walk.  I felt compassion for him; because he reminded me of my grandparents and how they struggle to do basic things in their old age; so I opened the door for him.  I think I mentioned something about the weather being nice out too.  I almost didn't help him; because I never know if helping people makes them feel inadequate or that they are incapable of helping themselves; but I opened the door anyway.
writesymp: I took an alternative spring break trip this year to West Virginia and I was amazed by how much rural poverty there was.  We worked with a family resource center; which existed to strengthen the family unit.  They had lots of classes teaching young families how to properly discipline their children; and they provided meals from a meal kitchen.  I learned so much about different lifestyles from talking to these people.  The main thing I observed was that it seemed like people were trapped in their own situation.  Perhaps they had a kid when they were young; or an older family member needed to be taken care of at home.  I could sympathize with them; I could try to understand what they were feeling.
writeempat: Last year; I found out a girl in my hall; we'll call her Nora; was cutting herself.  She gave me her knife to hang onto; so that she wouldn't hurt herself; but I knew that wouldn't be enough to stop her. so I told my RA; who told my hall director; who got her help.
