I knew it wouldn't stop her; because sometimes when I used to get stressed; I would want to hurt myself too; but I got help.  I was worried that she would find out that I told on her and not want to be my friend anymore; but since then she's gone on anti-depressants and doesn't cut herself anymore; and she never found out that it was me who told on her. :)
plove: I think there is love in everything; but I'm not entirely sure how to describe it in pity.
pcontempt: I disagree.  Feeling bad for someone doesn't mean you hate them; or are disgusted by them; necessarily.
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love.  It is pleasant and compassionate.
clove: Love in that you want to help people in some way; to spread love.
slove: I think sympathy is a kind of love; because it inspires action.
elove: I think empathy is a kind of love in that you see people who have gone through something similar to what you have gone through; and thus you have love for them in a way that you would have wanted someone to love you when you were in that situation.

writepity: 1. I felt pity when one of my friends was going through a lot of rough experiences all at once.  She was filling out graduate school application; integrating into a new work environment; broke up with her boyfriend; got in a big fight with her parents; and was taking a rigorous class schedule all at the same time.   /  / 2. I felt bad for her because she is one of my best friends and was going through so many hard things all at once.  I wanted to be able to help her and be there for her to talk to to sort things out.  /  / 3. I was available for her to talk to me as much as possible and I stayed in with her many nights so that she wouldn't have to be alone and so she would not have to cry all by herself.  I told her that everything would work itself out and that she should make decisions that make her happy and not try to be a people pleaser all the time.
writetende: I felt tenderness when I met my baby cousin for the first time.  She had just turned 2 years old.  My family lives out of state so we do not get to see them that often.  I got to hold her and play with her.  She was a very sweet little girl and she loved to play with her toys.  I felt happy and also a bit nurturing towards her.  I wanted to stay and play with her for a long time and get to know her better.
writecomp: I felt compassion when I asked two of my best friends to be bridesmaids for me.  They were so excited and had no idea that I was going to ask because it had been  a few weeks since my engagement.  I surprised them with new nail polish and candy; and a bottle of sangria.  I was feeling really happy about them being in my wedding and also about the fact that they had no idea what was coming but that I knew they would be excited.
writesymp: I felt sympathy for one of my old middle school friends when he dad got into a tragic car accident and died upon impact.  I felt really bad for her because she was very close with her dad and she was also only 13 years old.  I did not know how she felt because I've never gone through that type of a situation but I was able to support her at the funeral and go over to her house to try and cheer her up.  We didn't really talk about it but I just wanted her to know that I was there if she needed me.
writeempat: I felt empathy for another person when I found out that; like me; they had a sibling die at birth/an early age.  This other person later become my fiance.  I felt like we had a common tragedy and that allowed us to in a way 'bond' over it.  We both felt sad about it but were able to be there for each other.  I told him  about my own experience and then we were able to talk about how each of us were able to move forward with our lives.
plove: i would not call 'pity' love
pcontempt: I think this has some truth to it.  People often feel pity for another person and try to help that person but I think you can only give so much pity before you need to move on with your own life; which then would lead your pity towards that person to contempt because you feel as though they are bogging you down all the time.
tlove: tenderness in the kind of love that is warm and soft and is just nice to have
clove: compassion is the kind of love where you do nice things for the people you care about.
slove: i would not call sympathy love
elove: Empathy would be the kind of love that shows another person that you know what it feels like to be where they are.  You bring yourself back down to that place in order for the other person to not feel so alone.  Then you help them as they find their way. /  /

writepity: When my best friend went through her first major break-up; I felt pity for her. She couldn't accept her boyfriend's decision; and kept getting drunk and banging on his door every night crying. I knew she was in pain; but I felt like she was acting irrationally. I think that's why I felt more pity than sympathy for her; because I felt like she was not handling the situation as best as she could have. I listened to her and felt compassion for her loss; but part of me felt above her because of the way she was acting. I wanted to tell her she had to "buck up" eventually and accept the situation; but I knew I could not tell her that. Instead; I talked with her through her feelings and emotions.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my Mom when she had her mastectomy due to breast cancer. I remember when she came home she was on a lot of pain medication and her arm was in a sling. Of course; she needed help around the house and she both looked and felt vulnerable. I felt tenderness towards her because of that vulnerability; and my voice reflected that tender feeling. When I spoke to her; it was in a more concerned and soothing tone than normal. I was very attentive to her symptoms; feelings; wants and needs during that time in a way that was uncharacteristic of our normal mother-daughter relationship. My mom is very maternal; but during that time I felt more like the maternal character because she was the one in need. I asked her consistently if I could do anything for her; and I cooked most of the food for the family during that week. I wanted to try to minimize her discomfort and do as much as I could for her.
writecomp: A friend of mine had a very troubled family life growing up. She told me that her mother stole her credit cards; maxed them one; and therefore messed up her financial aid situation for college. In order to get the financial aid she needed; she had to emancipate herself from her mother. She also stopped talking to her; and moved out to live on her own. When my friend told me this; I felt compassion for her because I realized she had to overcome so much. I was amazed by her resiliency; and felt I understood her a little better because I knew where she had come from. However; I knew that I could never really understand all that she had gone through with her family; and told her I couldn't imagine what I would have done in her situation. I felt like I wanted to help her in some way; though I knew I couldn't really. Overall I felt closer to her; and felt she was deserving of small favors here and there (rides places; etc.) because her life has been hard enough. I felt grateful for everything I have; and the fact that I have parents who I can count on.
writesymp: Earlier this year; a good friend of mine's mother died. At the funeral; I remember looking at him and feeling intense sympathy for him. I kept thinking about how heartbroken he must feel; and how everything must remind him of his mother. I bought him and his family food; even though I knew small comforts wouldn't help the situation. At the funeral I hugged him and told him "I'm so sorry". I wanted him to know I was thinking of him; and that even though we hadn't been close in years; that he and his other old friends were here for him. After the funeral; I made sure to invite him places in order to include him and take his mind off of his loss; and regularly asked his close friends how he was doing.
writeempat: My boyfriend's ex-girlfriend died; and I felt empathy towards him as he was telling me the story of her death. He told me they were on vacation together; and when he woke up he discovered she had died in her sleep. He told me he reacted calmly; but hours later; the permanency of the situation sunk in and he felt out of control. As he was telling me this; I kept picturing the situation in my mind and imagining how I would think and feel in the same situation. I felt a sense of panic when thinking about it; and tried to fathom how he must have felt. As he told me about it; I mostly listened and asked questions to try to understand how he felt. On the inside; I felt sympathetic towards him and emotional. The next day; I cried thinking about what he went through. I kept re-living how I would have felt if one of my ex-boyfriend's had died; and I was there to witness it. While I felt very sad for my boyfriend; I also was amazed by his resiliency.
plove: I would not call it love
pcontempt: Somewhat; because I think pity has an emotional distance in which the person feels better than the person they pity. They would not want to be in their shoes.
tlove: Empathic love
clove: A type of love in which a person takes the other person's problems to heart and truly cares about them rather than being apathetic towards them.
slove: Love in the sense that you are affected by another person's suffering
elove: Love in understanding another

writepity: I felt pity towards my boyfriend when he first told me about how he is not very close to his family. He told me that he has always felt like a bit of an outsider in his family; that they don't really understand him; and now he feels like he isn't close to them and cannot relate to them. He is not close with his brother as well (they hardly ever talk); which is something I really pity; because my brother is my best friend. My boyfriend does not enjoy spending time with his family; dreads vacations with them; talking to them on the phone; coming home to visit them; etc. and he does not see much wrong with it. He accepts that his life is that way and his family simply isn't very important to him. I pity him because I am very much the opposite; my family is incredibly important to me. I love them to the ends of the earth; and I love spending time with them. I have grown up being close to my parents and especially my brother; who I can barely go a day without talking to. I pity him because I feel as though he has missed out on so many beautiful experiences that I myself have experienced (and take for granted). I don't express my pity to him too much; because he does not think he deserves it; he does not think he is in a situation to be pitied.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards my baby brother when I saw him for the first time after he was born. I was 7.5 years old and I remember going to the hospital and holding him in my arms for the first time. My mom gently placed him in my arms and showed me how to hold him and I remember being astonished at how small and delicate he was. His eyes could barely open; everything was tiny; fragile; his head covered in soft wispy curls. I felt protective of this newborn human being; realizing that he was MY baby brother; I was his one and only older sister and suddenly I felt responsibility to make sure that nothing ever hurt him. I wanted him to love me someday as much as I loved him in this moment. I wanted us to be best friends someday. I touched his face (I had washed my hands carefully before holding him) and smiled to myself. I think I remarked on how cute he was; how small. My grandparents were there; along with both of my parents; and they chuckled quietly among themselves. But I remember feeling so grown-up all of a sudden because I was holding this fragile creature.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my friend when her dad passed away. It was a terrible summer and he had gotten pneumonia and been hospitalized. Their family were close family-friends of my family; this friend is like a sister to me. When her father was hospitalized; that month was hell for all of us. We did everything we could to help their family; he fought long and hard; but his health ended up rapidly declining towards the end. I was devastated on the day that my mother quietly told me that the fight was over. I locked myself in my room and cried until my eyes could no longer produce tears. I was 15 and he was the first person I had lost who I had felt close to; this was really my first time experiencing grief. I felt sympathy towards my friend because I could not imagine what she was going through if I was having such a hard time. I could not imagine what it would be like to lose my own dad at such a young age (she was only 10 at the time). We went to their house that evening and I held her while she cried and I cried as well. Everything felt like a nightmare and I just wanted to wake up.
writeempat: I felt empathy towards my brother when he started crying after having a "bad performance" after a piano competition. He thought that he had played terribly because he forgot a part; even though I though he sounded fine and I knew that messing up was part of these high-pressurized situations. I also felt empathy because I knew what it was like to be in his shoes. I had had several piano performances throughout the 12 years I had learned piano; and the one that stuck out most to me was when I started crying after a concerto performance in Poland. I thought that I had sounded awful; that I hadn't been in sync with the orchestra at numerous parts of the piece; etc. Everyone told me I sounded marvelous; but I refused to believe them (much like what my brother was doing). I cried that evening after my concerto performance because I was so disappointed in myself; I just wanted one more chance to prove myself on that stage. My brother told me that he felt the same way. I told him about my experience in Poland; I told him I knew how he felt. I also made sure to tell him that after all my disappointment; I went and watched the video recording of myself and realized that I hadn't performed as badly as I thought I did. I told him that it always seems awful in that moment; but the truth is that he are all a little too hard on ourselves when we perform. I think he felt a little better after that.
plove: I do not think pity is necessarily synonymous with love.
pcontempt: It might be true sometimes when you don't have a desire to help alleviate the situation the person you are pitying is in.
clove: tender; caring love. the kind of love that makes you want to scoop someone up and make sure nothing ever hurts them.
slove: love that makes you want to carry some of their pain on your own shoulders so they suffer less
elove: I-know-how-you-feel-because-I've-been-there love

writepity: I was on a bus the other day when I saw an old lady carrying two big plastic bags full of beverage cans and beer bottles. The bus was pretty full that time and it was really hard to move around with two such big bags. However; there was no one willing to stand up and gave his or her seat to this old lady. I took pity on her and decided to gave my seat to her seeing tha she could not even stand straight in the overly-crowded bus. It reminded me of my mother when I looked at the old lady and it upset me when I realized that there is no one willing to help at that point of time. I felt responsible to help her even though she had no relation to me. I imagined how would I feel if that lady was my mother carrying so much stuff without a single person willing to help her when she is in need.
writetende: It happened a lot of times when I argued with my brother. He was always the rebellious one and would like to hold on to certain things that he thought and believed was correct. It was frustrating when arguing with him over certain things that was so minor. Once; he got on my nerves and we quarrelled over who should get in the backseat of a car first. After a few days of not talking to each other; I decided to inititate the conversation with him and at that moment I felt more tendered towards him; blaming myself for being too harsh at times and never consider his feelings. I swear to be a good sister thereafter.
writecomp: When comes to compassion; I would think of my mother. She always serves as the inspiration to me and I look up on her in everything she does. In short; she is a  role model to me. The feeling of compassion towards her comes from the little things she does in her daily lives. She is a businesswoman and housewife at the same time and I could not understand how she could manage her time so well that she achieves success in her business without neglecting the family's welfare. She takes care of each and everyone in the family so well and yet she never complains about being tired or frustrated at times. When I am facing problems in friendship or in general relationship with people; she would always be there for me; listening to me and motivating me. I am so proud of having her whenever I need someone to talk to and seek for advices.
writesymp: While I was traveling in Peru; I passed by a poor village in the rural area on my way to Machu Picchu. I spent a night in that village and while I was walking down the street near my hostel; I saw a little kid was picking something from the ground and put it into his mouth. I was so shocked because it looked like a trash to me and I ran forward to stop the kid from doing that. It was really hard to express what I wanted to say to that kid due to language barrier and all I could do was using my body language to tell him that he could not pick up anything from the street and eat it. I felt sympathy to this boy seeing how hungry he was that he picked up anything he could find on the street and ate it. Eventually; I went to buy some food for him and asked him to go home as soon as possible since it was near midnight that time. It was my first time dealing with such situation seeing how poverty could affect a person so much.
writeempat: My friend told me that she is in depressed because she just broke up with her boyfriend. The reason that they broke up being that the guy thought that both of them have a very different personalities that the communication gap between them got bigger and bigger over time. After listening to that; I felt the same as my friend due to my past experience. The bad memories of my past relationship flashed through my mind and I could not stop but being emotionally affected. However; I told my friend how I overcame my sadness and let her know that each and everyone of us is unique and thus if something do not work out; we should move forward in search of the right person.
plove: I think pity is not a kind of love.
pcontempt: No; I do not think so. I am not contempting people when I take pity on them. Rather; I feel the responsibility to help them as much as I can because I believe everyone has the same right to get whatever they need and want. We should always help them to achieve that if we were able to.
tlove: No. I do not call it a kind of love.
clove: Compassion is a kind of love when you feel so close ot someone that you would like to be like someone because that person has the characteristics you  wish you have generally.
slove: Sympathy is a kind of love when you feel that you have the responsibility to do something to help certain people who are in pain are facing problems. I felt I have the responsibility to help the kid and being caring to him by buying him food so that he would not suffer from hunger.
elove: Empathy is a kind of love you share with others due to the same feeling you feel when you see the situation someone is suffering from. It might due to the same past experience that you would like to use your own experience to help certain people who are suffering to get out of what they are facing.

writepity: I felt pity for my neighbor when she lost her three babies. She was about 5 months pregnant with triplets and was so excited to be pregnant. She went in to labor at 5 months and they could do nothing to stop the labor; so she gave birth to her three babies; all under one pound. Each baby was born alive; but within the first 24 hours they all died. I heard about the situation in an email from the mom's mother the day after the incident. I felt so incredibly sorry for this woman and her husband. I can't imagine what it would be like to lose your child; let alone three of them in one day. She was so excited to be a mom and in a span of 24 hours that was taken away from her. They even named the children; but then had to bury them all. So incredibly sad.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my sister when she found out she didn't get into the college she wanted to get in to. I knew the situation was a big disappointment to her; and what she needed was some encouragement and love. I knew that it would have been awful if i was in her place; and I would want someone to be sweet to me; so that's how I treated her. In that moment; she only needed kind words; and nothing mean or rude.
writecomp: One time i felt compassion for the campers that were in my cabin this summer at camp. I was a counselor at a special needs camp in Missouri and over the summer I had campers with varying disabilities and varying ages. To me; compassion is a mixture of sympathy and love towards someone or something. Compassion compels you to act and to love on that person. Many of the campers at camp needed help with something such as dressing; getting ready for the day; eating; bathing; etc. Their disability and sweet hearts caused me to want to take care of them and have compassion on them by loving on them.
writesymp: I felt sympathy towards my neighbors family when they found out their father had Cancer again. He had battled brain cancer earlier in his life; and now he is married with three children and the brain cancer came back. I felt really sad for their family because I knew it must be so difficult to go through something like that. The kids didn't even know what Cancer was; they only knew their father was really sick. I knew if my dad was really sick like that I would have worried so much about him. I also love my neighbors family very much and had to watch them go through this hard time and it was so hard not to be able to do anything to solve it or fix the father. Prayer was all i could do.
writeempat: When my friend tore her ACL playing soccer i felt empathy towards her because a few weeks earlier I had done the same thing. I knew she would be going through the same process as me and that this would be a very hard time for her. I knew that soon she would have surgery like I did and it would be frustrating and painful; but that it would get better. I wanted to encourage her because I knew how she was feeling and I knew what I would have wanted to hear in that situation.
plove: I do not consider it a kind of love.
pcontempt: No; I felt pity because I felt so bad for her situation; not because I disliked her in any way.
tlove: I think it's a sweet kind of love; a comforting kind of love. The person who needs tenderness is usually vulnerable; so they don't need tough love; they need gentleness.
clove: I think it's a selfless type of love because it causes you to go outside of yourself and love another person. The situation occured outside of my control; but I wanted to intervene anyway.
slove: It's loving them because you know they need to be loved. I know that the situation they were going through must be really difficult and love sometimes is the only thing you can do to help. Everyone needs to feel loved.
elove: Not necessarily love.

writepity: In one of my classes; students give a presentation everyday. One day; a girl gave a presentation on the same topic that some had the class before. This made it obvious that she had skipped the last class. Everyone recognized the topic and just kind of sat there; murmuring to each other about what was happening. I felt SO BAD for her and pitied that poor girl standing up there with everyone making comments to each other about her presentation.
writecomp: Sometimes; my mind wanders and I think about what life would be like without my dad. In these moments; I get extremely sad; but then become filled with love for my dad and just want to tell him that I love him. I care about him so much and want him to know.
writesymp: My Aunt's best friend died recently and she has been taking it roughly. I feel sympathy for her because I don't think she deserved this hardship and pain and wish she was in higher spirits. I feel like there isn't much I can do to make her feel better. I want to; but don't know how. I just feel bad that she has to go through this.
writeempat: My friend was telling me about an event his student organization had planned. He told that there was a blogger who wrote an article bashing the event; even though most people who knew about it on campus were excited. He told me that it was really upsetting to have people out there who speak so negatively about something that other people had worked hard for and wouldn't let something positive just happen. I understood what he meant since I had planned a service trip this Spring Break ; and; although it went amazingly well; a few people still were negative about it for stupid reasons. I could understand how he felt and wanted to be supportive since I remember wanting some support when I felt that similar feeling. I told that there are always people like that and not to let them bring him down. I really wanted to be more help; but I feel that I couldn't do much more. I really just hope that the event goes well and he can relish in its success.
plove: I wouldn't call it that.
pcontempt: No. Although I pitied this girl; I didn't feel a negative feeling towards her personally; just her situation.
clove: I would definitely call it love because it is a way of showing that you care for someone.
slove: I would say that it KIND OF is because it is a way of showing you care; even if it isn't always the most constructive way.
elove: I wouldn't call it love.

writecomp: I felt compassionate towards one of my middle school friends whose father had passed away suddenly.  She was a girl in my grade and we were all part of a pretty big group of friends.  Her dad coached the 5th/6th grade basketball team while I was on the 7th/8th grade basketball team; so I wasn't really too familiar with him from in that way.  I had met him before at her birthday party earlier that month; so it was weird to think that he was no longer living.  I remember feeling really sad because I tried to put myself in her shoes; how I would react/feel if my father had suddenly passed.  I felt like I wanted to bring him back somehow; as she was only 12-13 at the time.  I thought about how he wouldn't get to see her or her younger brother grow up and have families and be there for his grandkids.  I tried my best to be compassionate; but when it comes to death; I felt that there is only so much words can do.
writesymp: A time when I felt sympathetic was when I was walking down State Street.  There's always a bunch of homeless guys there and I always feel really sympathetic because I don't know how they live that way.  I know I couldn't do it; especially when it was particularly hot or cold outside.  But at the same time; I always remind myself of the numerous reasons why they're in their situation... Maybe they got mixed up with drugs; alcohol; or gambling.  Maybe they did something (that could have been avoided) and put themselves in their predicament.  They're situation may not be as innocent as they make it seem.  Of course there's a small part of me that wants to give them money to help them out; but then I always hear about how people beg for money claiming to use it towards food/warm clothing/for their families etc; but then go ahead and use it to buy cigarettes; drugs/alcohol; or to gamble; all things that the donor did not intend for that money to go to use for.
cfeltother: 1. Gratefulness (for my own situation) / 2. Sadness / 3. Helpless
clove: I would consider compassion a kind of love.  It is similar to sympathy in that compassion is derived from the care and general well-being for another individual.
slove: Sympathy is a kind of love in my opinion.  I think it is about the care for the welfare of a normal human being; and so in that respect; would be a type of love.

writepity: 1) Someone did something not so good due to jealousy; I feld sorry for him for doing what he did; but didn't say anything.
writecomp: A classmate suddenly suffered an unexpected illness recently.  I feel compassion towards her; worrying about her and wanting to know the updates about her condition.  I checked the WeiChat; a similar media like Tweet frequently to get the updates.  I'm also praying for her recovery.
writesymp: In the previous example; the classmate got seriously ll suddently; I feel sympathy for the family members for what they are suffering emotionally.
writeempat: Someone who is overweight was telling me about their physical difficulties such as gettign around from place to place.  I have empathy for her; but was thinking that she could have done something to change the situation.
plove: I wouldn't call pity love
pcontempt: They saying has some trueth.  When I feel pity for someone; I'm feeling better about myself.
clove: It's a general kind love for someone you know.
slove: A kind love for fellow human being
efeltother: 1. concerns for his well being if no change happens / 2.  / 3.
elove: empathy is a form of love hoping for better for the person that I have the feeling towards.

writepity: I remember feeling pity when my close friend told me that he did poorly on the previous organic chemistry test. He got a 60 percent or something close to that. My close friend works very hard; much harder than me. But I did much better than him on the test.  He teaches me the material taught in lecture very often. I felt pity because I thought that he deserved a much higher grade for all the effort he put into the test (he had gotten above 90 percent on all the tests prior to this one.) I also felt pity for him because I knew how important grades are to him; so getting a bad grade is pretty tough to take. I remember thinking that he was way to smart to not do well on the next tests; so I told him that. I also told him that the test was extremely hard and his grade was still significantly above average; so it would not be too difficult to manage an A for the class. I didn't talk about my test because that wouldn't help the situation. I remember watching his face to see if he was disappointed; defeated; or positive. The main emotion that I saw was determination to do better on the next tests.
writesymp: I felt sympathy toward my golf coach when he said he was and still is going through tough times because his daughter had not been in good health for quite a while. The people involved were the 6 varsity members of my high school golf team and my coach. After not making in to the state championship; out coach said he was bummed; but that he could not be more proud of the team's effort that we put forth all season. He admitted that it was very difficult coaching the golf team and taking care of his daughter at the same time. What made me feel sympathy was his honesty and willingness to open up about a topic that is very touchy and difficult to talk about. He is normally a very composed and often; harshly blunt in his methods of communication; so it was very different to see him show his true emotions. Also; he started to tear up; which made me feel sympathy. I felt sympathy because I understood what he was going through; as my aunt is also not in the best of health. When my aunt first became ill; my mom went through the same thing. It was hard for my mom to manage everyday tasks; like her job; while also taking care of my aunt's healthcare situation. My mom; a very strong woman; has a personality much like my golf coach; and they both acted similarly in their respective situations.  /  / I remember saying to my golf coach that everybody on the team was there for him and we would support him no matter what. Everybody on the team chimed in. I remember that i couldn't see my coach's face; as he was driving the van back home and I was in the backseat. All i could hear was his voice; which changed and cracked as he started talking about his daughter. I felt sympathy at this time because his voice showed his true emotions. I also remember the faces of my teammates. They all looked shocked and sad at the same time. Usually a loud; comical bunch; we were all taken aback. Seeing my teammates faces made me see how real my coach's situation is; which made me feel sympathy. I remember being somewhat surprised to see my golf coach open up like he did; so it took me a couple of seconds to think of something to say. There wasn't much else that I could say because it was essentially my coach's post-season speech. I wanted to pat him on the back or something along those lines; but we were in a van and I was in the backseat while my coach was driving. My coach continued on by talking about the positives of the team; which made me feel sympathy because it seemed like he was trying to change the subject from himself to the team; which is a very selfless thing to do.
writeempat: This is not a very strong feeling of empathy; but this example; to me; is the exact definition of empathy. This situation happens many times. Every time someone hurts their foot; ankle; knee or leg in a game of pickup basketball; I understand exactly how they feel and the pain that they are in. The most recent time that this situation occurred was this weekend. A very tall; heavy guy jumped onto a smaller guy's back by accident; then the smaller guy collapsed under the larger guy. The smaller guy was grabbing his knee and was writhing in pain on the floor of the basketball court. I could see the guy's clenched teeth and red face as he was trying to fight back the pain. He was also hitting the floor. This made me feel empathy because I have sprained both ankles several times each while playing basketball. Every time this happens; I do the same thing. I try to fight back yelling at the top of my lungs and slamming the floor. The pain is always much; much worse than someone would imagine. I remember that my body was shaking after the few severe sprains. I understood the pain that the smaller guy was feeling and how disappointing it is to be in crutches and being unable to walk for up to a week. I did not say anything or do anything because I was simply watching the basketball game; waiting to play in the next game. When the smaller guy got hurt; I thought about the sprained ankles and the pain that I described before. I knew that nothing that I could say or do would help the smaller guy; so I didn't do anything (other people already ran to get ice).
plove: Pity is a caring type of love because you have to feel sorry for somebody; which involves caring about that person.
pcontempt: I do not think this is true. I think that in order to feel pity; one must have empathy. I don't think empathy is involved with contempt; which is strong anger or resentment.
slove: Sympathy is a caring type of love.
elove: Empathy is definitely necessary to have love; but it is not a kind of love. Empathy is a separate emotion. It is understanding how someone else feels or thinks.

writepity: My best friend got an MIP when we were freshmen in college; and even though we did drink underage regularly; the moment she got an MIP; I don't think she was at fault. It was a football tailgate that she had decided not to drink at that day; because she had to work later on. Another friend asked if she could hold his beer bottle while he did something; and at that point in time a cop came up and wrote her an MIP. Even while he was writing her one; a drunk girl behind him threw a beer bottle at the cop; and he decided to do nothing about it. She was truly in the wrong place at the wrong time; and I don't believe it was fair. I felt bad because she had to wake up at 5 am for the next couple months and couldn't drink for upcoming occasions.
writetende: A family friend; who was also my dance teacher; I had known for 18 years. She was very close with my entire immediate family and when she developed cancer; we were all very saddened by it. IT happened very quickly and she passed away only months after being diagnosed. When my sisters; Mom; and I attended the funeral; we were all sobbing uncontrollably and hugging each other.
writecomp: My roommate is a graphic design major and works extremely hard; all the time. She is constantly stressing herself out; staying up late; and running around to meet deadlines. She's constantly been stressed out lately about her final senior projects being due and about finding a job. Her final project was chosen as a finalist for a class competition; and she got hired  by a company solely for her work; as they had seen that it had improved since the year before. I was extremely proud of her.
writesymp: I have a roommate whose dad passed away about two years ago. When he died; I wasn't that close with her; but I understood that he had had melanoma and had tumors in his brain; making his last couple months extremely painful. Even though I wasn't close with her then; I still attended his wake service and found myself trying to extremely hard to fight back tears. I had never met him; but the place was packed and there were flowers everywhere. I could gather that he was an extremely popular man. Now that I'm much closer to my roommate; I always feel very sympathetic about some of the things she says about her dad; or even seeing the tattoo she has in remembrance of him. Sometimes I don't know how to act; or even wonder if bringing up stories about my dad in front of her would be considered inappropriate. It breaks my heart any time she mentions him though.
writeempat: My roommate has always been very concerned about living far away from her parents because if they were to ever get sick; she wouldn't know how to deal with it from a distance. One day she came home crying and she told me that her dad had fainted and they had to rush him to the hospital. I felt extremely bad for her because I know it's something she constantly worries about anyway; so her state of mind was very frantic. There was not much I felt I could say to try to ease the situation; because when someone gets sick; it can be extremely difficult to verbally deal with. I felt frantic as well because she was just sitting in my bedroom crying and trying to decided if she should make the four hour drive home or not that day.
plove: I would maybe call pity love in regards to it meaning not enjoying seeing another person upset or in a bad situation.
pcontempt: No
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love dealing with sharing emotions
clove: I think compassion is a type of love dealing with others' happiness
slove: I would consider sympathy a kind of love because it's about feeling sorry for the bad situation that someone else is confronted with
elove: I would call it a type of love in which you care for the other person's happiness and well being

writepity: One of my close friends; a female; was in a secret relationship with another female. My close friend was not comfortable sharing her feelings; and was not able to be open about this relationship. The girl that she was in a relationship with was very comfortable with these feelings; and wanted to share them publicly. My friend was not able to even tell her closest friends about the feelings; and secret relationship; that she was having. I felt pity towards my close friend. I pitied her because she was not able to be comfortable with who she is; not even with her closest friends. She was pretending to be someone she wasn't; and was; in return; just hurting herself and her emotions. I thought that it was really upsetting that she was so uncomfortable with such a thing; knowing that I; and her other friends; would fully support her; and for that I pitied her. I wanted to tell her to just be open about it; and to tell people. I did tell her to do so; but she refused.
writetende: I time when I felt tenderness toward someone was when my sister's cat died. The cat's death didn't directly affect me much; but it definitely affected my sister; and it made me feel very tender. She was so visibly upset; and it was hard to watch. I wanted to hold her in my arms and tell her that everything would be okay; but she just wanted to be alone. I told her that things would turn out okay; and that her cat loved her a lot and was happy and safe wherever it was now.
writecomp: I was at a school talent show; where many of my friends were performing. They had practiced a lot and had to perform in front of over 2;000 people. While they were performing; I felt very compassionate. For them to be able to do such a thing made me feel a special way; and made me view them all differently. I bought them all flowers and told them how amazing they all were and cheered for them very loudly. I made sure that they knew how much I cared for them.
writesymp: Two of my friends tried out for a school play; and I was able to watch the callbacks. They both got called back for the same role. During callbacks; one of my friends; I'll call her friend #1; performed significantly better than my other friend; friend #2. Friend #2 ended up getting the role. Once the cast list was announced; my friend #1 was very upset and felt as though she had done something wrong. I told her that she had not done anything wrong; and that I had seen it with my own eyes; and she deserved the role; not friend #2. I felt a lot of sympathy towards her. It was not fair that she had not gotten the role; and it was not fair that she was so upset over it.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: In some cases; yes. Some people pity other people to try to make themselves feel better; and maybe because they are jealous. In some cases people pity other people and it is not connected to contempt.
tlove: I would not call tenderness a kind of love.
clove: I would not call compassion a kind of love.
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.

writepity: I'm from a big city; and there is one homeless man that's always sitting on the same street corner on a box. One day when I was in a particularly bad mood; he asked me for change as usual; and I felt that doing something nice that day might cheer me up. Instead of giving him change; I walked past him to the pizza place and bought him a couple of slices. When I gave it to him; he was not grateful; he seemed merely confused and a bit irritated. He asked me if I had any money. He did not even thank me. I felt pity toward him because this told me a lot about his homelessness. He was not grateful at all for food; which shows that he did not want the money to buy himself a meal; but to buy something else; likely drugs or cigarettes; which made me feel terrible for him and his situation; which must be extremely difficult.
writetende: When I was 16 my at the time boyfriend and I went back to his empty house after prom to have sex for both of our first times. It was extremely awkward physically; but we cared about each other so much that somehow the situation didn't feel awkward. It really hurt and it was terrible. However; afterward; we both thought that it was still a really positive experience because we somehow felt a lot closer to each other. No one got really hurt physically or emotionally; and we were both really glad that we chose to do this with each other; because had it been someone we trusted less; it could have been potentially really awkward and traumatic. We sat in his car talking for a long time after; and I felt very trusting and gentle toward him; because I was grateful that this had not been a bad experience and that I was with him.
writecomp: When I was going into my freshman year of high school; my best friend and I were hanging out after he had gotten back from summer camp for the last couple of months. We spent the whole day catching up on things; and just as I turned to leave to walk home; he stopped me and told me he had to tell me something. He took a deep breath and told me that at camp he realized he was gay. This was the first time he had talked about it openly; and although he was ready to share it with me; he was not ready to share it with the rest of his friends or his parents. He seemed decently comfortable and confident in this realization; but also very scared about how this would impact his life. I somewhat understood what he was going through; but everyone's coming out experience is extremely different; and I offered to help him in any way possible through his journey. I felt very proud and very close to him; but also felt sympathy toward him because I know that this is a difficult process. I told him that I supported him and that I wouldn't tell anyone; and that I was here for him if he ever needed anything; and that I was very grateful that he trusted me with this information.
writesymp: When I was in 6th grade; both of my mom's parents died within 11 months of each other. I had never dealt with the loss of a family member before; and had no conception of what her grief must have felt like; especially since I was only 11 years old. My grandparents were extremely old; and though I mourned their loss; I didn't know them well; as they had little ability to communicate in their older years when I remembered them. Therefore; I could not understand at all what my mom was going through; but I deeply felt for her and wanted to help her. My brother and I spent a lot more time with her that year than we usually did; and we tried to do anything we could to help her through the situation. I wanted to make her feel better; but knew that she didn't want to place the burden on us; and also that we couldn't understand what was really happening with her emotionally.
writeempat: My boyfriend's mom is in prison for shooting his dad when my boyfriend was in 9th grade. When he was in 11th grade; he received a letter from her; and it was his first time hearing from her since it happened. He told me about it after school; and said that the letter said that his mom thought he was turning into everything she hated about his dad. This really affected him and it was the first time I'd ever seen him truly shaken emotionally. Although I could not relate to the severity of the experience; I empathized with feeling like; or being told; that you are a disappointment to your parents. I felt truly powerless and devastated that he had to go through something so horrible; and then have his mom insult him after she was the one who committed such a terrible crime. I tried to just listen to him and ask him if he needed anything; because that was pretty much all I could do at the time to help him out.
plove: I don't believe pity is a form of love. Perhaps a form of compassion; which could be a part of love.
pcontempt: It's slightly true because there is some higher ground required in feeling pity for someone. You have to kind of believe you're a little bit better than them in some way.
tlove: Tenderness can definitely be a consequence of love; and I would even say it's one step before love. When you start to develop feelings of deep tenderness toward someone; that is not a far cry from loving them in some way.
clove: I believe that compassion can be a kind of love. I'm not sure what type it would be; as it can manifest itself in many ways; but it definitely requires caring about what happens to a person.
slove: I'm not sure I would go so far as to call sympathy a kind of love; as it is more removed from empathy; and does not require the ability to relate. Sympathy can just be feeling sad on behalf of someone else; which doesn't necessarily indicate love; though likely some affection.
elove: Empathy is a kind of compassionate love; as it requires caring about the person and understanding what they are going through in some capacity.

writepity: A few weekends ago I was volunteering at an all-day volunteer day in Detroit with fellow University of Michigan students. My group's assignment was to clean up a neighborhood garden of debris in order to make the neighborhood look more appealing and encourage people to keep it that way under the broken window theory. While I was working at the edge of the park kind of away from some of the fellow workers; a man from the neighborhood; clearly drunk; came up to me and asked if I had any money to spare. I said "No; I'm sorry" in the nicest way possible. I said no both because I did not have money on me and because I knew that he would only use it to buy himself more alcohol; though what he needed was a nice meal or warmer clothes. However; I said it in the nicest way possible because I did feel bad for him. Though it was probably his decision to pick up the bottle in the first place; alcoholism is a disease which led me to believe that he had enough problems without a student talking down to him or being rude to him when he needs help the most.
writecomp: The most recent time - and therefore my most vivid memory of - when I felt compassion for someone was last week when I was watching a movie for my spanish class called Baja la Misma Luna (Under the Same Moon). It was a story about a mom and son who had been separated for years because the mom had illegally crossed the border from Mexico into America to work to earn citizenship for her son. These two were only able to communicate during these years pay payphone for five minutes every Sunday while the mother worked three jobs to earn the money to pay a lawyer. These two faced many hardships; first; the mother had earned enough money to pay a man who claimed he was a lawyer when in reality he was just scamming her. Then; the son's grandmother; who had been his guardian while his mother was away; passed away. So; the son had to sneak across the border because he didnt have family left in Mexico to take care of him besides his aunt and uncle who just wanted to take care of him so that they could receive the checks his mother sent monthly. Then on the road to Los Angeles; where the mother was; he faced drug addicts; deportation; and lost his traveling money. All I wanted to do was reach in there and help him; give him some money and help him find his mom. Luckily; in the end; the two found each other.
plove: No; I would not call pity a type of love. I type of kindness yes but not love.
pcontempt: No; when I feel pity I feel that I should do something to help them. I feel restless and hopeless but also energized to find out what I can do. Pity is nothing like contempt for me.
clove: Yes; I think compassion is the kind of love that you can feel for people you know and/or not know. I think compassion comes from understanding another person's situation and feeling toward that situation and wanting to do whatever you can to help the situation or help them feel better because you know that you would appreciate the help if you were in their situation. It means respecting every person and holding them equal in importance to yourself because you are both human; not different due to racial; socioeconomic; etc. reasons.

writepity: I felt pity towards my sister when she got into trouble at school. She had wrongfully been accused of cheating on a test. I felt pity because I knew what had happened wasn't right and I felt powerless in the situation. I kept thinking that there must have been something I could have said to the teacher or principal but I didn't know exactly what I could say to persuade them otherwise.
writetende: I felt tenderness towards a baby that I was babysitting. The baby looked so fragile and helpless; so I was very gentle and calm in her presence. I was feeling that I needed to be very cautious so that I didn't cause any harm to the baby. I felt almost afraid because I knew that one wrong move on my part could really injure the baby. I also didn't want to negatively contribute to any developmental problems the baby may be able to have from being in my care. I wanted to play with the baby and make her laugh; which I did. I tried to tickle her and play peek a boo. Other times when I tried to play with the baby; she would scream. I think I felt tenderness because babies cry at little things and since they can't communicate; I have a hard time reassuring myself that I'm doing everything okay.
writecomp: I felt compassion towards someone when I worked in Detroit for a food bank service day. I didn't actually meet anyone who was homeless or in need of food. From prior experience to encountering or hearing about homeless people; it was not hard to imagine what the circumstances were like. I felt like I was very fortunate and that I could use that good fortune to help others in need. Everyone should have access to food; and I feel compassion towards those who do not. What I wanted to do was work as efficiently as possible to gather as many bags of food that would be distributed to the hungry. I wanted to genuinely work my hardest and produce a successful outcome. What I did was suggest an easier way to organize how the bag would be put together by the group of volunteers I was with. This led to more efficiency.
writesymp: I recently felt sympathetic when my grandmother's friend passed away. I felt sympathy for the family that was grieving. The main reason I felt this way was because I associated my grandma's friend as being somewhat like my actual grandma. The lady died of illness; so it was not a shock to the family and in a way it was kind of expected. Although my grandma is getting older; I felt sadness for the family based on the sadness I would feel if my grandma had passed away; regardless of the reason. I was thinking that my grandma could be the next person that I know that dies and I wanted to make sure I spent as much time with her as I can in the future. We always had a great relationship and it continues to get better each time I visit home or  talk with her over the phone. When I was at the funeral; I wanted to just be as supportive of the family as I could. The best way that I could do that; and did do that; was by making sure my grandma was at the funeral. My grandma is a good friend of the family and her absence would have been noticed. So; I felt that even if I couldn't really talk to the family that was grieving; since I didn't know them that well; I was being supportive since I made sure my grandma was there.
writeempat: I felt empathetic toward my boyfriend when he had a big assignment that was due the next day. I always tell him how he needs to stop procrastinating and that he always ends up in the same situations because of his own doing. I wanted to just hug him and tell him that everything would be okay. I always say that I'm going to not help him or feel bad; but it always ends up happening anyways. I ended up helping him and proofreading part of the assignment so that he would feel less stressed about the whole situation.
plove: I wouldn't call pity a type of love.
pcontempt: No; I do not think this is true
tlove: Tenderness is a kind of love that is very respectful with regards to boundaries and limits.
clove: Compassion is a temporary type of love that hits only certain people... people that genuinely care about the well being of others.
slove: It would be a kind of love that is short-lived but very genuine at the time of occurring
elove: I think this type of love would be temporary; but recurring

writetende: I'm struggling to come up with an example of this. I have never described how I felt with the word tenderness.  /  /  My situation is my significant other; opening up to me and letting me in; telling me they love me. I felt tenderness for them because I know it was difficult for them and I have been in the same situation. But I could tell they were fragile doing that; because it is risky to let someone in.
writesymp: Recently; my sorority house caught on fire. Thankfully everyone was okay but it was a scary experience at the time being woke up at 2am with the alarm going off and not being able to find the girls who had the room the fire started in. Those girls lost most everything. It was really hard to see them go through that; they were my sisters; friends; and I could not imagine if that would of been me. I just wanted to do what I could for them during this trying time. It was amazing how greek life; and the rest of our sisters; were so supportive and helpful during this time. Donating their time; money; clothes; whatever they could need to help make their situation less stressful. They even had school and exams during this time! We are all grateful that they are okay but it was still hard to see what they had to go through compared to the rest of the house.
writeempat: The experience that I thought of involved my mother. Her and her long time boyfriend were going through some tough times and it was really taking a toll on my mom. The thing is he kept pulling this shit with her. He would say things like he loves her but he is not "in love" with her and he's just not happy with himself and feels like he doesn't deserve her. Honestly I think my mom could do better but that is besides the point. I remember her crying to me on the phone and being so upset and there was nothing I could do. I would try to say things to make her feel better but what are you suppose to do when your parents are the ones that are crying to you? They are the people who are there for you when you are like that. It was really hard to see my mom like that; especially thinking of all the things she's done for me and I didn't know how to help her get through it. I really felt what she was going through and it was even harder because it was my mom. I'm normally an empathetic person even with strangers I do not even know. But with my mother the emotions were may more intense.
tlove: An enduring love
slove: I would not call sympathy a kind of love.
elove: I would not call empathy a kind of love.

writepity: When I was taking a course at the same time as my friend; we both wanted to do well. When it came to the exams she would always under perform compared to her expectations; after studying for weeks at a time. Every time I would pity her because it just seems like she could never be satisfied with her abilities and always comparing herself to others. I would always want to tell her that its silly and that she should just focus on doing her best and also use her time to enjoy her self
writetende: I felt tenderness towards my 4 year old cousin. When I was taking a nap he came to lay down next to me cover us with a blanket gave me a kiss and fell asleep right next to me. when I looked at him I felt tenderness because of how nice and genuine what he did was. All i wanted to do was just pick him up and hug him; to express my emotions towards him but I couldn't wake him up so I instead took a picture of him and told everyone of how cute he was.
writecomp: When I was volunteering on a ambulance in a foreign country; we picked up a call of a motorcycle accident. There was a 19 year old girl who got hit while on a motor bike with her boyfriend. I was sitting in the back with her taking her vitals; and even though i didn't really speak the same language as her she managed to communicate to me that she was scared and she wanted to hold my hand for comfort. I could not refuse; as she looked so scared and hurt. I felt compassionate towards her and wanted to comfort her best i could as a first aid provider. All i could tell her was that its going to be ok and that no her mother wont kill her for being on a bike with her boyfriend.
writesymp: When I was watching Armagedon with my girlfriend and after having seen the movie about a dozen times; she still bawls like a baby at the final scene. I couldn't help my try to sympathies with her because she looked so sad and upset; and i tried to comfort her and make her laugh but the tears kept pouring.
writeempat: When my friend told me about his father and how he was under investigation of FBI for thing he didn't do and how it was literally ruining his life. He went from being well of to having absolutely no money to spend. I couldnt help but think of how i would feel being in the same situation and how much it would suck and all i wanted and could tell him was that I'm here for him if he needs to talk about anything.
plove: i would not call pity a kind of love
pcontempt: Not really
tlove: a brotherly kind of love

writecomp: i showed compassion to my fiance . he is the love of my life . and i think without showing compassion to him he would be a wreck . because everyone needs to be shown a little compassion . it shows you care about them .
writesymp: august 23 ; 2001 my father died of a massive heart attack . i have two younger sisters and they were ages 9 and 11 at the time . they didnt under stand what was going on . At this moment i was 15 yrs old and i understood . they day he died they cried and cried ; so did i  . but i felt sympathy towards them because i had the honor of having our father for the majority of my life and they had to grow up without him in theirs . And i thought who was going to teach them about boys and dating and marraige and give them advice from a mans point of view as my father did for me. i hated the fact that he left this world so suddenly . leaving me to take care of two younger siblings . i told them everything will be ok and we will get through this together . till this day they are living life to the fullest and still come to me for advice.
writeempat: when my son was 11 months old he had his first eye surgery . it was hard to watch from the outside . the nurses was trying to put an I V in his foot and he cried and cried . at first i wanted to punch the nurse in the face because she was hurting my baby . i wanted to pick him up right off the bed and tell him everything was going to be ok . when the IV was in the maddnes was over . So my son and i went down to the cafeteria and had ice cream . he asked me why did the nurse hurt him and i told him she was only doing her job to make him feel better . he said ok and we ate ice cream until his heart was content.
clove: i think compassion is a unconditional kind of love
slove: a caring kind of love . because is you show someone sympathy it shows that you care about that person otherwise you wouldnt show synpathy
elove: im not quite sure what kind of love it is but i believe it is a kind of love

writepity: If I were to think of a time where I felt pity for someone it would be when one of my friends got caught cheating for an exam and she was really upset about it. Of course; she came to me and told me what happened. She figured I would be there for her because she was one of my closest friends. I truthfully didn't know what to tell her at the time. I did not feel bad that she got caught because it was what she deserved. She was aware of the consequences but went ahead and cheated anyway. Therefore; in this particular situation I felt pity towards her. Although I did not agree with what she did; I told her that everything will be okay and she should try and fix her mistake by writing an apology note to her professor and the department. Ultimately; this is what she did.
writecomp: The most recent time I felt compassion was when I visited my little sister in the hospital. She was diagnosed with bronchitis and was admitted immediately. She is very dear to my heart so this was a really sad moment for me. I wanted to be there for her and make her feel like she was in a safe place; considering she was 2 years old. I brought her toys from home and read books to her while she laid in bed. I comforted her and made sure she was happy until she was finally discharged.
writesymp: The most recent time I felt sympathy for someone was when my roommates grandfather passed away a couple weeks ago. I received the news the day of his passing. I decided to give her the space she needed and called the next day. I was very sad and devastated for her loss. Initially; I was at a loss for words but I pulled it together and began telling her that he is in a better place and looking down upon his family. I also told her that at one point; everyone will have to go and she should be happy he was here to stand by all of her accomplishments so far. I ended the conversation but telling her that if her or her family needed anything to let me know.
writeempat: The most recent time I felt empathy towards someone was about two days ago. My cousin called me; frustrated to say the least;to talk to me about a phone call she had just had with one of her closest friends. They have been on and off; I guess you could say; but neither one of them had ever openly admitted their feelings for one another. When I answered the phone; it was clear she was upset because they got into an argument over some issues that had evolved. I began telling her that every relationship has problems and no relationship is perfect. I continued by telling her to not feel so upset over this and to work it out with him. I began thinking about the same situation I had been in a few months back so I knew exactly how she felt. I informed her about how I was in her shoes once and the one thing I learned from my experience was to open up about the issue the moment it happens; instead of bottling it all up inside which usually leads to arguments like the one she just had. I also told her to give him some space for the time being so they can both breathe and come back to the situation. She essentially took my advice and ended up working it out with him.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I do not think Pity is akin to contempt.
clove: If I were to call compassion a kind of love; I would say it is the kind that brings you closer to people to show them how much you care for them and are willing to stay by their side. It follows the same kind of love as sympathy and empathy.
slove: If I were to call sympathy a kind of love; I would say it is the kind that allows you to be there for someone no matter what it is they are going through. To give them words of advice and help them as much as possible.
elove: If I were to call empathy a kind of love; it would be the kind that would make you be there for that person no matter how hard or stressful the situation may be. You would help them go through it until they feel better.

writepity: One of my best friends in high school wanted to apply for a famous university when we graduated. But his father did not have enough confidence in him and persuaded him to choose another one. He gave up and applied for the one that his father chose. We had a general university selection exam in China for all high school students. After the score came out; he found that his score was just enough to get into his dream school. But he did not have a chance since he already applied for the other one. I felt very pity for him because I knew how much it mean to him. I wanted to cheer him up but I knew it was impossible. Such a big decision could not be comforted by words but only time.
writetende: My friend suffered a difficult period during a busy semester. He did not do well in a very important exam and a very important project. He broke his new laptop and had to pay a lot to get it repaired. In a word; his life came to a mess. /  / I was one of his best friend. He had helped me a lot and I really cared about him. I felt tenderness. I wanted to do something to comfort his heart. I planned some small trips to cheer him up and moved him attention from the terrible exam result to something else. I knew it would past but it would be a difficult time since he was always of top range in the class.
writecomp: My teacher told us about the situation of some poor areas in Africa. She talked about the living of the children there. I was very shocked and felt compassion for those children. They were of the same age as I at that time. But they suffered so much. I thought that life was so unfair. I did not know what I could do as I was only a middle school student at that time. But I felt if there were any chances to help them; I would love to do.
writeempat: I met a schoolmate who was searching for an internship offer two weeks ago. He was very worried and tied. I felt empathy to him because I suffered the same thing last year during my internship searching. I told him about my experience and encouraged him to keep going.
plove: Yes. Usually you feel pity for someone who does matter to you. He/She must be someone you love.
pcontempt: No. I think that usually I feel pity when something bad happens to my friends. These are usually not under the control of us.
tlove: Yes. It is a kind of love that you want to help him/her. You want to do something to make them happy like cooking something for them; play something for them and so on.
clove: I do not think compassion is a kind of love. Love is usually between people with strong bonds. But compassion is usually not.
elove: No. I do not think empathy is a kind of love. It just occurs when you meet someone going though something that you have experience of. It has nothing related to love.

writepity: When you play varsity high school football; you end up seeing a lot of guys cry towards the end of the season.  This is because for most guys; it's the last time they will ever play football (in pads; under the lights; with refs; etc.).  I remember my senior year there was a football team playing us the last game of the regular season.  We had already made the playoffs and were undefeated coming into the game; but they just needed this one win in order to qualify for the playoffs.  It was simple; if they won; they got to keep playing football. If they lost; they were done for the rest of their lives.  The game was close but we ended up winning 56-49 in the last few seconds of the game.  I remember seeing the players at the end of the field on their hands and knees crying because they knew the sport was over for them.  It was in that moment I felt pity.  I felt as if I deserved to move on and keep playing football; but still felt horrible for ending their careers. They had put so much blood; sweat and tears into the sport and; in fact; almost beat us even though we were the heavy favorite.  Knowing what I had done had caused someone emotional pain like that caused me to feel a lot of pity.  After we shook hands with some of the players I wanted to run over to those guys crying on the field and help them up and tell them "sorry" and "good game."  I didn't end up doing it because I thought they'd be more mad at me for ending their career and not respond well to that action.  But; my pity tried to drive me to that action.  I instead went back over to my team and listened to our coaches thoughts on the game. But; the whole time I was focused on the emotional heartbreak they felt.
writetende: I remember feeling tenderness toward someone vividly when they were rejected from this University during our senior year of high school.  It was hard to feel sympathy or empathize with them when I felt they truly didn't deserve to be accepted here.  But; on the other hand; it had been a goal for her to attend this university and study here.  I remember feeling tender and bad for her when she found out she was rejected; but it didn't affect me emotionally the way it would if I believed she had deserved to get in.  I felt tenderness for her because I knew it was something she wanted very badly; but I was content with what had happened because I knew more worthy applicants had been accepted.  Though I agreed with the outcome of the situation; I still felt bad for her and expressed this verbally to her.  I told her that it was going to be alright and that she should keep trying to get in here.  I wanted to tell her that getting into Michigan doesn't define your success as a student and that acceptance here is very competitive.  I felt a state of dissonance while telling her this because although I wanted to make her feel better; I agreed with the decision they had made.
writesymp: In the last days of my senior year in high school; my best friend's mom died due to ovarian cancer.  She died on a Monday and it hit the school like a ton of bricks.  This was a woman that I had seen quite regularly; drove me to countless sports practices and was good friends with my mom.  She played an integral role in the community; but rather an even more integral role in her family.  When I found out she had passed my stomach dropped.  I felt sad; mad and even cried a little about it.  I couldn't even imagine losing my mom at such a young age.  It was in that moment that I felt sympathy for my friend because of his loss.  When I attempted to put myself in his shoes; I couldn't even imagine the emotional pain and distraught he was feeling.  I reached out to him immediately on the phone and made sure he was alright.  I gave him my condolences and said I was here for him no matter what. I felt that no one should lose a parent that early. I even pondered starting a charity or some sort of charitable fund for cancer in honor of his mom.  What caused me the most sympathy was how calm and collected he seemed to be through it all.  Just two days after her death; he showed up to school for the last day of high school.  It was astonishing to me the strength that he could portray when I know if that had happened to me; I would be a wreck.  Through his unfortunate circumstance and his ability to stay strong and collected through the emotional shock; I felt more sympathy for him than I ever had in my life.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I don't think this is true.  I don't think pity is akin to happiness on your part.  People can be in unfortunate circumstances themselves and have pity for someone else.  I think pity is a function of your personality and how caring you are as a person.  It has nothing to do with your emotional state.
tlove: I wouldn't call tenderness a kind of love.  I would say it is more an appreciation for someone's bad circumstance and a sensitivity towards it.  It doesn't drive you to the point of action like a "love" does in these situations.
slove: Sympathy would be the kind of love that is portrayed in dire circumstances.  When tragedy or unfortunate events occur; people show their love for those affected through their sympathy.

writepity: Pity is when you feel bad for someone but also feel as though you are better than them or could have made a better decision.
writetende: Tenderness is showing a soft spot for something important or hurtful to you
writecomp: When I feel compassion I usually first start off by thinking about someone else and how they feel instead myself. When I'm using compassion I tend to use it towards people who are feeling down or in need of someone to help them out emotionally. My encounter with using compassion was in practice when my teammate was feeling down; because he felt that the coaches always addressed how he made mistakes and not the things he did that were good. I pulled him to the side and told him that he needed to not worry about what the coaches said or did because that's just how the game is. He should only worry about the next play and how perfect he would be one step at a time; because everyone makes mistakes. I was going through the same problem before so i felt i could address the problem as effective as i could in order for him to get the idea that he only can control the controllable; which is what i needed to learn.
writeempat: Empathy is understanding how someone else is feeling. trying to connect to someone and understand how they feel even if you did not go through those situations.
plove: I dont feel pity is love at all
clove: Caring; unselfishness

writepity: There is a competitive Bollywood dance team circuit that has recently formed at the collegiate level. A bunch of my friends have joined the team here at the university and worked all year long to have an amazing competition season. The goal at the end is to get a bid to go to the national competition; which is held in California. This team has worked countless amount of hours and has placed at every single one of their competitions this year; however; they did not receive a bid for nationals this year. I felt pity for the team because of their dedication; but since they are a newly formed team; the circuit has not had the chance to get to know their abilities and chose a team that is more widely known instead of them to compete in California this year. In this instance I told the members of the team to stay proud and happy of all their accomplishments; and that as long as they keep working hard; they can get their bid next year.
writetende: Volunteering at the children's hospital over the summer allowed me to interact with a lot of young patients that were going through a tough time in their life. Many of the kids that I had the chance to spend time with had a disease they were dealing with; but since they were so young; none of them really understood why they were really in the hospital. There was one little boy that I was reading a story to one day that really touched my hear. He had leukemia and did not understand why he had to be in the hospital all the time. He just wanted to fit in at school and play with his friends. I felt tender for this child because he was so sweet as he got along with all the other children in the hospital very nicely and was very respectful to the staff and myself. However; it touched my heart to see that he could not leave the hospital to go home and see his siblings; or go to school and play with his friends. In this instance I made sure that he was always smiling and playing with myself or meeting a new friend every day to keep him occupied and happy. So he felt less homesick.
writesymp: Coming to college was a hard change from high school. The caliber was much difficult; along with the many credit hours; it was hard to balance school work and social events. However; I had a group of friends that all studied together all the time; and still managed to have a day of fun within the week. Once our first chemistry test came around; most of my friends and I scored really well on the exam; however one of my friends did not. Even though she studied as much as we did and maybe even more; she did not get the score she wanted. In this instance I felt sympathetic towards her because I knew college exams and classes are difficult and she worked so hard to do well; but did not meet the standards she wanted. After the exam we studied more together; just us; and made sure we did not only study. We thought that since we only stressed ourselves out by working so hard; it could be the reason why she stressed so much on the test. Therefore; we went to the gym more and hung out with friends outside of studying.
plove: I would not call pity a kind of love.
pcontempt: I can understand why people may think this way; considering if a person saw another person upset and felt pity about their situation then they themselves may feel better about them; however; personally I do not believe this is true.
tlove: I believe tenderness is a love people feel when they show by taking care of someone else who is in a rough situation and does not know what to do.
slove: I believe sympathy can be considered a love because when a person is sympathetic to another; that means they care a lot about that person to want to help them get past their tough situation.
